title: Definitions I
prose:
1. Those magnitudes measured by the same measure are said (to be) commensurable, but (those) of which no (magnitude) admits to be a common measure (are said to be) incommensurable.

2. (Two) straight-lines are commensurable in square when the squares on them are measured by the same area, but (are) incommensurable (in square) when no area admits to be a common measure of the squares on them.

3. These things being assumed, it is proved that there exist an infinite multitude of straight-lines commensurable and incommensurable with an assigned straight-line---those (incommensurable) in length only, and those also (commensurable or incommensurable) in square.
Therefore, let the assigned straight-line be called rational.
And (let) the (straight-lines) commensurable with it, either in length and square, or in square only, (also be called) rational.
But let the (straight-lines) incommensurable with it be called irrational.

4. And let the square on the assigned straight-line be called rational.
And (let areas) commensurable with it (also be called) rational.
But (let areas) incommensurable with it (be called) irrational, and (let) their square-roots (also be called) irrational---the sides themselves, if the (areas) are squares, and the (straight-lines) describing squares equal to them, if the (areas) are some other rectilinear (figure).

title: Proposition 1
prose:
If, from the greater of two unequal magnitudes (which are) laid out, (a part) greater than half is subtracted, and (if from) the remainder (a part) greater than half (is subtracted), and (if) this happens continually, then some magnitude will (eventually) be left which will be less than the lesser laid out magnitude.

Let {AB magnitude} and {C magnitude} be two unequal magnitudes, of which (let) {AB magnitude} (be) the greater.
I say that if (a part) greater than half is subtracted from {AB magnitude}, and (if a part) greater than half (is subtracted) from the remainder, and (if) this happens continually, then some magnitude will (eventually) be left which will be less than the magnitude {C magnitude}.

For {C magnitude}, when multiplied (by some number), will sometimes be greater than {AB magnitude} [Def. 5.4].
Let it have been (so) multiplied.
And let {DE magnitude} be (both) a multiple of {C magnitude}, and greater than {AB magnitude}.
And let {DE magnitude} have been divided into the (divisions) {DF magnitude}, {FG magnitude}, {GE magnitude}, equal to {C magnitude}.
And let {BH magnitude}, (which is) greater than half, have been subtracted from {AB magnitude}.
And (let) {HK magnitude}, (which is) greater than half, (have been subtracted) from {AH magnitude}.
And let this happen continually, until the divisions in {AB magnitude} become equal in number to the divisions in {DE magnitude}.

Therefore, let the divisions (in {AB magnitude}) be {AK magnitude}, {KH magnitude}, {HB magnitude}, being equal in number to {DF magnitude}, {FG magnitude}, {GE magnitude}.
And since {DE magnitude} is greater than {AB magnitude}, and {EG magnitude}, (which is) less than half, has been subtracted from {DE magnitude}, and {BH magnitude}, (which is) greater than half, from {AB magnitude}, the remainder {GD magnitude} is thus greater than the remainder {HA magnitude}.
And since {GD magnitude} is greater than {HA magnitude}, and the half {GF magnitude} has been subtracted from {GD magnitude}, and {HK magnitude}, (which is) greater than half, from {HA magnitude}, the remainder {DF magnitude} is thus greater than the remainder {AK magnitude}.
And {DF magnitude} (is) equal to {C magnitude}.
{C magnitude} is thus also greater than {AK magnitude}.
Thus, {AK magnitude} (is) less than {C magnitude}.

Thus, the magnitude {AK magnitude}, which is less than the lesser laid out magnitude {C magnitude}, is left over from the magnitude {AB magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.
---(The theorem) can similarly be proved even if the (parts) subtracted are halves.

title: Proposition 2
prose:
If the remainder of two unequal magnitudes (which are) [laid out] never measures the (magnitude) before it, (when) the lesser (magnitude is) continually subtracted in turn from the greater, then the (original) magnitudes will be incommensurable.

For, {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} being two unequal magnitudes, and {AB magnitude} (being) the lesser, let the remainder never measure the (magnitude) before it, (when) the lesser (magnitude is) continually subtracted in turn from the greater.
I say that the magnitudes {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} are incommensurable.

For if they are commensurable then some magnitude will measure them (both).
If possible, let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {E magnitude}.
And let {AB magnitude} leave {CF magnitude} less than itself (in) measuring {FD magnitude}, and let {CF magnitude} leave {AG magnitude} less than itself (in) measuring {BG magnitude}, and let this happen continually, until some magnitude which is less than {E magnitude} is left.
Let (this) have occurred, and let {AG magnitude}, (which is) less than {E magnitude}, have been left.
Therefore, since {E magnitude} measures {AB magnitude}, but {AB magnitude} measures {DF magnitude}, {E magnitude} will thus also measure {FD magnitude}.
And it also measures the whole (of) {CD magnitude}.
Thus, it will also measure the remainder {CF magnitude}.
But, {CF magnitude} measures {BG magnitude}.
Thus, {E magnitude} also measures {BG magnitude}.
And it also measures the whole (of) {AB magnitude}.
Thus, it will also measure the remainder {AG magnitude}, the greater (measuring) the lesser.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, some magnitude cannot measure (both) the magnitudes {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.
Thus, the magnitudes {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} are incommensurable [Def. 10.1].

Thus, if ...of two unequal magnitudes, and so on ....

title: Proposition 3
prose:
To find the greatest common measure of two given commensurable magnitudes.

Let {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} be the two given magnitudes, of which (let) {AB magnitude} (be) the lesser.
So, it is required to find the greatest common measure of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.

For the magnitude {AB magnitude} either measures, or (does) not (measure), {CD magnitude}.
Therefore, if it measures ({CD magnitude}), and (since) it also measures itself, {AB magnitude} is thus a common measure of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.
And (it is) clear that (it is) also (the) greatest.
For a (magnitude) greater than magnitude {AB magnitude} cannot measure {AB magnitude}.

So let {AB magnitude} not measure {CD magnitude}.
And continually subtracting in turn the lesser (magnitude) from the greater, the remaining (magnitude) will (at) some time measure the (magnitude) before it, on account of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} not being incommensurable [Prop. 10.2].
And let {AB magnitude} leave {EC magnitude} less than itself (in) measuring {ED magnitude}, and let {EC magnitude} leave {AF magnitude} less than itself (in) measuring {FB magnitude}, and let {AF magnitude} measure {CE magnitude}.

Therefore, since {AF magnitude} measures {CE magnitude}, but {CE magnitude} measures {FB magnitude}, {AF magnitude} will thus also measure {FB magnitude}.
And it also measures itself.
Thus, {AF magnitude} will also measure the whole (of) {AB magnitude}.
But, {AB magnitude} measures {DE magnitude}.
Thus, {AF magnitude} will also measure {ED magnitude}.
And it also measures {CE magnitude}.
Thus, it also measures the whole of {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {AF magnitude} is a common measure of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.
So I say that (it is) also (the) greatest (common measure).
For, if not, there will be some magnitude, greater than {AF magnitude}, which will measure (both) {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.
Let it be {G magnitude}.
Therefore, since {G magnitude} measures {AB magnitude}, but {AB magnitude} measures {ED magnitude}, {G magnitude} will thus also measure {ED magnitude}.
And it also measures the whole of {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {G magnitude} will also measure the remainder {CE magnitude}.
But {CE magnitude} measures {FB magnitude}.
Thus, {G magnitude} will also measure {FB magnitude}.
And it also measures the whole (of) {AB magnitude}.
And (so) it will measure the remainder {AF magnitude}, the greater (measuring) the lesser.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, some magnitude greater than {AF magnitude} cannot measure (both) {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {AF magnitude} is the greatest common measure of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}.

Thus, the greatest common measure of two given commensurable magnitudes, {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}, has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

Corollary

So (it is) clear, from this, that if a magnitude measures two magnitudes then it will also measure their greatest common measure.

title: Proposition 4
prose:
To find the greatest common measure of three given commensurable magnitudes.

Let {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude} be the three given commensurable magnitudes.
So it is required to find the greatest common measure of {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.

For let the greatest common measure of the two (magnitudes) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} have been taken [Prop. 10.3], and let it be {D magnitude}.
So {D magnitude} either measures, or [does] not [measure], {C magnitude}.
Let it, first of all, measure ({C magnitude}).
Therefore, since {D magnitude} measures {C magnitude}, and it also measures {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, {D magnitude} thus measures {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} is a common measure of {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
And (it is) clear that (it is) also (the) greatest (common measure).
For no magnitude larger than {D magnitude} measures (both) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.

So let {D magnitude} not measure {C magnitude}.
I say, first, that {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} are commensurable.
For if {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude} are commensurable then some magnitude will measure them which will clearly also measure {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
Hence, it will also measure {D magnitude}, the greatest common measure of {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.3 corr.].
And it also measures {C magnitude}.
Hence, the aforementioned magnitude will measure (both) {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} are commensurable [Def. 10.1].
Therefore, let their greatest common measure have been taken [Prop. 10.3], and let it be {E magnitude}.
Therefore, since {E magnitude} measures {D magnitude}, but {D magnitude} measures (both) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, {E magnitude} will thus also measure {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
And it also measures {C magnitude}.
Thus, {E magnitude} measures {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
Thus, {E magnitude} is a common measure of {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
So I say that (it is) also (the) greatest (common measure).
For, if possible, let {F magnitude} be some magnitude greater than {E magnitude}, and let it measure {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
And since {F magnitude} measures {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}, it will thus also measure {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, and will (thus) measure the greatest common measure of {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.3 corr.].
And {D magnitude} is the greatest common measure of {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
Thus, {F magnitude} measures {D magnitude}.
And it also measures {C magnitude}.
Thus, {F magnitude} measures (both) {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}.
Thus, {F magnitude} will also measure the greatest common measure of {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.3 corr.].
And it is {E magnitude}.
Thus, {F magnitude} will measure {E magnitude}, the greater (measuring) the lesser.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, some [magnitude] greater than the magnitude {E magnitude} cannot measure {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
Thus, if {D magnitude} does not measure {C magnitude} then {E magnitude} is the greatest common measure of {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}.
And if it does measure ({C magnitude}) then {D magnitude} itself (is the greatest common measure).

Thus, the greatest common measure of three given commensurable magnitudes has been found.
[(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.]

Corollary

So (it is) clear, from this, that if a magnitude measures three magnitudes then it will also measure their greatest common measure.

So, similarly, the greatest common measure of more (magnitudes) can also be taken, and the (above) corollary will go forward.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 5
prose:
Commensurable magnitudes have to one another the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.

Let {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} be commensurable magnitudes.
I say that {A magnitude} has to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.

For if {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are commensurable (magnitudes) then some magnitude will measure them.
Let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {C magnitude}.
And as many times as {C magnitude} measures {A magnitude}, so many units let there be in {D magnitude}.
And as many times as {C magnitude} measures {B magnitude}, so many units let there be in {E magnitude}.

Therefore, since {C magnitude} measures {A magnitude} according to the units in {D magnitude}, and a unit also measures {D magnitude} according to the units in it, a unit thus measures the number {D magnitude} as many times as the magnitude {C magnitude} (measures) {A magnitude}.
Thus, as {C magnitude} is to {A magnitude}, so a unit (is) to {D magnitude} [Def. 7.20].
Thus, inversely, as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to a unit [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
Again, since {C magnitude} measures {B magnitude} according to the units in {E magnitude}, and a unit also measures {E magnitude} according to the units in it, a unit thus measures {E magnitude} the same number of times that {C magnitude} (measures) {B magnitude}.
Thus, as {C magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so a unit (is) to {E magnitude} [Def. 7.20].
And it was also shown that as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to a unit.
Thus, via equality, as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so the number {D magnitude} (is) to the (number) {E magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].

Thus, the commensurable magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} have to one another the ratio which the number {D magnitude} (has) to the number {E magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 6
prose:
If two magnitudes have to one another the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number then the magnitudes will be commensurable.

For let the two magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} have to one another the ratio which the number {D magnitude} (has) to the number {E magnitude}.
I say that the magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are commensurable.

For, as many units as there are in {D magnitude}, let {A magnitude} have been divided into so many equal (divisions).
And let {C magnitude} be equal to one of them.
And as many units as there are in {E magnitude}, let {F magnitude} be the sum of so many magnitudes equal to {C magnitude}.
Therefore, since as many units as there are in {D magnitude}, so many magnitudes equal to {C magnitude} are also in {A magnitude}, therefore whichever part a unit is of {D magnitude}, {C magnitude} is also the same part of {A magnitude}.
Thus, as {C magnitude} is to {A magnitude}, so a unit (is) to {D magnitude} [Def. 7.20].
And a unit measures the number {D magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} also measures {A magnitude}.
And since as {C magnitude} is to {A magnitude}, so a unit (is) to the [number] {D magnitude}, thus, inversely, as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so the number {D magnitude} (is) to a unit [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
Again, since as many units as there are in {E magnitude}, so many (magnitudes) equal to {C magnitude} are also in {F magnitude}, thus as {C magnitude} is to {F magnitude}, so a unit (is) to the [number] {E magnitude} [Def. 7.20].
And it was also shown that as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to a unit.
Thus, via equality, as {A magnitude} is to {F magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
But, as {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, so {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}.
And thus as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so (it) also is to {F magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, {A magnitude} has the same ratio to each of {B magnitude} and {F magnitude}.
Thus, {B magnitude} is equal to {F magnitude} [Prop. 5.9].
And {C magnitude} measures {F magnitude}.
Thus, it also measures {B magnitude}.
But, in fact, (it) also (measures) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} measures (both) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
Thus, {A magnitude} is commensurable with {B magnitude} [Def. 10.1].

Thus, if two magnitudes ... to one another, and so on ....

Corollary

So it is clear, from this, that if there are two numbers, like {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}, and a straight-line, like {A magnitude}, then it is possible to contrive that as the number {D magnitude} (is) to the number {E magnitude}, so the straight-line (is) to (another) straight-line (i.e., {F magnitude}).
And if the mean proportion, (say) {B magnitude}, is taken of {A magnitude} and {F magnitude},then as {A magnitude} is to {F magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (will be) to the (square) on {B magnitude}.
That is to say, as the first (is) to the third, so the (figure) on the first (is) to the similar, and similarly described, (figure) on the second [Prop. 6.19 corr.].
But, as {A magnitude} (is) to {F magnitude}, so the number {D magnitude} is to the number {E magnitude}.
Thus, it has also been contrived that as the number {D magnitude} (is) to the number {E magnitude}, so the (figure) on the straight-line {A magnitude} (is) to the (similar figure) on the straight-line {B magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 7
prose:
Incommensurable magnitudes do not have to one another the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.

Let {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} be incommensurable magnitudes.
I say that {A magnitude} does not have to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.

For if {A magnitude} has to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number then {A magnitude} will be commensurable with {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
But it is not.
Thus, {A magnitude} does not have to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.

Thus, incommensurable numbers do not have to one another, and so on ....

title: Proposition 8
prose:
If two magnitudes do not have to one another the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number then the magnitudes will be incommensurable.

For let the two magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} not have to one another the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.
I say that the magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are incommensurable.

For if they are commensurable, {A magnitude} will have to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.5].
But it does not have (such a ratio).
Thus, the magnitudes {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are incommensurable.

Thus, if two magnitudes ... to one another, and so on ....

title: Proposition 9
prose:
Squares on straight-lines (which are) commensurable in length have to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And squares having to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number will also have sides (which are) commensurable in length.
But squares on straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in length do not have to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And squares not having to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number will not have sides (which are) commensurable in length either.

For let {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} be (straight-lines which are) commensurable in length.
I say that the square on {A magnitude} has to the square on {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.

For since {A magnitude} is commensurable in length with {B magnitude}, {A magnitude} thus has to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.5].
Let it have (that) which {C magnitude} (has) to {D magnitude}.
Therefore, since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude},so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
But the (ratio) of the square on {A magnitude} to the square on {B magnitude} is the square of the ratio of {A magnitude} to {B magnitude}.
For similar figures are in the squared ratio of (their) corresponding sides [Prop. 6.20 corr.].
And the (ratio) of the square on {C magnitude} to the square on {D magnitude} is the square of the ratio of the [number] {C magnitude} to the [number] {D magnitude}.
For there exits one number in mean proportion to two square numbers, and (one) square (number) has to the (other) square [number] a squared ratio with respect to (that) the side (of the former has) to the side (of the latter) [Prop. 8.11].
And, thus, as the square on {A magnitude} is to the square on {B magnitude}, so the square [number] on the (number) {C magnitude} (is) to the square [number] on the [number] {D magnitude}.

And so let the square on {A magnitude} be to the (square) on {B magnitude} as the square (number) on {C magnitude} (is) to the [square] (number) on {D magnitude}.
I say that {A magnitude} is commensurable in length with {B magnitude}.

For since as the square on {A magnitude} is to the [square] on {B magnitude}, so the square (number) on {C magnitude} (is) to the [square] (number) on {D magnitude}.
But, the ratio of the square on {A magnitude} to the (square) on {B magnitude} is the square of the (ratio) of {A magnitude} to {B magnitude} [Prop. 6.20 corr.].
And the (ratio) of the square [number] on the [number] {C magnitude} to the square [number] on the [number] {D magnitude} is the square of the ratio of the [number] {C magnitude} to the [number] {D magnitude} [Prop. 8.11].
Thus, as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so the [number] {C magnitude} also (is) to the [number] {D magnitude}.
{A magnitude}, thus, has to {B magnitude} the ratio which the number {C magnitude} has to the number {D magnitude}.
Thus, {A magnitude} is commensurable in length with {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].

And so let {A magnitude} be incommensurable in length with {B magnitude}.
I say that the square on {A magnitude} does not have to the [square] on {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.

For if the square on {A magnitude} has to the [square] on {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number then {A magnitude} will be commensurable (in length) with {B magnitude}.
But it is not.
Thus, the square on {A magnitude} does not have to the [square] on the {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.

So, again, let the square on {A magnitude} not have to the [square] on {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
I say that {A magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {B magnitude}.

For if {A magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with {B magnitude} then the (square) on {A magnitude} will have to the (square) on {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
But it does not have (such a ratio).
Thus, {A magnitude} is not commensurable in length with {B magnitude}.

Thus, (squares) on (straight-lines which are) commensurable in length, and so on ....

Corollary

And it will be clear, from (what) has been demonstrated, that (straight-lines) commensurable in length (are) always also (commensurable) in square, but (straight-lines commensurable) in square (are) not always also (commensurable) in length.

title: Proposition 10
prose:
To find two straight-lines incommensurable with a given straight-line, the one (incommensurable) in length only, the other also (incommensurable) in square.

Let {A magnitude} be the given straight-line.
So it is required to find two straight-lines incommensurable with {A magnitude}, the one (incommensurable) in length only, the other also (incommensurable) in square.

For let two numbers, {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}, not having to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number---that is to say, not (being) similar plane (numbers)---have been taken.
And let it be contrived that as {B magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so the square on {A magnitude} (is) to the square on {D magnitude}.
For we learned (how to do this) [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And since {B magnitude} does not have to {C magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {A magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {D magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {A magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Let the (straight-line) {E magnitude} (which is) in mean proportion to {A magnitude} and {D magnitude} have been taken [Prop. 6.13].
Thus, as {A magnitude} is to {D magnitude}, so the square on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {E magnitude} [Def. 5.9].
And {A magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {D magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {A magnitude} is also incommensurable with the square on {E magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
Thus, {A magnitude} is incommensurable in square with {E magnitude}.

Thus, two straight-lines, {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}, (which are) incommensurable with the given straight-line {A magnitude}, have been found, the one, {D magnitude}, (incommensurable) in length only, the other, {E magnitude}, (incommensurable) in square, and, clearly, also in length.
[(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.]

title: Proposition 11
prose:
If four magnitudes are proportional, and the first is commensurable with the second, then the third will also be commensurable with the fourth.
And if the first is incommensurable with the second, then the third will also be incommensurable with the fourth.

Let {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}, {D magnitude} be four proportional magnitudes, (such that) as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
And let {A magnitude} be commensurable with {B magnitude}.
I say that {C magnitude} will also be commensurable with {D magnitude}.

For since {A magnitude} is commensurable with {B magnitude}, {A magnitude} thus has to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.5].
And as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} also has to {D magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.
Thus, {C magnitude} is commensurable with {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].

And so let {A magnitude} be incommensurable with {B magnitude}.
I say that {C magnitude} will also be incommensurable with {D magnitude}.
For since {A magnitude} is incommensurable with {B magnitude}, {A magnitude} thus does not have to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.7].
And as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} does not have to {D magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number either.
Thus, {C magnitude} is incommensurable with {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.8].

Thus, if four magnitudes, and so on ....

title: Proposition 12
prose:
(Magnitudes) commensurable with the same magnitude are also commensurable with one another.

For let {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} each be commensurable with {C magnitude}.
I say that {A magnitude} is also commensurable with {B magnitude}.

For since {A magnitude} is commensurable with {C magnitude}, {A magnitude} thus has to {C magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.5].
Let it have (the ratio) which {D magnitude} (has) to {E magnitude}.
Again, since {C magnitude} is commensurable with {B magnitude}, {C magnitude} thus has to {B magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number [Prop. 10.5].
Let it have (the ratio) which {F magnitude} (has) to {G magnitude}.
And for any multitude whatsoever of given ratios---(namely,) those which {D magnitude} has to {E magnitude}, and {F magnitude} to {G magnitude}---let the numbers {H magnitude}, {K magnitude}, {L magnitude} (which are) continuously (proportional) in the(se) given ratios have been taken [Prop. 8.4].
Hence, as {D magnitude} is to {E magnitude}, so {H magnitude} (is) to {K magnitude}, and as {F magnitude} (is) to {G magnitude}, so {K magnitude} (is) to {L magnitude}.

Therefore, since as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, but as {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, so {H magnitude} (is) to {K magnitude}, thus also as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, so {H magnitude} (is) to {K magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
Again, since as {C magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {F magnitude} (is) to {G magnitude}, but as {F magnitude} (is) to {G magnitude}, [so] {K magnitude} (is) to {L magnitude}, thus also as {C magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {K magnitude} (is) to {L magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
And also as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, so {H magnitude} (is) to {K magnitude}.
Thus, via equality, as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {H magnitude} (is) to {L magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
Thus, {A magnitude} has to {B magnitude} the ratio which the number {H magnitude} (has) to the number {L magnitude}.
Thus, {A magnitude} is commensurable with {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].

Thus, (magnitudes) commensurable with the same magnitude are also commensurable with one another.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 13
prose:
If two magnitudes are commensurable, and one of them is incommensurable with some magnitude, then the remaining (magnitude) will also be incommensurable with it.

Let {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} be two commensurable magnitudes, and let one of them, {A magnitude}, be incommensurable with some other (magnitude), {C magnitude}.
I say that the remaining (magnitude), {B magnitude}, is also incommensurable with {C magnitude}.

For if {B magnitude} is commensurable with {C magnitude}, but {A magnitude} is also commensurable with {B magnitude}, {A magnitude} is thus also commensurable with {C magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
But, (it is) also incommensurable (with {C magnitude}).
The very thing (is) impossible.
Thus, {B magnitude} is not commensurable with {C magnitude}.
Thus, (it is) incommensurable.

Thus, if two magnitudes are commensurable, and so on ....

title: Lemma
prose:
For two given unequal straight-lines, to find (the straight-line) by (the square on) which the square on the greater (straight-line is) larger than (the square on) the lesser.

Let {AB line} and {C magnitude} be the two given unequal straight-lines, and let {AB line} be the greater of them.
So it is required to find (straight-line) by (the square on) which the square on {AB line} (is) greater than (the square on) {C magnitude}.

Let the semi-circle {ADB arc O} have been described on {AB line}.
And let {AD line}, equal to {C magnitude}, have been inserted into it [Prop. 4.1].
And let {DB line} have been joined.
So (it is) clear that the angle {ADB angle} is a right-angle [Prop. 3.31], and that the square on {AB line} (is) greater than (the square on) {AD line}---that is to say, (the square on) {C magnitude}---by (the square on) {DB line} [Prop. 1.47].

And, similarly, the square-root of (the sum of the squares on) two given straight-lines is also found likeso.

Let {AD line} and {DB line} be the two given straight-lines.
And let it be necessary to find the square-root of (the sum of the squares on) them.
For let them have been laid down such as to encompass a right-angle---(namely), that (angle encompassed) by {AD line} and {DB line}.
And let {AB line} have been joined.
(It is) again clear that {AB line} is the square-root of (the sum of the squares on) {AD line} and {DB line} [Prop. 1.47].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 14
prose:
If four straight-lines are proportional, and the square on the first is greater than (the square on) the second by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable [in length] with the first, then the square on the third will also be greater than (the square on) the fourth by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable [in length] with the third.
And if the square on the first is greater than (the square on) the second by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable [in length] with the first, then the square on the third will also be greater than (the square on) the fourth by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable [in length] with the third.

Let {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, {C magnitude}, {D magnitude} be four proportional straight-lines, (such that) as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
And let the square on {A magnitude} be greater than (the square on) {B magnitude} by the (square) on {E magnitude}, and let the square on {C magnitude} be greater than (the square on) {D magnitude} by the (square) on {F magnitude}.
I say that {A magnitude} is either commensurable (in length) with {E magnitude}, and {C magnitude} is also commensurable with {F magnitude}, or {A magnitude} is incommensurable (in length) with {E magnitude}, and {C magnitude} is also incommensurable with {F magnitude}.

For since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, thus as the (square) on {A magnitude} is to the (square) on {B magnitude}, so the (square) on {C magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {D magnitude} [Prop. 6.22].
But the (sum of the squares) on {E magnitude} and {B magnitude} is equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}, and the (sum of the squares) on {D magnitude} and {F magnitude} is equal to the (square) on {C magnitude}.
Thus, as the (sum of the squares) on {E magnitude} and {B magnitude} is to the (square) on {B magnitude}, so the (sum of the squares) on {D magnitude} and {F magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {D magnitude}.
Thus, via separation, as the (square) on {E magnitude} is to the (square) on {B magnitude}, so the (square) on {F magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {D magnitude} [Prop. 5.17].
Thus, also, as {E magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {F magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude} [Prop. 6.22].
Thus, inversely, as {B magnitude} is to {E magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to {F magnitude} [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
But, as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} also (is) to {D magnitude}.
Thus, via equality, as {A magnitude} is to {E magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {F magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
Therefore, {A magnitude} is either commensurable (in length) with {E magnitude}, and {C magnitude} is also commensurable with {F magnitude}, or {A magnitude} is incommensurable (in length) with {E magnitude}, and {C magnitude} is also incommensurable with {F magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].

Thus, if, and so on ....

title: Proposition 15
prose:
If two commensurable magnitudes are added together then the whole will also be commensurable with each of them.
And if the whole is commensurable with one of them then the original magnitudes will also be commensurable (with one another).

For let the two commensurable magnitudes {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} be laid down together.
I say that the whole {AC magnitude} is also commensurable with each of {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.

For since {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are commensurable, some magnitude will measure them.
Let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {D magnitude}.
Therefore, since {D magnitude} measures (both) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, it will also measure the whole {AC magnitude}.
And it also measures {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} measures {AB magnitude}, {BC magnitude}, and {AC magnitude}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is commensurable with each of {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Def. 10.1].

And so let {AC magnitude} be commensurable with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are also commensurable.

For since {AC magnitude} and {AB magnitude} are commensurable, some magnitude will measure them.
Let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {D magnitude}.
Therefore, since {D magnitude} measures (both) {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude}, it will thus also measure the remainder {BC magnitude}.
And it also measures {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} will measure (both) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are commensurable [Def. 10.1].

Thus, if two magnitudes, and so on ....

title: Proposition 16
prose:
If two incommensurable magnitudes are added together then the whole will also be incommensurable with each of them.
And if the whole is incommensurable with one of them then the original magnitudes will also be incommensurable (with one another).

For let the two incommensurable magnitudes {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} be laid down together.
I say that that the whole {AC magnitude} is also incommensurable with each of {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.

For if {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude} are not incommensurable then some magnitude will measure [them].
If possible, let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {D magnitude}.
Therefore, since {D magnitude} measures (both) {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude}, it will thus also measure the remainder {BC magnitude}.
And it also measures {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} measures (both) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are commensurable [Def. 10.1].
But they were also assumed (to be) incommensurable.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, some magnitude cannot measure (both) {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude} are incommensurable [Def. 10.1].
So, similarly, we can show that {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are also incommensurable.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is incommensurable with each of {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.

And so let {AC magnitude} be incommensurable with one of {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
So let it, first of all, be incommensurable with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are also incommensurable.
For if they are commensurable then some magnitude will measure them.
Let it (so) measure (them), and let it be {D magnitude}.
Therefore, since {D magnitude} measures (both) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, it will thus also measure the whole {AC magnitude}.
And it also measures {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} measures (both) {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {CA magnitude} and {AB magnitude} are commensurable [Def. 10.1].
But they were also assumed (to be) incommensurable.
The very thing is impossible.
Thus, some magnitude cannot measure (both) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are incommensurable [Def. 10.1].

Thus, if two...magnitudes, and so on ....

title: Lemma
prose:
If a parallelogram, falling short by a square figure, is applied to some straight-line then the applied (parallelogram) is equal (in area) to the (rectangle contained) by the pieces of the straight-line created via the application (of the parallelogram).

For let the parallelogram {AD polygon}, falling short by the square figure {DB polygon}, have been applied to the straight-line {AB line}.
I say that {AD polygon} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AC line} and {CB line}.

And it is immediately obvious.
For since {DB polygon} is a square, {DC line} is equal to {CB line}.
And {AD polygon} is the (rectangle contained) by {AC line} and {CD line}---that is to say, by {AC line} and {CB line}.

Thus, if ...to some straight-line, and so on ....

title: Proposition 17
prose:
If there are two unequal straight-lines, and a (rectangle) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, and divides it into (parts which are) commensurable in length, then the square on the greater will be larger than (the square on) the lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable [in length] with the greater.
And if the square on the greater is larger than (the square on) the lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable [in length] with the greater, and a (rectangle) equal to the fourth (part) of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, then it divides it into (parts which are) commensurable in length.

Let {A magnitude} and {BC magnitude} be two unequal straight-lines, of which (let) {BC magnitude} (be) the greater.
And let a (rectangle) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser, {A magnitude}---that is, (equal) to the (square) on half of {A magnitude}---falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {BC magnitude}.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [see previous lemma].
And let {BD magnitude} be commensurable in length with {DC magnitude}.
I say that that the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by (the square on some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).

For let {BC magnitude} have been cut in half at the point {E point} [Prop. 1.10].
And let {EF magnitude} be made equal to {DE magnitude} [Prop. 1.3].
Thus, the remainder {DC magnitude} is equal to {BF magnitude}.
And since the straight-line {BC magnitude} has been cut into equal (pieces) at {E point}, and into unequal (pieces) at {D point}, the rectangle contained by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}, plus the square on {ED magnitude}, is thus equal to the square on {EC magnitude} [Prop. 2.5].
(The same) also (for) the quadruples.
Thus, four times the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}, plus the quadruple of the (square) on {DE magnitude}, is equal to four times the square on {EC magnitude}.
But, the square on {A magnitude} is equal to the quadruple of the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}, and the square on {DF magnitude} is equal to the quadruple of the (square) on {DE magnitude}.
For {DF magnitude} is double {DE magnitude}.
And the square on {BC magnitude} is equal to the quadruple of the (square) on {EC magnitude}.
For, again, {BC magnitude} is double {CE magnitude}.
Thus, the (sum of the) squares on {A magnitude} and {DF magnitude} is equal to the square on {BC magnitude}.
Hence, the (square) on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {A magnitude} by the (square) on {DF magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is greater in square than {A magnitude} by {DF magnitude}.
It must also be shown that {BC magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with {DF magnitude}.
For since {BD magnitude} is commensurable in length with {DC magnitude}, {BC magnitude} is thus also commensurable in length with {CD magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
But, {CD magnitude} is commensurable in length with {CD magnitude} plus {BF magnitude}.
For {CD magnitude} is equal to {BF magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, {BC magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {BF magnitude} plus {CD magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
Hence, {BC magnitude} is also commensurable in length with the remainder {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
Thus, the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).

And so let the square on {BC magnitude} be greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).
And let a (rectangle) equal to the fourth (part) of the (square) on {A magnitude}, falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {BC magnitude}.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}.
It must be shown that {BD magnitude} is commensurable in length with {DC magnitude}.

For, similarly, by the same construction, we can show that the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on {FD magnitude}.
And the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).
Thus, {BC magnitude} is commensurable in length with {FD magnitude}.
Hence, {BC magnitude} is also commensurable in length with the remaining sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
But, the sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} is commensurable [in length] with {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Hence, {BC magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {CD magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
Thus, via separation, {BD magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].

Thus, if there are two unequal straight-lines, and so on ....

title: Proposition 18
prose:
If there are two unequal straight-lines, and a (rectangle) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, and divides it into (parts which are) incommensurable [in length], then the square on the greater will be larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with the greater.
And if the square on the greater is larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with the greater, and a (rectangle) equal to the fourth (part) of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, then it divides it into (parts which are) incommensurable [in length].

Let {A magnitude} and {BC magnitude} be two unequal straight-lines, of which (let) {BC magnitude} (be) the greater.
And let a (rectangle) equal to the fourth [part] of the (square) on the lesser, {A magnitude}, falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {BC magnitude}.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}.
And let {BD magnitude} be incommensurable in length with {DC magnitude}.
I say that that the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).

For, similarly, by the same construction as before, we can show that the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on {FD magnitude}.
[Therefore] it must be shown that {BC magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {DF magnitude}.
For since {BD magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {DC magnitude}, {BC magnitude} is thus also incommensurable in length with {CD magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
But, {DC magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And, thus, {BC magnitude} is incommensurable (in length) with the sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
Hence, {BC magnitude} is also incommensurable in length with the remainder {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
And the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on {FD magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).

So, again, let the square on {BC magnitude} be greater than the (square on) {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).
And let a (rectangle) equal to the fourth [part] of the (square) on {A magnitude}, falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {BC magnitude}.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {DC magnitude}.
It must be shown that {BD magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {DC magnitude}.

For, similarly, by the same construction, we can show that the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {A magnitude} by the (square) on {FD magnitude}.
But, the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {A magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}).
Thus, {BC magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FD magnitude}.
Hence, {BC magnitude} is also incommensurable (in length) with the remaining sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
But, the sum of {BF magnitude} and {DC magnitude} is commensurable in length with {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, {BC magnitude} is also incommensurable in length with {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
Hence, via separation, {BD magnitude} is also incommensurable in length with {DC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].

Thus, if there are two ... straight-lines, and so on ....

title: Proposition 19
prose:
The rectangle contained by rational straight-lines (which are) commensurable in length is rational.

For let the rectangle {AC polygon} have been enclosed by the rational straight-lines {AB line} and {BC line} (which are) commensurable in length.
I say that {AC polygon} is rational.

For let the square {AD polygon} have been described on {AB line}.
{AD polygon} is thus rational [Def. 10.4].
And since {AB line} is commensurable in length with {BC line}, and {AB line} is equal to {BD line}, {BD line} is thus commensurable in length with {BC line}.
And as {BD line} is to {BC line}, so {DA polygon} (is) to {AC polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {DA polygon} is commensurable with {AC polygon} [Prop. 10.11].
And {DA polygon} (is) rational.
Thus, {AC polygon} is also rational [Def. 10.4].
Thus, the ... by rational straight-lines ... commensurable, and so on ....

title: Proposition 20
prose:
If a rational (area) is applied to a rational (straightline) then it produces as breadth a (straight-line which is) rational, and commensurable in length with the (straightline) to which it is applied.

For let the rational (area) {AC polygon} have been applied to the rational (straight-line) {AB line}, producing the (straight-line) {BC line} as breadth.
I say that {BC line} is rational, and commensurable in length with {BA line}.

For let the square {AD polygon} have been described on {AB line}.
{AD polygon} is thus rational [Def. 10.4].
And {AC polygon} (is) also rational.
{DA polygon} is thus commensurable with {AC polygon}.
And as {DA polygon} is to {AC polygon}, so {DB line} (is) to {BC line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {DB line} is also commensurable (in length) with {BC line} [Prop. 10.11].
And {DB line} (is) equal to {BA line}.
Thus, {AB line} (is) also commensurable (in length) with {BC line}.
And {AB line} is rational.
Thus, {BC line} is also rational, and commensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.3].

Thus, if a rational (area) is applied to a rational (straight-line), and so on ....

title: Proposition 21
prose:
The rectangle contained by rational straight-lines (which are) commensurable in square only is irrational, and its square-root is irrational---let it be called medial.

For let the rectangle {AC polygon} be contained by the rational straight-lines {AB line} and {BC line} (which are) commensurable in square only.
I say that {AC polygon} is irrational, and its square-root is irrational---let it be called medial.

For let the square {AD polygon} have been described on {AB line}.
{AD polygon} is thus rational [Def. 10.4].
And since {AB line} is incommensurable in length with {BC line}.
For they were assumed to be commensurable in square only.
And {AB line} (is) equal to {BD line}.
{DB line} is thus also incommensurable in length with {BC line}.
And as {DB line} is to {BC line}, so {AD polygon} (is) to {AC polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {DA polygon} [is] incommensurable with {AC polygon} [Prop. 10.11].
And {DA polygon} (is) rational.
Thus, {AC polygon} is irrational [Def. 10.4].
Hence, its square-root [that is to say, the square-root of the square equal to it] is also irrational [Def. 10.4]---let it be called medial.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma
prose:
If there are two straight-lines then as the first is to the second, so the (square) on the first (is) to the (rectangle contained) by the two straight-lines.

Let {FE line} and {EG line} be two straight-lines.
I say that as {FE line} is to {EG line}, so the (square) on {FE line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line}.

For let the square {DF polygon} have been described on {FE line}.
And let {GD polygon} have been completed.
Therefore, since as {FE line} is to {EG line}, so {FD polygon} (is) to {DG polygon} [Prop. 6.1], and {FD polygon} is the (square) on {FE line}, and {DG polygon} the (rectangle contained) by {DE line} and {EG line}---that is to say, the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line}---thus as {FE line} is to {EG line}, so the (square) on {FE line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line}.
And also, similarly, as the (rectangle contained) by {GE line} and {EF line} is to the (square on) {EF line}---that is to say, as {GD polygon} (is) to {FD polygon}---so {GE line} (is) to {EF line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 22
prose:
The square on a medial (straight-line), being applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a (straight-line which is) rational, and incommensurable in length with the (straight-line) to which it is applied.

Let {A magnitude} be a medial (straight-line), and {CB line} a rational (straight-line), and let the rectangular area {BD polygon}, equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}, have been applied to {BC line}, producing {CD line} as breadth.
I say that {CD line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CB line}.

For since {A magnitude} is medial, the square on it is equal to a (rectangular) area contained by rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.21].
Let the square on ({A magnitude}) be equal to {GF polygon}.
And the square on ({A magnitude}) is also equal to {BD polygon}.
Thus, {BD polygon} is equal to {GF polygon}.
And ({BD polygon}) is also equiangular with ({GF polygon}).
And for equal and equiangular parallelograms, the sides about the equal angles are reciprocally proportional [Prop. 6.14].
Thus, proportionally, as {BC line} is to {EG line}, so {EF line} (is) to {CD line}.
And, also, as the (square) on {BC line} is to the (square) on {EG line}, so the (square) on {EF line} (is) to the (square) on {CD line} [Prop. 6.22].
And the (square) on {CB line} is commensurable with the (square) on {EG line}.
For they are each rational.
Thus, the (square) on {EF line} is also commensurable with the (square) on {CD line} [Prop. 10.11].
And the (square) on {EF line} is rational.
Thus, the (square) on {CD line} is also rational [Def. 10.4].
Thus, {CD line} is rational.
And since {EF line} is incommensurable in length with {EG line}.
For they are commensurable in square only.
And as {EF line} (is) to {EG line}, so the (square) on {EF line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line} [see previous lemma].
The (square) on {EF line} [is] thus incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line} [Prop. 10.11].
But, the (square) on {CD line} is commensurable with the (square) on {EF line}.
For they are rational in square.
And the (rectangle contained) by {DC line} and {CB line} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {FE line} and {EG line}.
For they are (both) equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {CD line} is also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {DC line} and {CB line} [Prop. 10.13].
And as the (square) on {CD line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {DC line} and {CB line}, so {DC line} is to {CB line} [see previous lemma].
Thus, {DC line} is incommensurable in length with {CB line} [Prop. 10.11].
Thus, {CD line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CB line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 23
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable with a medial (straight-line) is medial.

Let {A magnitude} be a medial (straight-line), and let {B magnitude} be commensurable with {A magnitude}.
I say that {B magnitude} is also a medial (staight-line).

Let the rational (straight-line) {CD line} be set out, and let the rectangular area {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {ED line} as width.
{ED line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And let the rectangular area {CF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {B magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {DF line} as width.
Therefore, since {A magnitude} is commensurable with {B magnitude}, the (square) on {A magnitude} is also commensurable with the (square) on {B magnitude}.
But, {EC polygon} is equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}, and {CF polygon} is equal to the (square) on {B magnitude}.
Thus, {EC polygon} is commensurable with {CF polygon}.
And as {EC polygon} is to {CF polygon}, so {ED line} (is) to {DF line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {ED line} is commensurable in length with {DF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And {ED line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line}.
{DF line} is thus also rational [Def. 10.3], and incommensurable in length with {DC line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {CD line} and {DF line} are rational, and commensurable in square only.
And the square-root of a (rectangle contained) by rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only is medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, the square-root of the (rectangle contained) by {CD line} and {DF line} is medial.
And the square on {B magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {CD line} and {DF line}.
Thus, {B magnitude} is a medial (straight-line).

Corollary

And (it is) clear, from this, that an (area) commensurable with a medial area is medial.

title: Proposition 24
prose:
A rectangle contained by medial straight-lines (which are) commensurable in length is medial.

For let the rectangle {AC polygon} be contained by the medial straight-lines {AB line} and {BC line} (which are) commensurable in length.
I say that {AC polygon} is medial.

For let the square {AD polygon} have been described on {AB line}.
{AD polygon} is thus medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
And since {AB line} is commensurable in length with {BC line}, and {AB line} (is) equal to {BD line}, {DB line} is thus also commensurable in length with {BC line}.
Hence, {DA polygon} is also commensurable with {AC polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And {DA polygon} (is) medial.
Thus, {AC polygon} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 25
prose:
The rectangle contained by medial straight-lines (which are) commensurable in square only is either rational or medial.

For let the rectangle {AC polygon} be contained by the medial straight-lines {AB line} and {BC line} (which are) commensurable in square only.
I say that {AC polygon} is either rational or medial.

For let the squares {AD polygon} and {BE polygon} have been described on (the straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line} (respectively).
{AD polygon} and {BE polygon} are thus each medial.
And let the rational (straight-line) {FG line} be laid out.
And let the rectangular parallelogram {GH polygon}, equal to {AD polygon}, have been applied to {FG line}, producing {FH line} as breadth.
And let the rectangular parallelogram {MK polygon}, equal to {AC polygon}, have been applied to {HM line}, producing {HK line} as breadth.
And, finally, let {NL polygon}, equal to {BE polygon}, have similarly been applied to {KN line}, producing {KL line} as breadth.
Thus, {FH line}, {HK line}, and {KL line} are in a straight-line.
Therefore, since {AD polygon} and {BE polygon} are each medial, and {AD polygon} is equal to {GH polygon}, and {BE polygon} to {NL polygon}, {GH polygon} and {NL polygon} (are) thus each also medial.
And they are applied to the rational (straight-line) {FG line}.
{FH line} and {KL line} are thus each rational, and incommensurable in length with {FG line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {AD polygon} is commensurable with {BE polygon}, {GH polygon} is thus also commensurable with {NL polygon}.
And as {GH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {FH line} (is) to {KL line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {FH line} is commensurable in length with {KL line} [Prop. 10.11].
Thus, {FH line} and {KL line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in length.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {FH line} and {KL line} is rational [Prop. 10.19].
And since {DB line} is equal to {BA line}, and {OB line} to {BC line}, thus as {DB line} is to {BC line}, so {AB line} (is) to {BO line}.
But, as {DB line} (is) to {BC line}, so {DA polygon} (is) to {AC polygon} [Props. 6.1].
And as {AB line} (is) to {BO line}, so {AC polygon} (is) to {CO polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, as {DA polygon} is to {AC polygon}, so {AC polygon} (is) to {CO polygon}.
And {AD polygon} is equal to {GH polygon}, and {AC polygon} to {MK polygon}, and {CO polygon}  to {NL polygon}.
Thus, as {GH polygon} is to {MK polygon}, so {MK polygon} (is) to {NL polygon}.
Thus, also, as {FH line} is to {HK line}, so {HK line} (is) to {KL line} [Props. 6.1, 5.11].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {FH line} and {KL line} is equal to the (square) on {HK line} [Prop. 6.17].
And the (rectangle contained) by {FH line} and {KL line} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {HK line} is also rational.
Thus, {HK line} is rational.
And if it is commensurable in length with {FG line} then {HN polygon} is rational [Prop. 10.19].
And if it is incommensurable in length with {FG line} then {KH line} and {HM line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only: thus, {HN polygon} is medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, {HN polygon} is either rational or medial.
And {HN polygon} (is) equal to {AC polygon}.
Thus, {AC polygon} is either rational or medial.

Thus, the ... by medial straight-lines (which are) commensurable in square only, and so on ....

title: Proposition 26
prose:
A medial (area) does not exceed a medial (area) by a rational (area).

For, if possible, let the medial (area) {AB polygon} exceed the medial (area) {AC polygon} by the rational (area) {DB polygon}.
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let the rectangular parallelogram {FH polygon}, equal to {AB polygon}, have been applied to to {EF line}, producing {EH line} as breadth.
And let {FG polygon}, equal to {AC polygon}, have been cut off (from {FH polygon}).
Thus, the remainder {BD polygon} is equal to the remainder {KH polygon}.
And {DB polygon} is rational.
Thus, {KH polygon} is also rational.
Therefore, since {AB polygon} and {AC polygon} are each medial, and {AB polygon} is equal to {FH polygon}, and {AC polygon} to {FG polygon}, {FH polygon} and {FG polygon} are thus each also medial.

And they are applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {HE line} and {EG line} are each rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {DB polygon} is rational, and is equal to {KH polygon}, {KH polygon} is thus also rational.
And ({KH polygon}) is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
{GH line} is thus rational, and commensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.20].
But, {EG line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line}.
Thus, {EG line} is incommensurable in length with {GH line} [Prop. 10.13].
And as {EG line} is to {GH line}, so the (square) on {EG line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Thus, the (square) on {EG line} is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line} [Prop. 10.11].
But, the (sum of the) squares on {EG line} and {GH line} is commensurable with the (square) on {EG line}.
For ({EG line} and {GH line} are) both rational.
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line} [Prop. 10.6].
For (the former) is double the latter.
Thus, the (sum of the squares) on {EG line} and {GH line} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line} [Prop. 10.13].
And thus the sum of the (squares) on {EG line} and {GH line} plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {EG line} and {GH line}, that is the (square) on {EH line} [Prop. 2.4], is incommensurable with the (sum of the squares) on {EG line} and {GH line} [Prop. 10.16].
And the (sum of the squares) on {EG line} and {GH line} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {EH line} is irrational [Def. 10.4].
Thus, {EH line} is irrational [Def. 10.4].
But, (it is) also rational.
The very thing is impossible.

Thus, a medial (area) does not exceed a medial (area) by a rational (area).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 27
prose:
To find (two) medial (straight-lines), containing a rational (area), (which are) commensurable in square only.

Let the two rational (straight-lines) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid down.
And let {C magnitude}---the mean proportional (straight-line) to {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}---have been taken [Prop. 6.13].
And let it be contrived that as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].

And since the rational (straight-lines) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are commensurable in square only, the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}---that is to say, the (square) on {C magnitude} [Prop. 6.17]---is thus medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, {C magnitude} is medial [Prop. 10.21].
And since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, [so] {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, and {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} [are] commensurable in square only, {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} are thus also commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And {C magnitude} is medial.
Thus, {D magnitude} is also medial [Prop. 10.23].
Thus, {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
I say that they also contain a rational (area).
For since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, thus, alternately, as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, so {B magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
But, as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, (so) {C magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}.
And thus as {C magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {B magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} is equal to the (square) on {B magnitude} [Prop. 6.17].
And the (square) on {B magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} [is] also rational.

Thus, (two) medial (straight-lines, {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}), containing a rational (area), (which are) commensurable in square only, have been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 28
prose:
To find (two) medial (straight-lines), containing a medial (area), (which are) commensurable in square only.

Let the [three] rational (straight-lines) {A magnitude}, {B magnitude}, and {C magnitude}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid down.
And let, {D magnitude}, the mean proportional (straight-line) to {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, have been taken [Prop. 6.13].
And let it be contrived that as {B magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, (so) {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].

Since the rational (straight-lines) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} are commensurable in square only, the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}---that is to say, the (square) on {D magnitude} [Prop. 6.17]---is medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, {D magnitude} (is) medial [Prop. 10.21].
And since {B magnitude} and {C magnitude} are commensurable in square only, and as {B magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, (so) {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} are thus commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And {D magnitude} (is) medial.
{E magnitude} (is) thus also medial [Prop. 10.23].
Thus, {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
So, I say that they also enclose a medial (area).
For since as {B magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, (so) {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, thus, alternately, as {B magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, (so) {C magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
And as {B magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, (so) {D magnitude} (is) to {A magnitude}.
And thus as {D magnitude} (is) to {A magnitude}, (so) {C magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {C magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} [Prop. 6.16].
And the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {C magnitude} is medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} (is) also medial.

Thus, (two) medial (straight-lines, {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}), containing a medial (area), (which are) commensurable in square only, have been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma I
prose:
To find two square numbers such that the sum of them is also square.

Let the two numbers {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} be laid down.
And let them be either (both) even or (both) odd.
And since, if an even (number) is subtracted from an even (number), or if an odd (number is subtracted) from an odd (number), then the remainder is even [Props. 9.24, 9.26], the remainder {AC magnitude} is thus even.
Let {AC magnitude} have been cut in half at {D magnitude}.
And let {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} also be either similar plane (numbers), or square (numbers)---which are themselves also similar plane (numbers).
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the square on {CD magnitude}, is equal to the square on {BD magnitude} [Prop. 2.6].
And the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is square---inasmuch as it was shown that if two similar plane (numbers) make some (number) by multiplying one another then the (number so) created is square [Prop. 9.1].
Thus, two square numbers have been found---(namely,) the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, and the (square) on {CD magnitude}---which, (when) added (together), make the square on {BD magnitude}.

And (it is) clear that two square (numbers) have again been found---(namely,) the (square) on {BD magnitude}, and the (square) on {CD magnitude}---such that their difference---(namely,) the (rectangle) contained by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}---is square whenever {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are similar plane (numbers).
But, when they are not similar plane numbers, two square (numbers) have been found---(namely,) the (square) on {BD magnitude}, and the (square) on {DC magnitude}---between which the difference---(namely,) the (rectangle) contained by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}---is not square.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma II
prose:
To find two square numbers such that the sum of them is not square.

For let the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, as we said, be square.
And (let) {CA magnitude} (be) even.
And let {CA magnitude} have been cut in half at {D magnitude}.
So it is clear that the square (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the square on {CD magnitude}, is equal to the square on {BD magnitude} [see previous lemma].
Let the unit {DE magnitude} have been subtracted (from {BD magnitude}).
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is less than the square on {BD magnitude}.
I say, therefore, that the square (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is not square.

For if it is square, it is either equal to the (square) on {BE magnitude}, or less than the (square) on {BE magnitude}, but cannot any more be greater (than the square on {BE magnitude}), lest the unit be divided.
First of all, if possible, let the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, be equal to the (square) on {BE magnitude}.
And let {GA magnitude} be double the unit {DE magnitude}.
Therefore, since the whole of {AC magnitude} is double the whole of {CD magnitude}, of which {AG magnitude} is double {DE magnitude}, the remainder {GC magnitude} is thus double the remainder {EC magnitude}.
Thus, {GC magnitude} has been cut in half at {E magnitude}.
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {GB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is equal to the square on {BE magnitude} [Prop. 2.6].
But, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, was also assumed (to be) equal to the square on {BE magnitude}.
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {GB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is equal to the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}.
And subtracting the (square) on {CE magnitude} from both, {AB magnitude} is inferred (to be) equal to {GB magnitude}.
The very thing is absurd.
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is not equal to the (square) on {BE magnitude}.
So I say that (it is) not less than the (square) on {BE magnitude} either.
For, if possible, let it be equal to the (square) on {BF magnitude}.
And (let) {HA magnitude} (be) double {DF magnitude}.
And it can again be inferred that {HC magnitude} (is) double {CF magnitude}.
Hence, {CH magnitude} has also been cut in half at {F magnitude}.
And, on account of this, the (number created) from (multiplying) {HB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {FC magnitude}, becomes equal to the (square) on {BF magnitude} [Prop. 2.6].
And the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, was also assumed (to be) equal to the (square) on {BF magnitude}.
Hence, the (number created) from (multiplying) {HB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CF magnitude}, will also be equal to the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}.
The very thing is absurd.
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CE magnitude}, is not less than the (square) on {BE magnitude}.
And it was shown that (is it) not equal to the (square) on {BE magnitude} either.
Thus, the (number created) from (multiplying) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus the square on {CE magnitude}, is not square.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 29
prose:
To find two rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, such that the square on the greater is larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) commensurable in length with the greater.

For let some rational (straight-line) {AB line} be laid down, and two square numbers, {CD magnitude} and {DE magnitude}, such that the difference between them, {CE magnitude}, is not square [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let the semi-circle {AFB arc O} have been drawn on {AB line}.
And let it be contrived that as {DC magnitude} (is) to {CE magnitude}, so the square on {BA line} (is) to the square on {AF line} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
And let {FB line} have been joined.

[Therefore,] since as the (square) on {BA line} is to the (square) on {AF line}, so {DC magnitude} (is) to {CE magnitude}, the (square) on {BA line} thus has to the (square) on {AF line} the ratio which the number {DC magnitude} (has) to the number {CE magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {BA line} is commensurable with the (square) on {AF line} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {AB line} (is) rational [Def. 10.4].
Thus, the (square) on {AF line} (is) also rational.
Thus, {AF line} (is) also rational.
And since {DC magnitude} does not have to {CE magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {BA line} thus does not have to the (square) on {AF line} the ratio which (some) square number has to (some) square number either.
Thus, {AB line} is incommensurable in length with {AF line} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, the rational (straight-lines) {BA line} and {AF line} are commensurable in square only.
And since as {DC magnitude} [is] to {CE magnitude}, so the (square) on {BA line} (is) to the (square) on {AF line}, thus, via conversion, as {CD magnitude} (is) to {DE magnitude}, so the (square) on {AB line} (is) to the (square) on {BF line} [Props. 5.19 corr., 3.31, 1.47].
And {CD magnitude} has to {DE magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {AB line} also has to the (square) on {BF line} the ratio which (some) square number has to (some) square number.
{AB line} is thus commensurable in length with {BF line} [Prop. 10.9].
And the (square) on {AB line} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AF line} and {FB line} [Prop. 1.47].
Thus, the square on {AB line} is greater than (the square on) {AF line} by (the square on) {BF line}, (which is) commensurable (in length) with ({AB line}).

Thus, two rational (straight-lines), {BA line} and {AF line}, commensurable in square only, have been found such that the square on the greater, {AB line}, is larger than (the square on) the lesser, {AF line}, by the (square) on {BF line}, (which is) commensurable in length with ({AB line}).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 30
prose:
To find two rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, such that the square on the greater is larger than the (the square on) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) incommensurable in length with the greater.

Let the rational (straight-line) {AB line} be laid out, and the two square numbers, {CE magnitude} and {ED magnitude}, such that the sum of them, {CD magnitude}, is not square [Prop. 10.28 lem. II].
And let the semi-circle {AFB arc O} have been drawn on {AB line}.
And let it be contrived that as {DC magnitude} (is) to {CE magnitude}, so the (square) on {BA line} (is) to the (square) on {AF line} [Prop. 10.6 corr].
And let {FB line} have been joined.

So, similarly to the (proposition) before this, we can show that {BA line} and {AF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
