And since as {DC magnitude} is to {CE magnitude}, so the (square) on {BA line} (is) to the (square) on {AF line}, thus, via conversion, as {CD magnitude} (is) to {DE magnitude}, so the (square) on {AB line} (is) to the (square) on {BF line} [Props. 5.19 corr., 3.31, 1.47].
And {CD magnitude} does not have to {DE magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.

Thus, the (square) on {AB line} does not have to the (square) on {BF line} the ratio which (some) square number has to (some) square number either.
Thus, {AB line} is incommensurable in length with {BF line} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {AB line} is greater than the (square on) {AF line} by the (square) on {FB line} [Prop. 1.47], (which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}).

Thus, {AB line} and {AF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {AB line} is greater than (the square on) {AF line} by the (square) on {FB line}, (which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 31
prose:
To find two medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a rational (area), such that the square on the greater is larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with the greater.

Let two rational (straight-lines), {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, commensurable in square only, be laid out, such that the square on the greater {A magnitude} is larger than the (square on the) lesser {B magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({A magnitude}) [Prop. 10.29].
And let the (square) on {C magnitude} be equal to the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
And the (rectangle contained by) {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} (is) medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, the (square) on {C magnitude} (is) also medial.
Thus, {C magnitude} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.21].
And let the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {B magnitude}.
And the (square) on {B magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus,the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} (is) also rational.
And since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, so the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {B magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], but the (square) on {C magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude} to the (square) on {B magnitude}, thus as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so the (square) on {C magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}.
And as the (square) on {C magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.].
And thus as {A magnitude} (is) to {B magnitude}, so {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}.
And {A magnitude} is commensurable in square only with {B magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} (is) also commensurable in square only with {D magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And {C magnitude} is medial.
Thus, {D magnitude} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23].
And since as {A magnitude} is to {B magnitude}, (so) {C magnitude} (is) to {D magnitude}, and the square on {A magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {B magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({A magnitude}), the square on {C magnitude} is thus also greater than (the square on) {D magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({C magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].

Thus, two medial (straight-lines), {C magnitude} and {D magnitude}, commensurable in square only, (and) containing a rational (area), have been found.
And the square on {C magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {D magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({C magnitude}).

So, similarly, (the proposition) can also be demonstrated for (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with {C magnitude}), provided that the square on {A magnitude} is greater than (the square on {B magnitude}) by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({A magnitude}) [Prop. 10.30].

title: Proposition 32
prose:
To find two medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a medial (area), such that the square on the greater is larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with the greater.

Let three rational (straight-lines), {A magnitude}, {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}, commensurable in square only, be laid out such that the square on {A magnitude} is greater than (the square on {C magnitude}) by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({A magnitude}) [Prop. 10.29].
And let the (square) on {D magnitude} be equal to the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {D magnitude} (is) medial.
Thus, {D magnitude} is also medial [Prop. 10.21].
And let the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} be equal to the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}.
And since as the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude} is to the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}, so {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], but the (square) on {D magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {A magnitude} and {B magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} to the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}, thus as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, so the (square) on {D magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}.
And as the (square) on {D magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.].
And thus as {A magnitude} (is) to {C magnitude}, so {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}.
And {A magnitude} (is) commensurable in square [only] with {C magnitude}.
Thus, {D magnitude} (is) also commensurable in square only with {E magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And {D magnitude} (is) medial.
Thus, {E magnitude} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23].
And since as {A magnitude} is to {C magnitude}, (so) {D magnitude} (is) to {E magnitude}, and the square on {A magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {C magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({A magnitude}), the square on {D magnitude} will thus also be greater than (the square on) {E magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({D magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
So, I also say that the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} is medial.
For since the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude} (is) medial [for {B magnitude} and {C magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only] [Prop. 10.21], the (rectangle contained) by {D magnitude} and {E magnitude} (is) thus also medial.

Thus, two medial (straight-lines), {D magnitude} and {E magnitude}, commensurable in square only, (and) containing a medial (area), have been found such that the square on the greater is larger than the (square on the) lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with the greater.

So, similarly, (the proposition) can again also be demonstrated for (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with the greater), provided that the square on {A magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {C magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({A magnitude}) [Prop. 10.30].

title: Lemma
prose:
Let {ABC polygon} be a right-angled triangle having the (angle) {A point} a right-angle.
And let the perpendicular {AD line} have been drawn.
I say that the (rectangle contained) by {CB line} and {BD line} is equal to the (square) on {BA line}, and the (rectangle contained) by {BC line} and {CD line} (is) equal to the (square) on {CA line}, and the (rectangle contained) by {BD line} and {DC line} (is) equal to the (square) on {AD line}, and, further, the (rectangle contained) by {BC line} and {AD line} [is] equal to the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AC line}.

And, first of all, (let us prove) that the (rectangle contained) by {CB line} and {BD line} [is] equal to the (square) on {BA line}.

For since {AD line} has been drawn from the right-angle in a right-angled triangle, perpendicular to the base, {ABD polygon} and {ADC polygon} are thus triangles (which are) similar to the whole, {ABC polygon}, and to one another [Prop. 6.8].
And since triangle {ABC polygon} is similar to triangle {ABD polygon}, thus as {CB line} is to {BA line}, so {BA line} (is) to {BD line} [Prop. 6.4].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CB line} and {BD line} is equal to the (square) on {AB line} [Prop. 6.17].

So, for the same (reasons), the (rectangle contained) by {BC line} and {CD line} is also equal to the (square) on {AC line}.

And since if a (straight-line) is drawn from the rightangle in a right-angled triangle, perpendicular to the base, the (straight-line so) drawn is the mean proportional to the pieces of the base [Prop. 6.8 corr.], thus as {BD line} is to {DA line}, so {AD line} (is) to {DC line}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {BD line} and {DC line} is equal to the (square) on {DA line} [Prop. 6.17].

I also say that the (rectangle contained) by {BC line} and {AD line} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AC line}.
For since, as we said, {ABC polygon} is similar to {ABD polygon}, thus as {BC line} is to {CA line}, so {BA line} (is) to {AD line} [Prop. 6.4].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {BC line} and {AD line} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AC line} [Prop. 6.16].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 33
prose:
To find two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial.

Let the two rational (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid out such that the square on the greater, {AB line}, is larger than (the square on) the lesser, {BC line}, by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}) [Prop. 10.30].
And let {BC line} have been cut in half at {D point}.
And let a parallelogram equal to the (square) on either of {BD line} or {DC line}, (and) falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {AB line} [Prop. 6.28], and let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AE line} and {EB line}.
And let the semi-circle {AFB arc O} have been drawn on {AB line}.
And let {EF line} have been drawn at right-angles to {AB line}.
And let {AF line} and {FB line} have been joined.

And since {AB line} and {BC line} are [two] unequal straightlines, and the square on {AB line} is greater than (the square on) {BC line} by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}).
And a parallelogram, equal to one quarter of the (square) on {BC line}---that is to say, (equal) to the (square) on half of it---(and) falling short by a square figure, has been applied to {AB line}, and makes the (rectangle contained) by {AE line} and {EB line}.
{AE line} is thus incommensurable (in length) with {EB line} [Prop. 10.18].
And as {AE line} is to {EB line}, so the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AE line} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BE line}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AE line} (is) equal to the (square) on {AF line}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BE line} to the (square) on {BF line} [Prop. 10.32 lem.].
The (square) on {AF line} is thus incommensurable with the (square) on {FB line} [Prop. 10.11].
Thus, {AF line} and {FB line} are incommensurable in square.
And since {AB line} is rational, the (square) on {AB line} is also rational.
Hence, the sum of the (squares) on {AF line} and {FB line} is also rational [Prop. 1.47].
And, again, since the (rectangle contained) by {AE line} and {EB line} is equal to the (square) on {EF line}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AE line} and {EB line} was assumed (to be) equal to the (square) on {BD line}, {FE line} is thus equal to {BD line}.
Thus, {BC line} is double {FE line}.
And hence the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {EF line} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} (is) medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {EF line} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {EF line} (is) equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FB line} [Prop. 10.32 lem.].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FB line} (is) also medial.
And the sum of the squares on them was also shown (to be) rational.

Thus, the two straight-lines, {AF line} and {FB line}, (which are) incommensurable in square, have been found, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 34
prose:
To find two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational.

Let the two medial (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid out having the (rectangle contained) by them rational, (and) such that the square on {AB line} is greater than (the square on) {BC line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}) [Prop. 10.31].
And let the semi-circle {ADB arc O} have been drawn on {AB line}.
And let {BC line} have been cut in half at {E point}.
And let a (rectangular) parallelogram equal to the (square) on {BE line}, (and) falling short by a square figure, have been applied to {AB line}, (and let it be) the (rectangle contained by) {AF line} and {FB line} [Prop. 6.28].
Thus, {AF line} [is] incommensurable in length with {FB line} [Prop. 10.18].
And let {FD line} have been drawn from {F point} at right-angles to {AB line}.
And let {AD line} and {DB line} have been joined.

Since {AF line} is incommensurable (in length) with {FB line}, the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AF line} is thus also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And the (rectangle contained) by {BA line} and {AF line} (is) equal to the (square) on {AD line}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BF line} to the (square) on {DB line} [Prop. 10.32 lem.].
Thus, the (square) on {AD line} is also incommensurable with the (square) on {DB line}.
And since the (square) on {AB line} is medial, the sum of the (squares) on {AD line} and {DB line} (is) thus also medial [Props. 3.31, 1.47].
And since {BC line} is double {DF line} [see previous proposition], the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} (is) thus also double the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {FD line}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} (is) rational.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {FD line} (is) also rational [Prop. 10.6, Def. 10.4].
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {FD line} (is) equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line} [Prop. 10.32 lem.].
And hence the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line} is rational.

Thus, two straight-lines, {AD line} and {DB line}, (which are) incommensurable in square, have been found, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational.
(Which is) the verything it was required to show.

title: Proposition 35
prose:
To find two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, incommensurable with the sum of the squares on them.

Let the two medial (straight-lines) {AB line} and {BC line}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid out containing a medial (area), such that the square on {AB line} is greater than (the square on) {BC line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AB line}) [Prop. 10.32].
And let the semi-circle {ADB arc O} have been drawn on {AB line}.
And let the remainder (of the figure) be generated similarly to the above (proposition).

And since {AF line} is incommensurable in length with {FB line} [Prop. 10.18], {AD line} is also incommensurable in square with {DB line} [Prop. 10.11].
And since the (square) on {AB line} is medial, the sum of the (squares) on {AD line} and {DB line} (is) thus also medial [Props. 3.31, 1.47].
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FB line} is equal to the (square) on each of {BE line} and {DF line}, {BE line} is thus equal to {DF line}.
Thus, {BC line} (is) double {FD line}.
And hence the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} is double the (rectangle) contained by {AB line} and {FD line}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} (is) medial.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {FD line} (is) also medial.
And it is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line} [Prop. 10.32 lem.].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line} (is) also medial.
And since {AB line} is incommensurable in length with {BC line}, and {CB line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {BE line}, {AB line} (is) thus also incommensurable in length with {BE line} [Prop. 10.13].
And hence the (square) on {AB line} is also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BE line} [Prop. 10.11].
But the (sum of the squares) on {AD line} and {DB line} is equal to the (square) on {AB line} [Prop. 1.47].
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {FD line}---that is to say, the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line}---is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BE line}.
Thus, the sum of the (squares) on {AD line} and {DB line} is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AD line} and {DB line}.

Thus, two straight-lines, {AD line} and {DB line}, (which are) incommensurable in square, have been found, making the sum of the (squares) on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, incommensurable with the sum of the squares on them.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 36
prose:
If two rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only are added together then the whole (straight-line) is irrational---let it be called a binomial (straight-line).

For let the two rational (straight-lines), {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, (which are) commensurable in square only, be laid down together.
I say that the whole (straight-line), {AC magnitude}, is irrational.
For since {AB magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {BC magnitude}---for they are commensurable in square only---and as {AB magnitude} (is) to {BC magnitude}, so the (rectangle contained) by {ABC magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {BC magnitude}, the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus incommensurable with the (square) on {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
But, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {BC magnitude}---for the rational (straight-lines) {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.15].
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
And, via composition, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}---that is to say, the (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.4]---is incommensurable with the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
And the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} [is] irrational [Def. 10.4].
Hence, {AC magnitude} is also irrational [Def. 10.4]---let it be called a binomial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 37
prose:
If two medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, which contain a rational (area), are added together then the whole (straight-line) is irrational---let it be called a first bimedial (straight-line).

For let the two medial (straight-lines), {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, commensurable in square only, (and) containing a rational (area), be laid down together.
I say that the whole (straight-line), {AC magnitude}, is irrational.

For since {AB magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {BC magnitude}, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus also incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [see previous proposition].
And, via composition, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}---that is, the (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.4]---is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
And the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational---for {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} were assumed to enclose a rational (area).
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) irrational.
Thus, {AC magnitude} (is) irrational [Def. 10.4]---let it be called a first bimedial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 38
prose:
If two medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, which contain a medial (area), are added together then the whole (straight-line) is irrational---let it be called a second bimedial (straight-line).

For let the two medial (straight-lines), {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, commensurable in square only, (and) containing a medial (area), be laid down together [Prop. 10.28].
I say that {AC magnitude} is irrational.

For let the rational (straight-line) {DE line} be laid down, and let (the rectangle) {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AC magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, making {DG line} as breadth [Prop. 1.44].
And since the (square) on {AC line} is equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB line} and {BC line}, plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB line} and {BC line} [Prop. 2.4], so let (the rectangle) {EH polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}.
The remainder {HF polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
And since {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are each medial, (the sum of) the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus also medial.
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} was also assumed (to be) medial.
And {EH polygon} is equal to (the sum of) the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, and {FH polygon} (is) equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {EH polygon} and {HF polygon} (are) each medial.
And they were applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
Thus, {DH line} and {HG line} are each rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
Therefore, since {AB magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {BC magnitude}, and as {AB magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], the (square) on {AB magnitude} is thus incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
But, the sum of the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.15], and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
But, {EH polygon} is equal to (the sum of) the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, and {HF polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle) contained by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {EH polygon} is incommensurable with {HF polygon}.
Hence, {DH line} is also incommensurable in length with {HG line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
Thus, {DH line} and {HG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Hence, {DG line} is irrational [Prop. 10.36].
And {DE line} (is) rational.
And the rectangle contained by irrational and rational (straight-lines) is irrational [Prop. 10.20].
The area {DF polygon} is thus irrational, and (so) the square-root [of it] is irrational [Def. 10.4].
And {AC magnitude} is the square-root of {DF polygon}.
{AC magnitude} is thus irrational---let it be called a second bimedial(straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 39
prose:
If two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, are added together then the whole straight-line is irrational---let it be called a major (straight-line).

For let the two straight-lines, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, incommensurable in square, and fulfilling the prescribed (conditions), be laid down together [Prop. 10.33].
I say that {AC magnitude} is irrational.

For since the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is [thus] also medial [Props. 10.6, 10.23 corr.].
And the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Def. 10.4].
Hence, (the sum of) the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}---that is, the (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.4]---is also incommensurable with the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16] [and the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational].
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is irrational.
Hence, {AC magnitude} is also irrational [Def. 10.4]---let it be called a major (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 40
prose:
If two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational, are added together then the whole straight-line is irrational---let it be called the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

For let the two straight-lines, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, incommensurable in square, (and) fulfilling the prescribed (conditions), be laid down together [Prop. 10.34].
I say that {AC magnitude} is irrational.

For since the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational, the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Hence, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is also incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.16].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
The (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) thus irrational.
Thus, {AC magnitude} (is) irrational [Def. 10.4]---let it be called the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 41
prose:
If two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, incommensurable with the sum of the squares on them, are added together then the whole straight-line is irrational---let it be called the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

For let the two straight-lines, {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, incommensurable in square, (and) fulfilling the prescribed (conditions), be laid down together [Prop. 10.35].
I say that {AC magnitude} is irrational.

Let the rational (straight-line) {DE line} be laid out, and let (the rectangle) {DF polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, and (the rectangle) {GH polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}.
Thus, the whole of {DH polygon} is equal to the square on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.4].
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {DF polygon}, {DF polygon} is thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
Thus, {DG line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
So, for the same (reasons), {GK line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {GF line}---that is to say, {DE line}.
And since (the sum of) the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, {DF polygon} is incommensurable with {GH polygon}.
Hence, {DG line} is also incommensurable (in length) with {GK line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And they are rational.
Thus, {DG line} and {GK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {DK line} is irrational, and that (straight-line which is) called binomial [Prop. 10.36].
And {DE line} (is) rational.
Thus, {DH polygon} is irrational, and its square-root is irrational [Def. 10.4].
And {AC magnitude} (is) the square-root of {HD polygon}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is irrational---let it be called the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma
prose:
We will now demonstrate that the aforementioned irrational (straight-lines) are uniquely divided into the straight-lines of which they are the sum, and which produce the prescribed types, (after) setting forth the following lemma.

Let the straight-line {AB magnitude} be laid out, and let the whole (straight-line) have been cut into unequal parts at each of the (points) {C point} and {D point}.
And let {AC magnitude} be assumed (to be) greater than {DB magnitude}.
I say that (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.

For let {AB magnitude} have been cut in half at {E point}.
And since {AC magnitude} is greater than {DB magnitude}, let {DC magnitude} have been subtracted from both.
Thus, the remainder {AD magnitude} is greater than the remainder {CB magnitude}.
And {AE magnitude} (is) equal to {EB magnitude}.
Thus, {DE magnitude} (is) less than {EC magnitude}.
Thus, points {C point} and {D point} are not equally far from the point of bisection.
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, plus the (square) on {EC magnitude}, is equal to the (square) on {EB magnitude} [Prop. 2.5], but, moreover, the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, plus the (square) on {DE magnitude}, is also equal to the (square) on {EB magnitude} [Prop. 2.5], the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, plus the (square) on {EC magnitude}, is thus equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, plus the (square) on {DE magnitude}.
And, of these, the (square) on {DE magnitude} is less than the (square) on {EC magnitude}.
And, thus, the remaining (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is less than the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.
And, hence, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is less than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.
And thus the remaining sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than the sum of the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 42
prose:
A binomial (straight-line) can be divided into its (component) terms at one point only.

Let {AB magnitude} be a binomial (straight-line) which has been divided into its (component) terms at {C point}.
{AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.36].
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be divided at another point into two rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.

For, if possible, let it also have been divided at {D point}, such that {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
So, (it is) clear that {AC magnitude} is not the same as {DB magnitude}.
For, if possible, let it be (the same).
So, {AD magnitude} will also be the same as {CB magnitude}.
And as {AC magnitude} will be to {CB magnitude}, so {BD magnitude} (will be) to {DA magnitude}.
And {AB magnitude} will (thus) also be divided at {D point} in the same (manner) as the division at {C point}.
The very opposite was assumed.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is not the same as {DB magnitude}.
So, on account of this, points {C point} and {D point} are not equally far from the point of bisection.
Thus, by whatever (amount the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same amount)---on account of both (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, and (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, plus twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, being equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 2.4].
But, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For (they are) both rational (areas).
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area, despite both) being medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21].
The very thing is absurd.
For a medial (area) cannot exceed a medial (area) by a rational (area) [Prop. 10.26].

Thus, a binomial (straight-line) cannot be divided (into its component terms) at different points.
Thus, (it can be so divided) at one point only.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 43
prose:
A first bimedial (straight-line) can be divided (into its component terms) at one point only

Let {AB magnitude} be a first bimedial (straight-line) which has been divided at {C point}, such that {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a rational (area) [Prop. 10.37].
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be (so) divided at another point.

For, if possible, let it also have been divided at {D point}, such that {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a rational (area).
Since, therefore, by whatever (amount) twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} by this (same amount) [Prop. 10.41 lem.].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For (they are) both rational (areas).
(The sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} thus differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} by a rational (area, despite both) being medial (areas).
The very thing is absurd [Prop. 10.26].

Thus, a first bimedial (straight-line) cannot be divided into its (component) terms at different points.
Thus, (it can be so divided) at one point only.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 44
prose:
A second bimedial (straight-line) can be divided (into its component terms) at one point only.

Let {AB magnitude} be a second bimedial (straight-line) which has been divided at {C point}, so that {AC magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a medial (area) [Prop. 10.38].
So, (it is) clear that {C point} is not (located) at the point of bisection, since ({AC magnitude} and {BC magnitude}) are not commensurable in length.
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be (so) divided at another point.

For, if possible, let it also have been (so) divided at {D point}, so that {AC magnitude} is not the same as {DB magnitude}, but {AC magnitude} (is), by hypothesis, greater.
So, (it is) clear that (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} is also less than (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, as we showed above [Prop. 10.41 lem.].
And {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, (and) containing a medial (area).
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let the rectangular parallelogram {EK polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}.
And let {EG polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been cut off (from {EK polygon}).
Thus, the remainder, {HK polygon}, is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 2.4].
So, again, let {EL polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}---which was shown (to be) less than (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}---have been cut off (from {EK polygon}).
And, thus, the remainder, {MK polygon}, (is) equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.
And since (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is medial, {EG polygon} (is) thus [also] medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {EH line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
So, for the same (reasons), {HN line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line}.
And since {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, {AC magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {CB magnitude}.
And as {AC magnitude} (is) to {CB magnitude}, so the (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.].
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
But, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AC magnitude}.
For, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are commensurable in square [Prop. 10.15].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And thus (the sum of) the squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
But, {EG polygon} is equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, and {HK polygon} equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}.
Thus, {EG polygon} is polygon incommensurable with {HK polygon}.
Hence, {EH line} is also incommensurable in length with {HN line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And (they are) rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {EH line} and {HN line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And if two rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only are added together then the whole (straight-line) is that irrational called binomial [Prop. 10.36].
Thus, {EN line} is a binomial (straightline) which has been divided (into its component terms) at {H point}.
So, according to the same (reasoning), {EM line} and {MN line} can be shown (to be) rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And {EN line} will (thus) be a binomial (straight-line) which has been divided (into its component terms) at the different (points) {H point} and {M point} (which is absurd [Prop. 10.42]).
And {EH line} is not the same as {MN line}, since (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}.
But, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} is greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [Prop. 10.59 lem.].
Thus, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}---that is to say, {EG polygon}---is also much greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}---that is to say, {MK polygon}.
Hence, {EH line} is also greater than {MN line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EH line} is not the same as {MN line}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 45
prose:
A major (straight-line) can only be divided (into its component terms) at the same point.

Let {AB magnitude} be a major (straight-line) which has been divided at {C point}, so that {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} rational, and the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} medial [Prop. 10.39].
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be (so) divided at another point.

For, if possible, let it also have been divided at {D point}, such that {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also incommensurable in square, making the sum of the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial.
And since, by whatever (amount the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same amount).
But, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} exceeds (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For (they are) both rational (areas).
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area), (despite both) being medial (areas).
The very thing is impossible [Prop. 10.26].
Thus, a major (straight-line) cannot be divided (into its component terms) at different points.
Thus, it can only be (so) divided at the same (point).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 46
prose:
The square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) can be divided (into its component terms) at one point only.

Let {AB magnitude} be the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) which has been divided at {C point}, so that {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} rational [Prop. 10.40].
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be (so) divided at another point.

For, if possible, let it also have been divided at {D point}, so that {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also incommensurable in square, making the sum of the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} rational.
Therefore, since by whatever (amount) twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} differs from twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also differs from (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same amount).
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} by a rational (area).
(The sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} thus also exceeds (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area), (despite both) being medial (areas).
The very thing is impossible [Prop. 10.26].
Thus, the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) cannot be divided (into its component terms) at different points.
Thus, it can be (so) divided at one point (only).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 47
prose:
The square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) can be divided (into its component terms) at one point only.

Let {AB magnitude} be [the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas)] which has been divided at {C magnitude}, such that {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} medial, and the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} medial, and, moreover, incommensurable with the sum of the (squares) on ({AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}) [Prop. 10.41].
I say that {AB magnitude} cannot be divided at another point fulfilling the prescribed (conditions).

For, if possible, let it have been divided at {D point}, such that {AC magnitude} is again manifestly not the same as {DB magnitude}, but {AC magnitude} (is), by hypothesis, greater.
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let {EG polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, and {HK polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}.
Thus, the whole of {EK polygon} is equal to the square on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 2.4].
So, again, let {EL polygon}, equal to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}.
Thus, the remainder---twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}---is equal to the remainder, {MK polygon}.
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} was assumed (to be) medial, {EG polygon} is also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
{HE line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
So, for the same (reasons), {HN line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line}.
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, {EG polygon} is thus also incommensurable with {GN polygon}.
Hence, {EH line} is also incommensurable with {HN line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And they are (both) rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {EH line} and {HN line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EN line} is a binomial (straightline) which has been divided (into its component terms) at {H point} [Prop. 10.36].
So, similarly, we can show that it has also been (so) divided at {M point}.
And {EH line} is not the same as {MN line}.
Thus, a binomial (straight-line) has been divided (into its component terms) at different points.
The very thing is absurd [Prop. 10.42].
Thus, the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) cannot be divided (into its component terms) at different points.
Thus, it can be (so) divided at one [point] only.

title: Definitions II
prose:
5. Given a rational (straight-line), and a binomial (straight-line) which has been divided into its (component) terms, of which the square on the greater term is larger than (the square on) the lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with (the greater) then, if the greater term is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line previously) laid out, let [the whole] (straight-line) be called a first binomial (straight-line).

6. And if the lesser term is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line previously) laid out then let (the whole straight-line) be called a second binomial (straight-line).

7. And if neither of the terms is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line previously) laid out then let (the whole straight-line) be called a third binomial (straight-line).

8. So, again, if the square on the greater term is larger than (the square on) [the lesser] by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with (the greater) then, if the greater term is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line previously) laid out, let (the whole straight-line) be called a fourth binomial (straight-line).

9. And if the lesser (term is commensurable), a fifth (binomial straight-line).

10. And if neither (term is commensurable), a sixth (binomial straight-line).

title: Proposition 48
prose:
To find a first binomial (straight-line).

Let two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that their sum {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, and does not have to {CA magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let some rational (straight-line) {D magnitude} be laid down.
And let {EF magnitude} be commensurable in length with {D magnitude}.
{EF magnitude} is thus also rational [Def. 10.3].
And let it have been contrived that as the number {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} has to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} also has to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) number (has) to (some) number.
Hence, the (square) on {EF magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And {EF magnitude} is rational.
Thus, {FG magnitude} (is) also rational.
And since {BA magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, thus the (square) on {EF magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop 10.9].
{EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EG magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
I say that (it is) also a first (binomial straight-line).

For since as the number {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and {BA magnitude} (is) greater than {AC magnitude}, the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) thus also greater than the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, let (the sum of) the (squares) on {FG magnitude} and {H magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {EF magnitude}.
And since as {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {AB magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} also has to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is commensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, the square on {EF magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {FG magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({EF magnitude}).
And {EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are rational (straight-lines).
And {EF magnitude} (is) commensurable in length with {D magnitude}.

Thus, {EG magnitude} is a first binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.5].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 49
prose:
To find a second binomial (straight-line).

Let the two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that their sum {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, and does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let the rational (straight-line) {D magnitude} be laid down.
And let {EF magnitude} be commensurable in length with {D magnitude}.
{EF magnitude} is thus a rational (straight-line).
So, let it also have been contrived that as the number {CA magnitude} (is) to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, {FG magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And since the number {CA magnitude} does not have to {AB magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {EF magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
{EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EG magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, we must show that (it is) also a second (binomial straight-line).

For since, inversely, as the number {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {GF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.7 corr.], and {BA magnitude} (is) greater than {AC magnitude}, the (square) on {GF magnitude} (is) thus [also] greater than the (square) on {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Let (the sum of) the (squares) on {EF magnitude} and {H magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {GF magnitude}.
Thus, via conversion, as {AB magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
But, {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} also has to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is commensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Hence, the square on {FG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {FE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({FG magnitude}).
And {FG magnitude} and {FE magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And the lesser term {EF magnitude} is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line) {D magnitude} (previously) laid down.

Thus, {EG magnitude} is a second binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.6].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 50
prose:
To find a third binomial (straight-line).

Let the two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that their sum {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, and does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let some other non-square number {D magnitude} also be laid down, and let it not have to each of {BA magnitude} and {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let some rational straight-line {E magnitude} be laid down, and let it have been contrived that as {D magnitude} (is) to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {E magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And {E magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).
Thus, {FG magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And since {D magnitude} does not have to {AB magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number has to (some) square number, the (square) on {E magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
{E magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
So, again, let it have been contrived that as the number {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And {FG magnitude} (is) a rational (straight-line).
Thus, {GH magnitude} (is) also a rational (straight-line).
And since {BA magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {FG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {HG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
{FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that (it is) also a third (binomial straight-line).

For since as {D magnitude} is to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and as {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, thus, via equality, as {D magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
And {D magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {E magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {E magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And since as {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) thus greater than the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, let (the sum of) the (squares) on {GH magnitude} and {K magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {FG magnitude}.
Thus, via conversion, as {AB magnitude} [is] to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {K magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} has to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} also has to the (square) on {K magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, {FG magnitude} [is] commensurable in length with {K magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, the square on {FG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({FG magnitude}).
And {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and neither of them is commensurable in length with {E magnitude}.

Thus, {FH magnitude} is a third binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.7].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 51
prose:
To find a fourth binomial (straight-line).

Let the two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that {AB magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude}, or to {AC magnitude} either, the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let the rational (straight-line) {D magnitude} be laid down.
And let {EF magnitude} be commensurable in length with {D magnitude}.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And let it have been contrived that as the number {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, {FG magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And since {BA magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {EF magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, {EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Hence, {EG magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that (it is) also a fourth (binomial straight-line).

For since as {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [and {BA magnitude} (is) greater than {AC magnitude}], the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) thus greater than the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, let (the sum of) the squares on {FG magnitude} and {H magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {EF magnitude}.
Thus, via conversion, as the number {AB magnitude} (is) to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, the square on {EF magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GF magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({EF magnitude}).
And {EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And {EF magnitude} is commensurable in length with {D magnitude}.

Thus, {EG magnitude} is a fourth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.8].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 52
prose:
To find a fifth binomial straight-line.

Let the two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that {AB magnitude} does not have to either of them the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let some rational straight-line {D magnitude} be laid down.
And let {EF magnitude} be commensurable [in length] with {D magnitude}.
Thus, {EF magnitude} (is) a rational (straight-line).
And let it have been contrived that as {CA magnitude} (is) to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
And {CA magnitude} does not have to {AB magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {EF magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {EF magnitude} and {FG magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, {EG magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that (it is) also a fifth (binomial straight-line).

For since as {CA magnitude} is to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {EF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, inversely, as {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.7 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {GF magnitude} (is) greater than the (square) on {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, let (the sum of) the (squares) on {EF magnitude} and {H magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {GF magnitude}.
Thus, via conversion, as the number {AB magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {GF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Hence, the square on {FG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {FE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({FG magnitude}).
And {GF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And the lesser term {EF magnitude} is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line previously) laid down, {D magnitude}.

Thus, {EG magnitude} is a fifth binomial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 53
prose:
To find a sixth binomial (straight-line).

Let the two numbers {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} be laid down such that {AB magnitude} does not have to each of them the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let {D magnitude} also be another number, which is not square, and does not have to each of {BA magnitude} and {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let some rational straight-line {E magnitude} be laid down.
And let it have been contrived that as {D magnitude} (is) to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And {E magnitude} is rational.
Thus, {FG magnitude} (is) also rational.
And since {D magnitude} does not have to {AB magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {E magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {E magnitude} (is) incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
So, again, let it have be contrived that as {BA magnitude} (is) to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
The (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) thus commensurable with the (square) on {HG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
The (square) on {HG magnitude} (is) thus rational.
Thus, {HG magnitude} (is) rational.
And since {BA magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {FG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, we must show that (it is) also a sixth (binomial straight-line).

For since as {D magnitude} is to {AB magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and also as {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, thus, via equality, as {D magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {E magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
And {D magnitude} does not have to {AC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {E magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
{E magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And ({E magnitude}) was also shown (to be) incommensurable (in length) with {FG magnitude}.
Thus, {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are each incommensurable in length with {E magnitude}.
And since as {BA magnitude} is to {AC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) thus greater than the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, let (the sum of) the (squares) on {GH magnitude} and {K magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {FG magnitude}.
Thus, via conversion, as {AB magnitude} (is) to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {K magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Hence, the (square) on {FG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {K magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {K magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
The square on {FG magnitude} is thus greater than (the square on) {GH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({FG magnitude}).
And {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and neither of them is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line) {E magnitude} (previously) laid down.

 Thus, {FH magnitude} is a sixth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.10].
 (Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma
prose:
Let {AB polygon} and {BC polygon} be two squares, and let them be laid down such that {DB line} is straight-on to {BE line}.
 {FB line} is, thus, also straight-on to {BG line}.
 And let the parallelogram {AC polygon} have been completed.
 I say that {AC polygon} is a square, and that {DG polygon} is the mean proportional to {AB polygon} and {BC polygon}, and, moreover, {DC polygon} is the mean proportional to {AC polygon} and {CB polygon}.

For since {DB line} is equal to {BF line}, and {BE line} to {BG line}, the whole of {DE line} is thus equal to the whole of {FG line}.
But {DE line} is equal to each of {AH line} and {KC line}, and {FG line} is equal to each of {AK line} and {HC line} [Prop. 1.34].
Thus, {AH line} and {KC line} are also equal to {AK line} and {HC line}, respectively.
Thus, the parallelogram {AC polygon} is equilateral.
And (it is) also right-angled.
Thus, {AC polygon} is a square.

And since as {FB line} is to {BG line}, so {DB line} (is) to {BE line}, but as {FB line} (is) to {BG line}, so {AB polygon} (is) to {DG polygon}, and as {DB line} (is) to {BE line}, so {DG polygon} (is) to {BC polygon} [Prop. 6.1], thus also as {AB polygon} (is) to {DG polygon}, so {DG polygon} (is) to {BC polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, {DG polygon} is the mean proportional to {AB polygon} and {BC polygon}.

So I also say that {DC polygon} [is] the mean proportional to {AC polygon} and {CB polygon}.

For since as {AD line} is to {DK line}, so {KG line} (is) to {GC line}.
For [they are] respectively equal.
And, via composition, as {AK line} (is) to {KD line}, so {KC line} (is) to {CG line} [Prop. 5.18].
But as {AK line} (is) to {KD line}, so {AC polygon} (is) to {CD polygon}, and as {KC line} (is) to {CG line}, so {DC polygon} (is) to {CB polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, also, as {AC polygon} (is) to {DC polygon}, so {DC polygon} (is) to {BC polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, {DC polygon} is the mean proportional to {AC polygon} and {CB polygon}.
Which (is the very thing) it was prescribed to show.

title: Proposition 54
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a first binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called binomial.

For let the area {AC polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and by the first binomial (straight-line) {AD line}.
I say that square-root of area {AC polygon} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called binomial.

For since {AD line} is a first binomial (straight-line), let it have been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, and let {AE line} be the greater term.
So, (it is) clear that {AE line} and {ED line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and that the square on {AE line} is greater than (the square on) {ED line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE line}), and that {AE line} is commensurable (in length) with the rational (straight-line) {AB line} (first) laid out [Def. 10.5].
So, let {ED line} have been cut in half at point {F point}.
And since the square on {AE line} is greater than (the square on) {ED line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE line}), thus if a (rectangle) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser (term)---that is to say, the (square) on {EF line}---falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater (term) {AE line}, then it divides it into (terms which are) commensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.17].
Therefore, let the (rectangle contained) by {AG line} and {GE line}, equal to the (square) on {EF line}, have been applied to {AE line}.
{AG line} is thus commensurable in length with {EG line}.
And let {GH line}, {EK line}, and {FL line} have been drawn from (points) {G point}, {E point}, and {F point} (respectively), parallel to either of {AB line} or {CD line}.
And let the square {SN polygon}, equal to the parallelogram {AH polygon}, have been constructed, and (the square) {NQ polygon}, equal to (the parallelogram) {GK polygon} [Prop. 2.14].
And let {MN line} be laid down so as to be straight-on to {NO line}.
{RN line} is thus also straight-on to {NP line}.
And let the parallelogram {SQ polygon} have been completed.
{SQ polygon} is thus a square [Prop. 10.53 lem.].
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AG line} and {GE line} is equal to the (square) on {EF line}, thus as {AG line} is to {EF line}, so {FE line} (is) to {EG line} [Prop. 6.17].
And thus as {AH polygon} (is) to {EL polygon}, (so) {EL polygon} (is) to {KG polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EL polygon} is the mean proportional to {AH polygon} and {GK polygon}.
But, {AH polygon} is equal to {SN polygon}, and {GK polygon} (is) equal to {NQ polygon}.
{EL polygon} is thus the mean proportional to {SN polygon} and {NQ polygon}.
And {MR polygon} is also the mean proportional to the same---(namely), {SN polygon} and {NQ polygon} [Prop. 10.53 lem.].
{EL polygon} is thus equal to {MR polygon}.
Hence, it is also equal to {PO polygon} [Prop. 1.43].
And {AH polygon} plus {GK polygon} is equal to {SN polygon} plus {NQ polygon}.
Thus, the whole of {AC polygon} is equal to the whole of {SQ polygon}---that is to say, to the square on {MO line}.
Thus, {MO line} (is) the square-root of (area) {AC polygon}.
I say that {MO line} is a binomial (straight-line).

For since {AG line} is commensurable (in length) with {GE line}, {AE line} is also commensurable (in length) with each of {AG line} and {GE line} [Prop. 10.15].
And {AE line} was also assumed (to be) commensurable (in length) with {AB line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {GE line} are also commensurable (in length) with {AB line} [Prop. 10.12].
And {AB line} is rational.
{AG line} and {GE line} are thus each also rational.
Thus, {AH polygon} and {GK polygon} are each rational (areas), and {AH polygon} is commensurable with {GK polygon} [Prop. 10.19].
But, {AH polygon} is equal to {SN polygon}, and {GK polygon} to {NQ polygon}.
{SN polygon} and {NQ polygon}---that is to say, the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line} (respectively)---are thus also rational and commensurable.
And since {AE line} is incommensurable in length with {ED line}, but {AE line} is commensurable (in length) with {AG line}, and {DE line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {AG line} (is) thus also incommensurable (in length) with {EF line} [Prop. 10.13].
Hence, {AH polygon} is also incommensurable with {EL polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
But, {AH polygon} is equal to {SN polygon}, and {EL polygon} to {MR polygon}.
Thus, {SN polygon} is also incommensurable with {MR polygon}.
But, as {SN polygon} (is) to {MR polygon}, (so) {PN line} (is) to {NR line} [Prop. 6.1].
{PN line} is thus incommensurable (in length) with {NR line} [Prop. 10.11].
And {PN line} (is) equal to {MN line}, and {NR line} to {NO line}.
Thus, {MN line} is incommensurable (in length) with {NO line}.
And the (square) on {MN line} is commensurable with the (square) on {NO line}, and each (is) rational.
{MN line} and {NO line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.

Thus, {MO line} is (both) a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36], and the square-root of {AC polygon}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 55
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a second binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called first bimedial.

For let the area {ABCD polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and by the second binomial (straight-line) {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AC polygon} is a first bimedial(straight-line).

For since {AD line} is a second binomial (straight-line), let it have been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, such that {AE line} is the greater term.
