Thus, {AE line} and {ED line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {AE line} is greater than (the square on) {ED line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE line}), and the lesser term {ED line} is commensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.6].
Let {ED line} have been cut in half at {F point}.
And let the (rectangle contained) by {AG line} and {GE line}, equal to the (square) on {EF line}, have been applied to {AE line}, falling short by a square figure.
{AG line} (is) thus commensurable in length with {GE line} [Prop. 10.17].
And let {GH line}, {EK line}, and {FL line} have been drawn through (points) {G point}, {E point}, and {F point} (respectively), parallel to {AB line} and {CD line}.
And let the square {SN polygon}, equal to the parallelogram {AH polygon}, have been constructed, and the square {NQ polygon}, equal to {GK polygon}.
And let {MN line} be laid down so as to be straight-on to {NO line}.
Thus, {RN line} [is] also straight-on to {NP line}.
And let the square {SQ polygon} have been completed.
So, (it is) clear from what has been previously demonstrated [Prop. 10.53 lem.] that {MR polygon} is the mean proportional to {SN polygon} and {NQ polygon}, and (is) equal to {EL polygon}, and that {MO line} is the square-root of the area {AC polygon}.
So, we must show that {MO line} is a first bimedial (straight-line).

Since {AE line} is incommensurable in length with {ED line}, and {ED line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {AB line}, {AE line} (is) thus incommensurable (in length) with {AB line} [Prop. 10.13].
And since {AG line} is commensurable (in length) with {EG line}, {AE line} is also commensurable (in length) with each of {AG line} and {GE line} [Prop. 10.15].
But, {AE line} is incommensurable in length with {AB line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {GE line} are also (both) incommensurable (in length) with {AB line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {BA line}, {AG line}, and ({BA line}, and) {GE line} are (pairs of) rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And, hence, each of {AH polygon} and {GK polygon} is a medial (area) [Prop. 10.21].
Hence, each of {SN polygon} and {NQ polygon} is also a medial (area).
Thus, {MN line} and {NO line} are medial (straight-lines).
And since {AG line} (is) commensurable in length with {GE line}, {AH polygon} is also commensurable with {GK polygon} ---that is to say, {SN polygon} with {NQ polygon}---that is to say, the (square) on {MN line} with the (square) on {NO line} [hence, {MN line} and {NO line} are commensurable in square] [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And since {AE line} is incommensurable in length with {ED line}, but {AE line} is commensurable (in length) with {AG line}, and {ED line} commensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {AG line} (is) thus incommensurable (in length) with {EF line} [Prop. 10.13].
Hence, {AH polygon} is also incommensurable with {EL polygon}---that is to say, {SN polygon} with {MR polygon}---that is to say, {PN line} with {NR line}---that is to say, {MN line} is incommensurable in length with {NO line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
But {MN line} and {NO line} have also been shown to be medial (straight-lines) which are commensurable in square.
Thus, {MN line} and {NO line} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
So, I say that they also contain a rational (area).
For since {DE line} was assumed (to be) commensurable (in length) with each of {AB line} and {EF line}, {EF line} (is) thus also commensurable with {EK line} [Prop. 10.12].
And they (are) each rational.
Thus, {EL polygon}---that is to say, {MR polygon}---(is) rational [Prop. 10.19].
And {MR polygon} is the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line}.
And if two medial (straight-lines), commensurable in square only, which contain a rational (area), are added together, then the whole is (that) irrational (straight-line which is) called first bimedial [Prop. 10.37].

Thus, {MO line} is a first bimedial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 56
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a third binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called second bimedial.

For let the area {ABCD polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and by the third binomial (straight-line) {AD line}, which has been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, of which {AE line} is the greater.
I say that the square-root of area {AC polygon} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called second bimedial.

For let the same construction be made as previously.
And since {AD line} is a third binomial (straight-line), {AE line} and {ED line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {AE line} is greater than (the square on) {ED line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE line}), and neither of {AE line} and {ED line} [is] commensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.7].
So, similarly to that which has been previously demonstrated, we can show that {MO line} is the square-root of area {AC polygon}, and {MN line} and {NO line} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Hence, {MO line} is bimedial.
So, we must show that (it is) also second (bimedial).

[And] since {DE line} is incommensurable in length with {AB line}---that is to say, with {EK line}---and {DE line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {EF line} is thus incommensurable in length with {EK line} [Prop. 10.13].
And they are (both) rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {FE line} and {EK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{EL polygon}---that is to say, {MR polygon}---[is] thus medial [Prop. 10.21].
And it is contained by {MN line} and {NO line}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line} is medial.

Thus, {MO line} is a second bimedial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.38].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 57
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fourth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called major.

For let the area {AC polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and the fourth binomial (straight-line) {AD line}, which has been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, of which let {AE line} be the greater.
I say that the square-root of {AC polygon} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called major.

For since {AD line} is a fourth binomial (straight-line), {AE line} and {ED line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {AE line} is greater than (the square on) {ED line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AE line}), and {AE line} [is] commensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.8].
Let {DE line} have been cut in half at {F point}, and let the parallelogram (contained by) {AG line} and {GE line}, equal to the (square) on {EF line}, (and falling short by a square figure) have been applied to {AE line}.
{AG line} is thus incommensurable in length with {GE line} [Prop. 10.18].
Let {GH line}, {EK line}, and {FL line} have been drawn parallel to {AB line}, and let the rest (of the construction) have been made the same as the (proposition) before this.
So, it is clear that {MO line} is the square-root of area {AC polygon}.
So, we must show that {MO line} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called major.

Since {AG line} is incommensurable in length with {EG line}, {AH polygon} is also incommensurable with {GK polygon}---that is to say, {SN polygon} with {NQ polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
Thus, {MN line} and {NO line} are incommensurable in square.
And since {AE line} is commensurable in length with {AB line}, {AK polygon} is rational [Prop. 10.19].
And it is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {MN line} and {NO line}.
Thus, the sum of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line} [is] also rational.
And since {DE line} [is] incommensurable in length with {AB line} [Prop. 10.13]---that is to say, with {EK line}---but {DE line} is commensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {EF line} (is) thus incommensurable in length with {EK line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {EK line} and {EF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{LE polygon}---that is to say, {MR polygon}---(is) thus medial [Prop. 10.21].
And it is contained by {MN line} and {NO line}.
The (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line} is thus medial.
And the [sum] of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line} (is) rational, and {MN line} and {NO line} are incommensurable in square.
And if two straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, are added together, then the whole is the irrational (straight-line which is) called major [Prop. 10.39].

Thus, {MO line} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called major.
And (it is) the square-root of area {AC polygon}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 58
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fifth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

For let the area {AC polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and the fifth binomial (straight-line) {AD line}, which has been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, such that {AE line} is the greater term.
[So] I say that the square-root of area {AC polygon} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

For let the same construction be made as that shown previously.
So, (it is) clear that {MO line} is the square-root of area {AC polygon}.
So, we must show that {MO line} is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

For since {AG line} is incommensurable (in length) with {GE line} [Prop. 10.18], {AH polygon} is thus also incommensurable with {HE polygon}---that is to say, the (square) on {MN line} with the (square) on {NO line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
Thus, {MN line} and {NO line} are incommensurable in square.
And since {AD line} is a fifth binomial (straight-line), and {ED line} [is] its lesser segment, {ED line} (is) thus commensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.9].
But, {AE line} is incommensurable (in length) with {ED line}.
Thus, {AB line} is also incommensurable in length with {AE line} [{BA line} and {AE line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only] [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {AK polygon} ---that is to say, the sum of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line}---is medial [Prop. 10.21].
And since {DE line} is commensurable in length with {AB line}---that is to say, with {EK line}---but, {DE line} is commensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {EF line} is thus also commensurable (in length) with {EK line} [Prop. 10.12].
And {EK line} (is) rational.
Thus, {EL polygon}---that is to say, {MR polygon}---that is to say, the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line}---(is) also rational [Prop. 10.19].
{MN line} and {NO line} are thus (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational.

Thus, {MO line} is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) [Prop. 10.40].
And (it is) the square-root of area {AC polygon}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 59
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a sixth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line which is) called the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

For let the area {ABCD polygon} be contained by the rational (straight-line) {AB line} and the sixth binomial (straight-line) {AD line}, which has been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, such that {AE line} is the greater term.
So, I say that the square-root of {AC polygon} is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

[For] let the same construction be made as that shown previously.
So, (it is) clear that {MO line} is the square-root of {AC polygon}, and that {MN line} is incommensurable in square with {NO line}.
And since {EA line} is incommensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.10], {EA line} and {AB line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {AK polygon} ---that is to say, the sum of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line}---is medial [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {ED line} is incommensurable in length with {AB line} [Def. 10.10], {FE line} is thus also incommensurable (in length) with {EK line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {FE line} and {EK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EL polygon}---that is to say, {MR polygon}---that is to say, the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line}---is medial [Prop. 10.21].
And since {AE line} is incommensurable (in length) with {EF line}, {AK polygon} is also incommensurable with {EL polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
But, {AK polygon} is the sum of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line}, and {EL polygon} is the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line}.
Thus, the sum of the (squares) on {MN line} and {NO line} is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {MN line} and {NO line}.
And each of them is medial.
And {MN line} and {NO line} are incommensurable in square.

Thus, {MO line} is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) [Prop. 10.41].
And (it is) the square-root of {AC polygon}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Lemma
prose:
If a straight-line is cut unequally then (the sum of) the squares on the unequal (parts) is greater than twice the rectangle contained by the unequal (parts).

Let {AB magnitude} be a straight-line, and let it have been cut unequally at {C point}, and let {AC magnitude} be greater (than {CB magnitude}).
I say that (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}.

For let {AB magnitude} have been cut in half at {D point}.
Therefore, since a straight-line has been cut into equal (parts) at {D point}, and into unequal (parts) at {C point}, the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, plus the (square) on {CD magnitude}, is thus equal to the (square) on {AD magnitude} [Prop. 2.5].
Hence, the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is less than the (square) on {AD magnitude}.
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is less than double the (square) on {AD magnitude}.
But, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [is] double (the sum of) the (squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DC magnitude} [Prop. 2.9].
Thus, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 60
prose:
The square on a binomial (straight-line) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a first binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a binomial (straight-line), having been divided into its (component) terms at {C point}, such that {AC magnitude} is the greater term.
And let the rational (straight-line) {DE line} be laid down.
And let the (rectangle) {DEFG polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a first binomial (straight-line).

For let {DH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AC magnitude}, and {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {BC magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}.
Thus, the remaining twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is equal to {MF polygon} [Prop. 2.4].
Let {MG line} have been cut in half at {N point}, and let {NO line} have been drawn parallel [to each of {ML line} and {GF line}].
{MO polygon} and {NF polygon} are thus each equal to once the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude}.
And since {AB magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line), having been divided into its (component) terms at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.36].
Thus, the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are rational, and commensurable with one another.
And hence the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} (is rational) [Prop. 10.15], and is equal to {DL polygon}.
Thus, {DL polygon} is rational.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
{DM line} is thus rational, and commensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.20].
Again, since {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}---that is to say, {MF polygon}---is thus medial [Prop. 10.21].
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {ML line}.
{MG line} is thus also rational, and incommensurable in length with {ML line}---that is to say, with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
And {MD line} is also rational, and commensurable in length with {DE line}.
Thus, {DM line} is incommensurable in length with {MG line} [Prop. 10.13].
And they are rational.
{DM line} and {MG line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {DG line} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, we must show that (it is) also a first (binomial straight-line).

Since the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.53 lem.], {MO polygon} is thus also the mean proportional to {DH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {DH polygon} is to {MO polygon}, so {MO polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}---that is to say, as {DK line} (is) to {MN line}, (so) {MN line} (is) to {MK line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {DK line} and {KM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line} [Prop. 6.17].
And since the (square) on {AC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {CB magnitude}, {DH polygon} is also commensurable with {KL polygon}.
Hence, {DK line} is also commensurable with {KM line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And since (the sum of) the squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.59 lem.], {DL polygon} (is) thus also greater than {MF polygon}.
Hence, {DM line} is also greater than {MG line} [Props. 6.1, 5.14].
And the (rectangle contained) by {DK line} and {KM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}---that is to say, to one quarter the (square) on {MG line}.
And {DK line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {KM line}.
And if there are two unequal straight-lines, and a (rectangle) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, and divides it into (parts which are) commensurable (in length), then the square on the greater is larger than (the square on) the lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with the greater [Prop. 10.17].
Thus, the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({DM line}).
And {DM line} and {MG line} are rational.
And {DM line}, which is the greater term, is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a first binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.5].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 61
prose:
The square on a first bimedial (straight-line) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a second binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a first bimedial (straight-line) having been divided into its (component) medial (straight-lines) at {C point}, of which {AC magnitude} (is) the greater.
And let the rational (straight-line) {DE line} be laid down.
And let the parallelogram {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a second binomial (straight-line).

For let the same construction have been made as in the (proposition) before this.
And since {AB magnitude} is a first bimedial (straight-line), having been divided at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus medial (straight-lines) commensurable in square only, and containing a rational (area) [Prop. 10.37].
Hence, the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are also medial [Prop. 10.21].
Thus, {DL polygon} is medial [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
{MD line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is rational, {MF polygon} is also rational.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {ML line}.
Thus, {MG line} [is] also rational, and commensurable in length with {ML line}---that is to say, with {DE line} [Prop. 10.20].
{DM line} is thus incommensurable in length with {MG line} [Prop. 10.13].
And they are rational.
{DM line} and {MG line} are thus rational, and commensurable in square only.
{DG line} is thus a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, we must show that (it is) also a second (binomial straight-line).

For since (the sum of) the squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is greater than twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.59], {DL polygon} (is) thus also greater than {MF polygon}.
Hence, {DM line} (is) also (greater) than {MG line} [Prop. 6.1].
And since the (square) on {AC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {CB magnitude}, {DH polygon} is also commensurable with {KL polygon}.
Hence, {DK line} is also commensurable (in length) with {KM line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And the (rectangle contained) by {DKM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}.
Thus, the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({DM line}) [Prop. 10.17].
And {MG line} is commensurable in length with {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a second binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.6].

title: Proposition 62
prose:
The square on a second bimedial (straight-line) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a third binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a second bimedial (straight-line) having been divided into its (component) medial (straight-lines) at {C point}, such that {AC magnitude} is the greater segment.
And let {DE line} be some rational (straight-line).
And let the parallelogram {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a third binomial (straight-line).

Let the same construction be made as that shown previously.
And since {AB magnitude} is a second bimedial (straight-line), having been divided at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus medial (straight-lines) commensurable in square only, and containing a medial (area) [Prop. 10.38].
Hence, the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is also medial [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it is equal to {DL polygon}.
Thus, {DL polygon} (is) also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
{MD line} is thus also rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
So, for the same (reasons), {MG line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {ML line}---that is to say, with {DE line}.
Thus, {DM line} and {MG line} are each rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line}.
And since {AC magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {CB magnitude}, and as {AC magnitude} (is) to {CB magnitude}, so the (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], the (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And hence the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude}---that is to say, {DL polygon} with {MF polygon} [Props. 10.12, 10.13].
Hence, {DM line} is also incommensurable (in length) with {MG line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And they are rational.
{DG line} is thus a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
[So] we must show that (it is) also a third (binomial straight-line).

So, similarly to the previous (propositions), we can conclude that {DM line} is greater than {MG line}, and {DK line} (is) commensurable (in length) with {KM line}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {DKM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}.
Thus, the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({DM line}) [Prop. 10.17].
And neither of {DM line} and {MG line} is commensurable in length with {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a third binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.7].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 63
prose:
The square on a major (straight-line) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a fourth binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a major (straight-line) having been divided at {C point}, such that {AC magnitude} is greater than {CB magnitude}, and (let) {DE line} (be) a rational (straight-line).
And let the parallelogram {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a fourth binomial (straight-line).

Let the same construction be made as that shown previously.
And since {AB magnitude} is a major (straight-line), having been divided at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial [Prop. 10.39].
Therefore, since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is rational, {DL polygon} is thus rational.
Thus, {DM line} (is) also rational, and commensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.20].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}---that is to say, {MF polygon}---is medial, and is (applied to) the rational (straight-line) {ML line}, {MG line} is thus also rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
{DM line} is thus also incommensurable in length with {MG line} [Prop. 10.13].
{DM line} and {MG line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {DG line} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
[So] we must show that (it is) also a fourth (binomial straight-line).

So, similarly to the previous (propositions), we can show that {DM line} is greater than {MG line}, and that the (rectangle contained) by {DKM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}.
Therefore, since the (square) on {AC magnitude} is incommensurable with the (square) on {CB magnitude}, {DH polygon} is also incommensurable with {KL polygon}.
Hence, {DK line} is also incommensurable with {KM line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And if there are two unequal straight-lines, and a parallelogram equal to the fourth part of the (square) on the lesser, falling short by a square figure, is applied to the greater, and divides it into (parts which are) incommensurable (in length), then the square on the greater will be larger than (the square on) the lesser by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with the greater [Prop. 10.18].
Thus, the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({DM line}).
And {DM line} and {MG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And {DM line} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a fourth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.8].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 64
prose:
The square on the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a fifth binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) having been divided into its (component) straight-lines at {C point}, such that {AC magnitude} is greater.
And let the rational (straight-line) {DE line} be laid down.
And let the (parallelogram) {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a fifth binomial straight-line.

Let the same construction be made as in the (propositions) before this.
Therefore, since {AB magnitude} is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area), having been divided at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational [Prop. 10.40].
Therefore, since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is medial, {DL polygon} is thus medial.
Hence, {DM line} is rational and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {ACB magnitude}---that is to say, {MF polygon}---is rational, {MG line} (is) thus rational and commensurable (in length) with {DE line} [Prop. 10.20].
{DM line} (is) thus incommensurable (in length) with {MG line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {DM line} and {MG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {DG line} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that (it is) also a fifth (binomial straight-line).

For, similarly (to the previous propositions), it can be shown that the (rectangle contained) by {DKM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}, and {DK line} (is) incommensurable in length with {KM line}.
Thus, the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({DM line}) [Prop. 10.18].
And {DM line} and {MG line} are [rational] (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the lesser {MG line} is commensurable in length with {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a fifth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.9].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 65
prose:
The square on the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) applied to a rational (straight-line) produces as breadth a sixth binomial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas), having been divided at {C point}.
And let {DE line} be a rational (straight-line).
And let the (parallelogram) {DF polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {DE line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
I say that {DG line} is a sixth binomial (straight-line).

For let the same construction be made as in the previous (propositions).
And since {AB magnitude} is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas), having been divided at {C point}, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, the sum of the squares on them incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by them [Prop. 10.41].
Hence, according to what has been previously demonstrated, {DL polygon} and {MF polygon} are each medial.
And they are applied to the rational (straight-line) {DE line}.
Thus, {DM line} and {MG line} are each rational, and incommensurable in length with {DE line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, {DL polygon} is thus incommensurable with {MF polygon}.
Thus, {DM line} (is) also incommensurable (in length) with {MG line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
{DM line} and {MG line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {DG line} is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that (it is) also a sixth (binomial straight-line).

So, similarly (to the previous propositions), we can again show that the (rectangle contained) by {DKM line} is equal to the (square) on {MN line}, and that {DK line} is incommensurable in length with {KM line}.
And so, for the same (reasons), the square on {DM line} is greater than (the square on) {MG line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({DM line}) [Prop. 10.18].
And neither of {DM line} and {MG line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {DE line}.

Thus, {DG line} is a sixth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.10].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 66
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable in length with a binomial (straight-line) is itself also binomial, and the same in order.

Let {AB magnitude} be a binomial (straight-line), and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable in length with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line), and (is) the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For since {AB magnitude} is a binomial (straight-line), let it have been divided into its (component) terms at {E point}, and let {AE magnitude} be the greater term.
{AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.36].
Let it have been contrived that as {AB magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so {AE magnitude} (is) to {CF magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].
Thus, the remainder {EB magnitude} is also to the remainder {FD magnitude}, as {AB magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude} [Props. 6.16, 5.19 corr.].
And {AB magnitude} (is) commensurable in length with {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} is also commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude}, and {EB magnitude} with {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are rational.
Thus, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also rational.
And as {AE magnitude} is to {CF magnitude}, (so) {EB magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, alternately, as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, (so) {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
And {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} [are] commensurable in square only.
Thus, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And they are rational.
{CD magnitude} is thus a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
So, I say that it is the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For the square on {AE magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {EB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) either commensurable or incommensurable (in length) with ({AE magnitude}).
Therefore, if the square on {AE magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {EB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE magnitude}) then the square on {CF magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {FD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({CF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {AE magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with (some previously) laid down rational (straight-line) then {CF magnitude} will also be commensurable (in length) with it [Prop. 10.12].
And, on account of this, {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} are each first binomial (straight-lines) [Def. 10.5]---that is to say, the same in order.
And if {EB magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) then {FD magnitude} is also commensurable (in length) with it [Prop. 10.12], and, again, on account of this, ({CD magnitude}) will be the same in order as {AB magnitude}.
For each of them will be second binomial (straight-lines) [Def. 10.6].
And if neither of {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) then neither of {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} will be commensurable (in length) with it [Prop. 10.13], and each (of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) is a third (binomial straight-line) [Def. 10.7].
And if the square on {AE magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {EB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AE magnitude}) then the square on {CF magnitude} is also greater than (the square on) {FD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {AE magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) then {CF magnitude} is also commensurable (in length) with it [Prop. 10.12], and each (of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) is a fourth (binomial straight-line) [Def. 10.8].
And if {EB magnitude} (is commensurable in length with the previously laid down rational straight-line) then {FD magnitude} (is) also (commensurable in length with it), and each (of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) will be a fifth (binomial straight-line) [Def. 10.9].
And if neither of {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is commensurable in length with the previously laid down rational straight-line) then also neither of {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the laid down rational (straight-line), and each (of {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) will be a sixth (binomial straight-line) [Def. 10.10].

Hence, a (straight-line) commensurable in length with a binomial (straight-line) is a binomial (straight-line), and the same in order.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 67
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable in length with a bimedial (straight-line) is itself also bimedial, and the same in order.

Let {AB magnitude} be a bimedial (straight-line), and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable in length with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is bimedial, and the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For since {AB magnitude} is a bimedial (straight-line), let it have been divided into its (component) medial (straight-lines) at {E point}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Props. 10.37, 10.38].
And let it have been contrived that as {AB magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, (so) {AE magnitude} (is) to {CF magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].
And thus as the remainder {EB magnitude} is to the remainder {FD magnitude}, so {AB magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude} [Props. 5.19 corr., 6.16].
And {AB magnitude} (is) commensurable in length with {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are also commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, respectively [Prop. 10.11].
And {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (are) medial.
Thus, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (are) also medial [Prop. 10.23].
And since as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, (so) {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude}, and {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are commensurable in square only, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are [thus] also commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And they were also shown (to be) medial.
Thus, {CD magnitude} is a bimedial (straight-line).
So, I say that it is also the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For since as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, (so) {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude}, thus also as the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AEB magnitude}, so the (square) on {CF magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CFD magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.].
Alternately, as the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {CF magnitude}, so the (rectangle contained) by {AEB magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CFD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
And the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {CF magnitude}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AEB magnitude} (is) also commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {CFD magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
Therefore, either the (rectangle contained) by {AEB magnitude} is rational, and the (rectangle contained) by {CFD magnitude} is rational [and, on account of this, ({AE magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) are first bimedial (straight-lines)], or (the rectangle contained by {AEB magnitude} is) medial, and (the rectangle contained by {CFD magnitude} is) medial, and ({AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}) are each second (bimedial straight-lines) [Props. 10.23, 10.37, 10.38].

And, on account of this, {CD magnitude} will be the same in order as {AB magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 68
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with a major (straight-line) is itself also major.

Let {AB magnitude} be a major (straight-line), and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is a major (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} have been divided (into its component terms) at {E point}.
{AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are thus incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial [Prop. 10.39].
And let (the) same (things) have been contrived as in the previous (propositions).
And since as {AB magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so {AE magnitude} (is) to {CF magnitude} and {EB magnitude} to {FD magnitude}, thus also as {AE magnitude} (is) to {CF magnitude}, so {EB magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
And {AB magnitude} (is) commensurable (in length) with {CD magnitude}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (are) also commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, respectively [Prop. 10.11].
And since as {AE magnitude} is to {CF magnitude}, so {EB magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude}, also, alternately, as {AE magnitude} (is) to {EB magnitude}, so {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16], and thus, via composition, as {AB magnitude} is to {BE magnitude}, so {CD magnitude} (is) to {DF magnitude} [Prop. 5.18].
And thus as the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {BE magnitude}, so the (square) on {CD magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {DF magnitude} [Prop. 6.20].
So, similarly, we can also show that as the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {AE magnitude}, so the (square) on {CD magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {CF magnitude}.
And thus as the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) to (the sum of) the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude}, so the (square) on {CD magnitude} (is) to (the sum of) the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
And thus, alternately, as the (square) on {AB magnitude} is to the (square) on {CD magnitude}, so (the sum of) the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) to (the sum of) the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
And the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {CD magnitude}.
Thus, (the sum of) the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) also commensurable with (the sum of) the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (added) together are rational.
The (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (added) together (are) thus also rational.
So, similarly, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is also commensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is medial.
Therefore, twice the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
{CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are thus (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square [Prop 10.13], simultaneously making the sum of the squares on them rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial.
The whole, {CD magnitude}, is thus that irrational (straight-line) called major [Prop. 10.39].

Thus, a (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with a major (straight-line) is major.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 69
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) is [itself also] the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

Let {AB magnitude} be the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area), and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
We must show that {CD magnitude} is also the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

Let {AB magnitude} have been divided into its (component) straight-lines at {E point}.
{AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are thus incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational [Prop. 10.40].
And let the same construction have been made as in the previous (propositions).
So, similarly, we can show that {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also incommensurable in square, and that the sum of the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) commensurable with the sum of the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
And hence the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} is medial, and the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) rational.

Thus, {CD magnitude} is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) [Prop. 10.40].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 70
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) is (itself also) the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

Let {AB magnitude} be the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas), and (let) {CD magnitude} (be) commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
We must show that {CD magnitude} is also the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

For since {AB magnitude} is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas), let it have been divided into its (component) straight-lines at {E point}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the [squares] on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, the sum of the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} incommensurable with the (rectangle) contained by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} [Prop. 10.41].
And let the same construction have been made as in the previous (propositions).
So, similarly, we can show that {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also incommensurable in square, and (that) the sum of the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) commensurable with the sum of the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
Hence, the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} is also medial, and the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) medial, and, moreover, the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.

Thus, {CD magnitude} is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) [Prop. 10.41].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 71
prose:
When a rational and a medial (area) are added together, four irrational (straight-lines) arise (as the square-roots of the total area)---either a binomial, or a first bimedial, or a major, or the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

Let {AB polygon} be a rational (area), and {CD polygon} a medial (area).
I say that the square-root of area {AD polygon} is either binomial, or first bimedial, or major, or the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

For {AB polygon} is either greater or less than {CD polygon}.
Let it, first of all, be greater.
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let (the rectangle) {EG polygon}, equal to {AB polygon}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EH line} as breadth.
And let (the recatangle) {HI polygon}, equal to {DC polygon}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {HK line} as breadth.
And since {AB polygon} is rational, and is equal to {EG polygon}, {EG polygon} is thus also rational.
And it has been applied to the [rational] (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {EH line} as breadth.
{EH line} is thus rational, and commensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.20].
Again, since {CD polygon} is medial, and is equal to {HI polygon}, {HI polygon} is thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {HK line} as breadth.
{HK line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {CD polygon} is medial, and {AB polygon} rational, {AB polygon} is thus incommensurable with {CD polygon}.
Hence, {EG polygon} is also incommensurable with {HI polygon}.
And as {EG polygon} (is) to {HI polygon}, so {EH line} is to {HK line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EH line} is also incommensurable in length with {HK line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational.
Thus, {EH line} and {HK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{EK line} is thus a binomial (straight-line), having been divided (into its component terms) at {H point} [Prop. 10.36].
And since {AB polygon} is greater than {CD polygon}, and {AB polygon} (is) equal to {EG polygon}, and {CD polygon} to {HI polygon}, {EG polygon} (is) thus also greater than {HI polygon}.
Thus, {EH line} is also greater than {HK line} [Prop. 5.14].
Therefore, the square on {EH line} is greater than (the square on) {HK line} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({EH line}), or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with {EH line}).
Let it, first of all, be greater by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length with {EH line}).
And the greater (of the two components of {EK line}) {HE line} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down (straight-line) {EF line}.
{EK line} is thus a first binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.5].
And {EF line} (is) rational.
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a first binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.54].
Thus, the square-root of {EI polygon} is a binomial (straight-line).
Hence the square-root of {AD polygon} is also a binomial (straight-line).
And, so, let the square on {EH line} be greater than (the square on) {HK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({EH line}).
And the greater (of the two components of {EK line}) {EH line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {EK line} is a fourth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.8].
And {EF line} (is) rational.
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fourth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the irrational (straight-line) called major [Prop. 10.57].
Thus, the square-root of area {EI polygon} is a major (straight-line). Hence, the square-root of {AD polygon} is also major.

And so, let {AB polygon} be less than {CD polygon}.
Thus, {EG polygon} is also less than {HI polygon}.
Hence, {EH line} is also less than {HK line} [Props. 6.1, 5.14].
And the square on {HK line} is greater than (the square on) {EH line} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({HK line}), or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({HK line}).
Let it, first of all, be greater by the square on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({HK line}).
And the lesser (of the two components of {EK line}) {EH line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {EK line} is a second binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.6].
And {EF line} (is) rational.
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a second binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is a first bimedial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.55].
Thus, the square-root of area {EI polygon} is a first bimedial (straight-line).
Hence, the square-root of {AD polygon} is also a first bimedial (straight-line).
And so, let the square on {HK line} be greater than (the square on) {HE line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({HK line}).
And the lesser (of the two components of {EK line}) {EH line} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {EK line} is a fifth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.9].
And {EF line} (is) rational.
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fifth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area) [Prop. 10.58].
Thus, the square-root of area {EI polygon} is the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).
Hence, the square-root of area {AD polygon} is also the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).

Thus, when a rational and a medial area are added together, four irrational (straight-lines) arise (as the square-roots of the total area)---either a binomial, or a first bimedial, or a major, or the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 72
prose:
When two medial (areas which are) incommensurable with one another are added together, the remaining two irrational (straight-lines) arise (as the square-roots of the total area)---either a second bimedial, or the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

For let the two medial (areas) {AB polygon} and {CD polygon}, (which are) incommensurable with one another, have been added together.
I say that the square-root of area {AD polygon} is either a second bimedial, or the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

For {AB polygon} is either greater than or less than {CD polygon}.
By chance, let {AB polygon}, first of all, be greater than {CD polygon}.
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let {EG polygon}, equal to {AB polygon}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EH line} as breadth, and {HI polygon}, equal to {CD polygon}, producing {HK line} as breadth.
And since {AB polygon} and {CD polygon} are each medial, {EG polygon} and {HI polygon} (are) thus also each medial.
And they are applied to the rational straight-line {FE line}, producing {EH line} and {HK line} (respectively) as breadth.
Thus, {EH line} and {HK line} are each rational (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {AB polygon} is incommensurable with {CD polygon}, and {AB polygon} is equal to {EG polygon}, and {CD polygon} to {HI polygon}, {EG polygon} is thus also incommensurable with {HI polygon}.
And as {EG polygon} (is) to {HI polygon}, so {EH line} is to {HK line} [Prop. 6.1].
EHis thus incommensurable in length with {HK line} [Prop. 10.11].
Thus, {EH line} and {HK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{EK line} is thus a binomial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.36].
And the square on {EH line} is greater than (the square on) {HK line} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({EH line}), or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with {EH line}).
Let it, first of all, be greater by the square on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({EH line}).
And neither of {EH line} or {HK line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {EF line}.
Thus, {EK line} is a third binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.7].
And {EF line} (is) rational.
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a third binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is a second bimedial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.56].
Thus, the square-root of {EI polygon}---that is to say, of {AD polygon}---is a second bimedial.
And so, let the square on {EH line} be greater than (the square) on {HK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({EH line}).
And {EH line} and {HK line} are each incommensurable in length with {EF line}.
Thus, {EK line} is a sixth binomial (straight-line) [Def. 10.10].
And if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a sixth binomial (straight-line) then the square-root of the area is the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas) [Prop. 10.59].
Hence, the square-root of area {AD polygon} is also the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

[So, similarly, we can show that, even if {AB polygon} is less than {CD polygon}, the square-root of area {AD polygon} is either a second bimedial or the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).]

Thus, when two medial (areas which are) incommensurable with one another are added together, the remaining two irrational (straight-lines) arise (as the square-roots of the total area)---either a second bimedial, or the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas).

A binomial (straight-line), and the (other) irrational (straight-lines) after it, are neither the same as a medial (straight-line) nor (the same) as one another.
For the (square) on a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a rational (straight-line which is) also incommensurable in length with (the straight-line) to which it is applied [Prop. 10.22].
And the (square) on a binomial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a first binomial [Prop. 10.60].
And the (square) on a first bimedial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a second binomial [Prop. 10.61].
And the (square) on a second bimedial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a third binomial [Prop. 10.62].
And the (square) on a major (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a fourth binomial [Prop. 10.63].
And the (square) on the square-root of a rational plus a medial (area), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a fifth binomial [Prop. 10.64].
And the (square) on the square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a sixth binomial [Prop. 10.65].
And the aforementioned breadths differ from the first (breadth), and from one another---from the first, because it is rational---and from one another, because they are not the same in order.
Hence, the (previously mentioned) irrational (straight-lines) themselves also differ from one another.

title: Proposition 73
prose:
If a rational (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, is subtracted from a(nother) rational (straight-line) then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called an apotome.

For let the rational (straight-line) {BC magnitude}, which commensurable in square only with the whole, have been subtracted from the rational (straight-line) {AB magnitude}.
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is that irrational (straight-line) called an apotome.

For since {AB magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {BC magnitude}, and as {AB magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {AB magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], the (square) on {AB magnitude} is thus incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
But, the (sum of the) squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.15], and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And, inasmuch as the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} plus the (square) on {CA magnitude} [Prop. 2.7], the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus also incommensurable with the remaining (square) on {AC magnitude} [Props. 10.13, 10.16].
And the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is rational.
{AC magnitude} is thus an irrational (straight-line) [Def. 10.4].
And let it be called an apotome.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 74
prose:
If a medial (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and which contains a rational (area) with the whole, is subtracted from a(nother) medial (straight-line) then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called a first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let the medial (straight-line) {BC magnitude}, which is commensurable in square only with {AB magnitude}, and which makes with {AB magnitude} the rational (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been subtracted from the medial (straight-line) {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.27].
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called the first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For since {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are medial (straight-lines), the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is also medial.
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
The (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is also incommensurable with the remaining (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.7], since if the whole is incommensurable with one of the (constituent magnitudes) then the original magnitudes will also be incommensurable (with one another) [Prop. 10.16].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is irrational.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is an irrational (straight-line) [Def. 10.4].
Let it be called a first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

title: Proposition 75
prose:
If a medial (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and which contains a medial (area) with the whole, is subtracted from a(nother) medial (straight-line) then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let the medial (straight-line) {CB magnitude}, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, {AB magnitude}, and which contains with the whole, {AB magnitude}, the medial (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been subtracted from the medial (straight-line) {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.28].
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let the rational (straight-line) {DI line} be laid down.
And let {DE polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AB line} and {BC line}, have been applied to {DI line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
And let {DH polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been applied to {DI line}, producing {DF line} as breadth.
The remainder {FE polygon} is thus equal to the (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
And since the (squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are medial and commensurable (with one another), {DE polygon} (is) thus also medial [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DI line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
Thus, {DG line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {DI line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
And it is equal to {DH polygon}.
Thus, {DH polygon} is also medial.
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {DI line}, producing {DF line} as breadth.
{DF line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {DI line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} are commensurable in square only, {AB magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {BC magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {AB magnitude} (is) also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Props. 10.21 lem., 10.11].
But, the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.15], and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
And {DE polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, and {DH polygon} to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {DE polygon} [is] incommensurable with {DH polygon}.
And as {DE polygon} (is) to {DH polygon}, so {GD line} (is) to {DF line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {GD line} is incommensurable with {DF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {GD line} and {DF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FG line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
And {DI line} (is) rational.
And the (area) contained by a rational and an irrational (straight-line) is irrational [Prop. 10.20], and its square-root is irrational.

And {AC magnitude} is the square-root of {FE polygon}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is an irrational (straight-line) [Def. 10.4].
And let it be called the second apotome of a medial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 76
prose:
If a straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and with the whole makes the (squares) on them (added) together rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, is subtracted from a(nother) straight-line then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called a minor (straight-line).

For let the straight-line {BC magnitude}, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and fulfils the (other) prescribed (conditions), have been subtracted from the straight-line {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.33].
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is that irrational (straight-line) called minor.

For since the sum of the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) medial, the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
And, via conversion, the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with the remaining (square) on {AC magnitude} [Props. 2.7, 10.16].
And the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} (is) rational.
The (square) on {AC magnitude} (is) thus irrational.
Thus, {AC magnitude} (is) an irrational (straight-line) [Def. 10.4].
Let it be called a minor (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 77
prose:
If a straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and with the whole makes the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them rational, is subtracted from a(nother) straight-line then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called that which makes with a rational (area) a medial whole.

For let the straight-line {BC magnitude}, which is incommensurable in square with {AB magnitude}, and fulfils the (other) prescribed (conditions), have been subtracted from the straight-line {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.34].
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is the aforementioned irrational (straight-line).

For since the sum of the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} rational, the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}.
Thus, the remaining (square) on {AC magnitude} is also incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} [Props. 2.7, 10.16].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is rational.
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is irrational.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is an irrational (straight-line) [Def. 10.4].
And let it be called that which makes with a rational (area) a medial whole.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 78
prose:
If a straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and with the whole makes the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, the (sum of the) squares on them incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by them, is subtracted from a(nother) straight-line then the remainder is an irrational (straight-line).
Let it be called that which makes with a medial (area) a medial whole.

For let the straight-line {BC magnitude}, which is incommensurable in square {AB magnitude}, and fulfils the (other) prescribed (conditions), have been subtracted from the (straight-line) {AB magnitude} [Prop. 10.35].
I say that the remainder {AC magnitude} is the irrational (straight-line) called that which makes with a medial (area) a medial whole.

For let the rational (straight-line) {DI line} be laid down.
And let {DE polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been applied to {DI line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
And let {DH polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, have been subtracted (from {DE polygon}) [producing {DF line} as breadth].
Thus, the remainder {FE polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AC magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Hence, {AC magnitude} is the square-root of {FE polygon}.
And since the sum of the squares on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {DE polygon}, {DE polygon} [is] thus medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DI line}, producing {DG line} as breadth.
Thus, {DG line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {DI line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {DH polygon}, {DH polygon} is thus medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {DI line}, producing {DF line} as breadth.
Thus, {DF line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {DI line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the (sum of the squares) on {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {BC magnitude}, {DE polygon} (is) also incommensurable with {DH polygon}.
And as {DE polygon} (is) to {DH polygon}, so {DG line} also is to {DF line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {DG line} (is) incommensurable (in length) with {DF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational.
Thus, {GD line} and {DF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FG line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
And {FH line} (is) rational.
And the [rectangle] contained by a rational (straight-line) and an apotome is irrational [Prop. 10.20], and its square-root is irrational.
And {AC magnitude} is the square-root of {FE polygon}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} is irrational.
Let it be called that which makes with a medial (area) a medial whole.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 79
prose:
[Only] one rational straight-line, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, can be attached to an apotome.

Let {AB magnitude} be an apotome, with {BC magnitude} (so) attached to it.
{AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
I say that another rational (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {BD magnitude} be (so) attached (to {AB magnitude}).
Thus, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
And since by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area).
For both exceed by the same (area)---(namely), the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Thus, alternately, by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [also] exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area).
And the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For both (are) rational (areas).
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
The very thing is impossible.
For both are medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21], and a medial (area) cannot exceed a(nother) medial (area) by a rational (area) [Prop. 10.26].
Thus, another rational (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

Thus, only one rational (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, can be attached to an apotome.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 80
prose:
Only one medial straight-line, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a rational (area) with the whole, can be attached to a first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let {AB magnitude} be a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), and let {BC magnitude} be (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a rational (area)---(namely, that contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.74].
I say that a(nother) medial (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a rational (area) with the whole, cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {DB magnitude} also be (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a rational (area)---(namely, that) contained by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [Prop. 10.74].
And since by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area).
For [again] both exceed by the same (area)---(namely), the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Thus, alternately, by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area).
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For both (are) rational (areas).
Thus, the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds the (sum of the) [squares] on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
The very thing is impossible.
For both are medial (areas) [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.], and a medial (area) cannot exceed a(nother) medial (area) by a rational (area) [Prop. 10.26].

Thus, only one medial (straight-line), which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a rational (area) with the whole, can be attached to a first apotome of a medial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 81
prose:
Only one medial straight-line, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a medial (area) with the whole, can be attached to a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), with {BC magnitude} (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a medial (area)---(namely, that contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.75].
I say that a(nother) medial straight-line, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a medial (area) with the whole, cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {BD magnitude} be (so) attached.
Thus, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a medial (area)---(namely, that contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [Prop. 10.75].
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let {EG polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EM line} as breadth.
And let {HG polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been subtracted (from {EG polygon}), producing {HM line} as breadth.
The remainder {EL polygon} is thus equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Hence, {AB magnitude} is the square-root of {EL polygon}.
