So, again, let {EI polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EN line} as breadth.
And {EL polygon} is also equal to the square on {AB magnitude}.
Thus, the remainder {HI polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
And since {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are (both) medial (straight-lines), the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is also medial.
And it is equal to {EG polygon}.
Thus, {EG polygon} is also medial [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {EM line} as breadth.
Thus, {EM line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is medial, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
And it is equal to {HG polygon}.
Thus, {HG polygon} is also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {HM line} as breadth.
Thus, {HM line} is also rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are commensurable in square only, {AC magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {CB magnitude}.
And as {AC magnitude} (is) to {CB magnitude}, so the (square) on {AC magnitude} is to the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {AC magnitude} is incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
But, the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AC magnitude}, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
And {EG polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}.
And {GH polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}.
Thus, {EG polygon} is incommensurable with {HG polygon}.
And as {EG polygon} (is) to {HG polygon}, so {EM line} is to {HM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EM line} is incommensurable in length with {MH line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {EM line} and {MH line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EH line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73], and {HM line} (is) attached to it.
So, similarly, we can show that {HN line} (is) also (commensurable in square only with {EN line} and is) attached to ({EH line}).
Thus, different straight-lines, which are commensurable in square only with the whole, are attached to an apotome.
The very thing is impossible [Prop. 10.79].

Thus, only one medial straight-line, which is commensurable in square only with the whole, and contains a medial (area) with the whole, can be attached to a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 82
prose:
Only one straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and (together) with the whole makes the (sum of the) squares on them rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial, can be attached to a minor (straight-line).

Let {AB magnitude} be a minor (straight-line), and let {BC magnitude} be (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial [Prop. 10.76].
I say that another another straight-line fulfilling the same (conditions) cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {BD magnitude} be (so) attached (to {AB magnitude}).
Thus, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, fulfilling the (other) aforementioned (conditions) [Prop. 10.76].
And since by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area) [Prop. 2.7].
And the (sum of the) squares on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the) squares on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For both are rational (areas).
Thus, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
The very thing is impossible.
For both are medial (areas) [Prop. 10.26].

Thus, only one straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and (with the whole) makes the squares on them (added) together rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial, can be attached to a minor (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 83
prose:
Only one straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and (together) with the whole makes the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them rational, can be attached to that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

Let {AB magnitude} be a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole, and let {BC magnitude} be (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, fulfilling the (other) proscribed (conditions) [Prop. 10.77].
I say that another (straight-line) fulfilling the same (conditions) cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {BD magnitude} be (so) attached (to {AB magnitude}).
Thus, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also straight-lines (which are) incommensurable in square, fulfilling the (other) prescribed (conditions) [Prop. 10.77].
Therefore, analogously to the (propositions) before this, since by whatever (area) the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by this (same area).
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} exceeds twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
For they are (both) rational (areas).
Thus, the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} also exceeds the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} by a rational (area).
The very thing is impossible.
For both are medial (areas) [Prop. 10.26].

Thus, another straight-line cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and fulfills the (other) aforementioned (conditions) with the whole.
Thus, only one (such straight-line) can be (so) attached.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 84
prose:
Only one straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and (together) with the whole makes the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, incommensurable with the sum of the (squares) on them, can be attached to that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

Let {AB magnitude} be a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole, {BC magnitude} being (so) attached to it.
Thus, {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, fulfilling the (other) aforementioned (conditions) [Prop. 10.78].
I say that a(nother) (straight-line) fulfilling the aforementioned (conditions) cannot be attached to {AB magnitude}.

For, if possible, let {BD magnitude} be (so) attached.
Hence, {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are also (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the squares on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} (added) together medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} medial, and, moreover, the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [Prop. 10.78].
And let the rational (straight-line) {EF line} be laid down.
And let {EG polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EM line} as breadth.
And let {HG polygon}, equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {HM line} as breadth.
Thus, the remaining (square) on {AB magnitude} is equal to {EL polygon} [Prop. 2.7].
Thus, {AB magnitude} is the square-root of {EL polygon}.
Again, let {EI polygon}, equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, have been applied to {EF line}, producing {EN line} as breadth.
And the (square) on {AB magnitude} is also equal to {EL polygon}.
Thus, the remaining twice the (rectangle contained) by {AD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} [is] equal to {HI polygon} [Prop. 2.7].
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {EG polygon}, {EG polygon} is thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {EM line} as breadth.
{EM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {HG polygon}, {HG polygon} is thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {HM line} as breadth.
{HM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {EF line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the (sum of the squares) on {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AC magnitude} and {CB magnitude}, {EG polygon} is also incommensurable with {HG polygon}.
Thus, {EM line} is also incommensurable in length with {MH line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {EM line} and {MH line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EH line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73], with {HM line} attached to it.
So, similarly, we can show that {EH line} is again an apotome, with {HN line} attached to it.
Thus, different rational (straight-lines), which are commensurable in square only with the whole, are attached to an apotome.
The very thing was shown (to be) impossible [Prop. 10.79].
Thus, another straight-line cannot be (so) attached to {AB magnitude}.

Thus, only one straight-line, which is incommensurable in square with the whole, and (together) with the whole makes the squares on them (added) together medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, moreover, the (sum of the) squares on them incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by them, can be attached to {AB magnitude}.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Definitions III
prose:
11. Given a rational (straight-line) and an apotome, if the square on the whole is greater than the (square on a straight-line) attached (to the apotome) by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with (the whole), and the whole is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), then let the (apotome) be called a first apotome.

12. And if the attached (straight-line) is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), and the square on the whole is greater than (the square on) the attached (straight-line) by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with (the whole), then let the (apotome) be called a second apotome.

13. And if neither of (the whole or the attached straight-line) is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), and the square on the whole is greater than (the square on) the attached (straight-line) by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with (the whole), then let the (apotome) be called a third apotome.

14. Again, if the square on the whole is greater than (the square on) the attached (straight-line) by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable [in length] with (the whole), and the whole is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), then let the (apotome) be called a fourth apotome.

15. And if the attached (straight-line is commensurable), a fifth (apotome).

16. And if neither (the whole nor the attached straight-line is commensurable), a sixth (apotome).

title: Proposition 85
prose:
To find a first apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude} be laid down.
And let {BG magnitude} be commensurable in length with {A magnitude}.
{BG magnitude} is thus also a rational (straight-line).
And let two square numbers {DE magnitude} and {EF magnitude} be laid down, and let their difference {FD magnitude} be not square [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
Thus, {ED magnitude} does not have to {DF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let it have been contrived that as {ED magnitude} (is) to {DF magnitude}, so the square on {BG magnitude} (is) to the square on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6. corr.].
Thus, the (square) on {BG magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {GC magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {GC magnitude} is also rational.
And since {ED magnitude} does not have to {DF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {BG magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {GC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {BG magnitude} and {GC magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a first (apotome).

Let the (square) on {H magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {BG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
And since as {ED magnitude} is to {FD magnitude}, so the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GC magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {DE magnitude} is to {EF magnitude}, so the (square) on {GB magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {DE magnitude} has to {EF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square-number (has) to (some) square-number.
For each is a square (number).
Thus, the (square) on {GB magnitude} also has to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is commensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on {H magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({BG magnitude}).
And the whole, {BG magnitude}, is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is a first apotome [Def. 10.11].

Thus, the first apotome {BC magnitude} has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to find.

title: Proposition 86
prose:
To find a second apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}, and {GC magnitude} (which is) commensurable in length with {A magnitude}, be laid down.
Thus, {GC magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).
And let the two square numbers {DE magnitude} and {EF magnitude} be laid down, and let their difference {DF magnitude} be not square [Prop. 10.28 lem. I].
And let it have been contrived that as {FD magnitude} (is) to {DE magnitude}, so the square on {CG magnitude} (is) to the square on {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Thus, the square on {CG magnitude} is commensurable with the square on {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {CG magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {GB magnitude} [is] also rational.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).
And since the square on {GC magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {GB magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, {CG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {CG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that it is also a second (apotome).

For let the (square) on {H magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {BG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Therefore, since as the (square) on {BG magnitude} is to the (square) on {GC magnitude}, so the number {ED magnitude} (is) to the number {DF magnitude}, thus, also, via conversion, as the (square) on {BG magnitude} is to the (square) on {H magnitude}, so {DE magnitude} (is) to {EF magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {DE magnitude} and {EF magnitude} are each square (numbers).
Thus, the (square) on {BG magnitude} has to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is commensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on {H magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({BG magnitude}).
And the attachment {CG magnitude} is commensurable (in length) with the (prevously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is a second apotome [Def. 10.12].

Thus, the second apotome {BC magnitude} has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 87
prose:
To find a third apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude} be laid down.
And let the three numbers, {E magnitude}, {BC magnitude}, and {CD magnitude}, not having to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, be laid down.
And let {CB magnitude} have to {BD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let it have been contrived that as {E magnitude} (is) to {BC magnitude}, so the square on {A magnitude} (is) to the square on {FG magnitude}, and as {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so the square on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
Therefore, since as {E magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the square on {A magnitude} (is) to the square on {FG magnitude}, the square on {A magnitude} is thus commensurable with the square on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the square on {A magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).
And since {E magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the square on {A magnitude} thus does not have to the [square] on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {A magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Again, since as {BC magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the square on {FG magnitude} is to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, the square on {FG magnitude} is thus commensurable with the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {GH magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {GH magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).
And since {BC magnitude} does not have to {CD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {FG magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And both are rational (straight-lines).
{FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a third (apotome).

For since as {E magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the square on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and as {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {HG magnitude}, thus, via equality, as {E magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {HG magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
And {E magnitude} does not have to {CD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {A magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
{A magnitude} (is) thus incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, neither of {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Therefore, let the (square) on {K magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {FG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Therefore, since as {BC magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {BC magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so the square on {FG magnitude} (is) to the square on {K magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {BC magnitude} has to {BD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} also has to the (square) on {K magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
{FG magnitude} is thus commensurable in length with {K magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {FG magnitude} is (thus) greater than (the square on) {GH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({FG magnitude}).
And neither of {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is a third apotome [Def. 10.13].

Thus, the third apotome {FH magnitude} has been found.
(Which is) very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 88
prose:
To find a fourth apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}, and {BG magnitude} (which is) commensurable in length with {A magnitude}, be laid down.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And let the two numbers {DF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} be laid down such that the whole, {DE magnitude}, does not have to each of {DF magnitude} and {EF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let it have been contrived that as {DE magnitude} (is) to {EF magnitude}, so the square on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].
The (square) on {BG magnitude} is thus commensurable with the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {GC magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {GC magnitude} (is) a rational (straight-line).
And since {DE magnitude} does not have to {EF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {BG magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {GC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {BG magnitude} and {GC magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
[So, I say that (it is) also a fourth (apotome).]

Now, let the (square) on {H magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {BG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Therefore, since as {DE magnitude} is to {EF magnitude}, so the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GC magnitude}, thus, also, via conversion, as {ED magnitude} is to {DF magnitude}, so the (square) on {GB magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {ED magnitude} does not have to {DF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {GB magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on {H magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square) on {GC magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BG magnitude}).
And the whole, {BG magnitude}, is commensurable in length with the the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is a fourth apotome [Def. 10.14].

Thus, a fourth apotome has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 89
prose:
To find a fifth apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude} be laid down, and let {CG magnitude} be commensurable in length with {A magnitude}.
Thus, {CG magnitude} [is] a rational (straight-line).
And let the two numbers {DF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} be laid down such that {DE magnitude} again does not have to each of {DF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let it have been contrived that as {FE magnitude} (is) to {ED magnitude}, so the (square) on {CG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {GB magnitude} (is) also rational [Prop. 10.6].
Thus, {BG magnitude} is also rational.
And since as {DE magnitude} is to {EF magnitude}, so the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GC magnitude}.
And {DE magnitude} does not have to {EF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
The (square) on {BG magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {GC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
{BG magnitude} and {GC magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a fifth (apotome).

For, let the (square) on {H magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {BG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GC magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Therefore, since as the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GC magnitude}, so {DE magnitude} (is) to {EF magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {ED magnitude} is to {DF magnitude}, so the (square) on {BG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {H magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {ED magnitude} does not have to {DF magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {BG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {H magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {BG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {H magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {BG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on {H magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {GB magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GC magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({GB magnitude}).
And the attachment {CG magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} is a fifth apotome [Def. 10.15].

Thus, the fifth apotome {BC magnitude} has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 90
prose:
To find a sixth apotome.

Let the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}, and the three numbers {E magnitude}, {BC magnitude}, and {CD magnitude}, not having to one another the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, be laid down.
Furthermore, let {CB magnitude} also not have to {BD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
And let it have been contrived that as {E magnitude} (is) to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and as {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6 corr.].

Therefore, since as {E magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) thus commensurable with the (square) on {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is also a rational (straight-line).
And since {E magnitude} does not have to {BC magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {A magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {FG magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
Thus, {A magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {FG magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Again, since as {BC magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) thus commensurable with the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.6].
And the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {GH magnitude} (is) also rational.
Thus, {GH magnitude} (is) also rational.
And since {BC magnitude} does not have to {CD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number, the (square) on {FG magnitude} thus does not have to the (square) on {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square (number) has to (some) square (number) either.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And both are rational (straightlines).
Thus, {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a sixth (apotome).

For since as {E magnitude} is to {BC magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FG magnitude}, and as {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, thus, via equality, as {E magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 5.22].
And {E magnitude} does not have to {CD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {A magnitude} does not have to the (square) {GH magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
{A magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
Thus, neither of {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} is commensurable in length with the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Therefore, let the (square) on {K magnitude} be that (area) by which the (square) on {FG magnitude} is greater than the (square) on {GH magnitude} [Prop. 10.13 lem.].
Therefore, since as {BC magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {GH magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {CB magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so the (square) on {FG magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {K magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
And {CB magnitude} does not have to {BD magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number.
Thus, the (square) on {FG magnitude} does not have to the (square) on {K magnitude} the ratio which (some) square number (has) to (some) square number either.
{FG magnitude} is thus incommensurable in length with {K magnitude} [Prop. 10.9].
And the square on {FG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GH magnitude} by the (square) on {K magnitude}.
Thus, the square on {FG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({FG magnitude}).
And neither of {FG magnitude} and {GH magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}.
Thus, {FH magnitude} is a sixth apotome [Def. 10.16].

Thus, the sixth apotome {FH magnitude} has been found.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 91
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a first apotome then the square-root of the area is an apotome.

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the first apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is an apotome.

For since {AD line} is a first apotome, let {DG line} be its attachment.
Thus, {AG line} and {DG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
And the whole, {AG line}, is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on {AG line} is greater than (the square on) {GD line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.11].
Thus, if (an area) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {DG line} is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) commensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.17].
Let {DG line} have been cut in half at {E point}.
And let (an area) equal to the (square) on {EG line} have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
{AF line} is thus commensurable (in length) with {FG line}.
And let {EH line}, {FI line}, and {GK line} have been drawn through points {E point}, {F point}, and {G point} (respectively), parallel to {AC line}.

And since {AF line} is commensurable in length with {FG line}, {AG line} is thus also commensurable in length with each of {AF line} and {FG line} [Prop. 10.15].
But {AG line} is commensurable (in length) with {AC line}.
Thus, each of {AF line} and {FG line} is also commensurable in length with {AC line} [Prop. 10.12].
And {AC line} is a rational (straight-line).
Thus, {AF line} and {FG line} (are) each also rational (straight-lines).
Hence, {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} are also each rational (areas) [Prop. 10.19].
And since {DE line} is commensurable in length with {EG line}, {DG line} is thus also commensurable in length with each of {DE line} and {EG line} [Prop. 10.15].
And {DG line} (is) rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line}.
{DE line} and {EG line} (are) thus each rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {DH polygon} and {EK polygon} are each medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21].

So let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, be laid down.
And let the square {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, have been subtracted (from {LM polygon}), having with it the common angle {LPM angle}.
Thus, the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let the (rest of the) figure have been drawn.
Therefore, since the rectangle contained by {AF line} and {FG line} is equal to the square {EG line}, thus as {AF line} is to {EG line}, so {EG line} (is) to {FG line} [Prop. 6.17].
But, as {AF line} (is) to {EG line}, so {AI polygon} (is) to {EK polygon}, and as {EG line} (is) to {FG line}, so {EK polygon} is to {KF polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EK polygon} is the mean proportional to {AI polygon} and {KF polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
And {MN polygon} is also the mean proportional to {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}, as shown before [Prop. 10.53 lem.].
And {AI polygon} is equal to the square {LM polygon}, and {KF polygon} to {NO polygon}.
Thus, {MN polygon} is also equal to {EK polygon}.
But, {EK polygon} is equal to {DH polygon}, and {MN polygon} to {LO polygon} [Prop. 1.43].
Thus, {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and {NO polygon}.
And {AK polygon} is also equal to (the sum of) the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}.
Thus, the remainder {AB polygon} is equal to {ST polygon}.
And {ST polygon} is the square on {LN line}.
Thus, the square on {LN line} is equal to {AB polygon}.
Thus, {LN line} is the square-root of {AB polygon}.
So, I say that {LN line} is an apotome.

For since {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} are each rational (areas), and are equal to {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} (respectively), thus {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}---that is to say, the (squares) on each of {LP line} and {PN line} (respectively)---are also each rational (areas).
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are also each rational (straight-lines).
Again, since {DH polygon} is a medial (area), and is equal to {LO polygon}, {LO polygon} is thus also a medial (area).
Therefore, since {LO polygon} is medial, and {NO polygon} rational, {LO polygon} is thus incommensurable with {NO polygon}.
And as {LO polygon} (is) to {NO polygon}, so {LP line} is to {PN line} [Prop. 6.1].
{LP line} is thus incommensurable in length with {PN line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {LN line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
Thus, the square-root of area {AB polygon} is an apotome.

Thus, if an area is contained by a rational (straight-line), and so on ....

title: Proposition 92
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a second apotome then the square-root of the area is a first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the second apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is the first apotome of a medial(straight-line).

For let {DG line} be an attachment to {AD line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {GD line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73], and the attachment {DG line} is commensurable (in length) with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on the whole, {AG line}, is greater than (the square on) the attachment, {GD line}, by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.12].
Therefore, since the square on {AG line} is greater than (the square on) {GD line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AG line}), thus if (an area) equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {GD line} is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) commensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.17].
Therefore, let {DG line} have been cut in half at {E point}.
And let (an area) equal to the (square) on {EG line} have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
Thus, {AF line} is commensurable in length with {FG line}.
{AG line} is thus also commensurable in length with each of {AF line} and {FG line} [Prop. 10.15].
And {AG line} (is) a rational (straight-line), and incommensurable in length with {AC line}.
{AF line} and {FG line} are thus also each rational (straight-lines), and incommensurable in length with {AC line} [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} are each medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {DE line} is commensurable (in length) with {EG line}, thus {DG line} is also commensurable (in length) with each of {DE line} and {EG line} [Prop. 10.15].
But, {DG line} is commensurable in length with {AC line} [thus, {DE line} and {EG line} are also each rational, and commensurable in length with {AC line}].
Thus, {DH polygon} and {EK polygon} are each rational (areas) [Prop. 10.19].

Therefore, let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, have been constructed.
And let {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, which is about the same angle {LPM angle} as {LM polygon}, have been subtracted (from {LM polygon}).
Thus, the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let the (rest of the) figure have been drawn.
Therefore, since {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} are medial (areas), and are equal to the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} (respectively), [thus] the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} are also medial.
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are also medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line} is equal to the (square) on {EG line}, thus as {AF line} is to {EG line}, so {EG line} (is) to {FG line} [Prop. 10.17].
But, as {AF line} (is) to {EG line}, so {AI polygon} (is) to {EK polygon}.
And as {EG line} (is) to {FG line}, so {EK polygon} [is] to {FK polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EK polygon} is the mean proportional to {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
And {MN polygon} is also the mean proportional to the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} [Prop. 10.53 lem.].
And {AI polygon} is equal to {LM polygon}, and {FK polygon} to {NO polygon}.
Thus, {MN polygon} is also equal to {EK polygon}.
But, {DH polygon} [is] equal to {EK polygon}, and {LO polygon} equal to {MN polygon} [Prop. 1.43].
Thus, the whole (of) {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and {NO polygon}.
Therefore, since the whole (of) {AK polygon} is equal to {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}, of which {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and {NO polygon}, the remainder {AB polygon} is thus equal to {TS polygon}.
And {TS polygon} is the (square) on {LN line}.
Thus, the (square) on {LN line} is equal to the area {AB polygon}.
{LN line} is thus the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
[So], I say that {LN line} is the first apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For since {EK polygon} is a rational (area), and is equal to {LO polygon}, {LO polygon}---that is to say, the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}---is thus a rational (area).
And {NO polygon} was shown (to be) a medial (area).
Thus, {LO polygon} is incommensurable with {NO polygon}.
And as {LO polygon} (is) to {NO polygon}, so {LP line} is to {PN line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are incommensurable in length [Prop. 10.11].
{LP line} and {PN line} are thus medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and which contain a rational (area).
Thus, {LN line} is the first apotome of a medial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.74].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.

Thus, the square root of area {AB polygon} is the first apotome of a medial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 93
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a third apotome then the square-root of the area is a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the third apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is the second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For let {DG line} be an attachment to {AD line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {GD line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73], and neither of {AG line} and {GD line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on the whole, {AG line}, is greater than (the square on) the attachment, {DG line}, by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.13].
Therefore, since the square on {AG line} is greater than (the square on) {GD line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AG line}), thus if (an area) equal to the fourth part of the square on {DG line} is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) commensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.17].
Therefore, let {DG line} have been cut in half at {E point}.
And let (an area) equal to the (square) on {EG line} have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
And let {EH line}, {FI line}, and {GK line} have been drawn through points {E point}, {F point}, and {G point} (respectively), parallel to {AC line}.
Thus, {AF line} and {FG line} are commensurable (in length).
{AI polygon} (is) thus also commensurable with {FK polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And since {AF line} and {FG line} are commensurable in length, {AG line} is thus also commensurable in length with each of {AF line} and {FG line} [Prop. 10.15].
And {AG line} (is) rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line}.
Hence, {AF line} and {FG line} (are) also (rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line}) [Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} are each medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {DE line} is commensurable in length with {EG line}, {DG line} is also commensurable in length with each of {DE line} and {EG line} [Prop. 10.15].
And {GD line} (is) rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line}.
Thus, {DE line} and {EG line} (are) each also rational, and incommensurable in length with {AC line} [Prop. 10.13].
{DH polygon} and {EK polygon} are thus each medial (areas) [Prop. 10.21].
And since {AG line} and {GD line} are commensurable in square only, {AG line} is thus incommensurable in length with {GD line}.
But, {AG line} is commensurable in length with {AF line}, and {DG line} with {EG line}.
Thus, {AF line} is incommensurable in length with {EG line} [Prop. 10.13].
And as {AF line} (is) to {EG line}, so {AI polygon} is to {EK polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {AI polygon} is incommensurable with {EK polygon} [Prop. 10.11].

Therefore, let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, have been constructed.
And let {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, which is about the same angle as {LM polygon}, have been subtracted (from {LM polygon}).
Thus, {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let the (rest of the) figure have been drawn.
Therefore, since the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line} is equal to the (square) on {EG line}, thus as {AF line} is to {EG line}, so {EG line} (is) to {FG line} [Prop. 6.17].
But, as {AF line} (is) to {EG line}, so {AI polygon} is to {EK polygon} [Prop.6.1].
And as {EG line} (is) to {FG line}, so {EK polygon} is to {FK polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
And thus as {AI polygon} (is) to {EK polygon}, so {EK polygon} (is) to {FK polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, {EK polygon} is the mean proportional to {AI polygon} and {FK polygon}.
And {MN polygon} is also the mean proportional to the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} [Prop. 10.53 lem.].
And {AI polygon} is equal to {LM polygon}, and {FK polygon} to {NO polygon}.
Thus, {EK polygon} is also equal to {MN polygon}.
But, {MN polygon} is equal to {LO polygon}, and {EK polygon} [is] equal to {DH polygon} [Prop. 1.43].
And thus the whole of {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and {NO polygon}.
And {AK polygon} (is) also equal to {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}.
Thus, the remainder {AB polygon} is equal to {ST polygon}---that is to say, to the square on {LN line}.
Thus, {LN line} is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
I say that {LN line} is the second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

For since {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} were shown (to be) medial (areas), and are equal to the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} (respectively), the (squares) on each of {LP line} and {PN line} (are) thus also medial.
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} (are) each medial (straight-lines).
And since {AI polygon} is commensurable with {FK polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11], the (square) on {LP line} (is) thus also commensurable with the (square) on {PN line}.
Again, since {AI polygon} was shown (to be) incommensurable with {EK polygon}, {LM polygon} is thus also incommensurable with {MN polygon}---that is to say, the (square) on {LP line} with the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}.
Hence, {LP line} is also incommensurable in length with {PN line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
So, I say that they also contain a medial (area).

For since {EK polygon} was shown (to be) a medial (area), and is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}, the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line} is thus also medial.
Hence, {LP line} and {PN line} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and which contain a medial (area).
Thus, {LN line} is the second apotome of a medial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.75].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.

Thus, the square-root of area {AB polygon} is the second apotome of a medial (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 94
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fourth apotome then the square-root of the area is a minor (straight-line).

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the fourth apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is a minor (straight-line).
For let {DG line} be an attachment to {AD line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {DG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73], and {AG line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on the whole, {AG line}, is greater than (the square on) the attachment, {DG line}, by the square on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.14].
Therefore, since the square on {AG line} is greater than (the square on) {GD line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({AG line}), thus if (some area), equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {DG line}, is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) incommensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.18].
Therefore, let {DG line} have been cut in half at {E point}, and let (some area), equal to the (square) on {EG line}, have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, and let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
Thus, {AF line} is incommensurable in length with {FG line}.
Therefore, let {EH line}, {FI line}, and {GK line} have been drawn through {E point}, {F point}, and {G point} (respectively), parallel to {AC line} and {BD line}.
Therefore, since {AG line} is rational, and commensurable in length with {AC line}, the whole (area) {AK polygon} is thus rational [Prop. 10.19].
Again, since {DG line} is incommensurable in length with {AC line}, and both are rational (straight-lines), {DK polygon} is thus a medial (area) [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {AF line} is incommensurable in length with {FG line}, {AI polygon} (is) thus also incommensurable with {FK polygon} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].

Therefore, let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, have been constructed.
And let {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, (and) about the same angle, {LPM angle}, have been subtracted (from {LM polygon}).
Thus, the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let the (rest of the) figure have been drawn.
Therefore, since the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line} is equal to the (square) on {EG line}, thus, proportionally, as {AF line} is to {EG line}, so {EG line} (is) to {FG line} [Prop. 6.17].
But, as {AF line} (is) to {EG line}, so {AI polygon} is to {EK polygon}, and as {EG line} (is) to {FG line}, so {EK polygon} is to {FK polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {EK polygon} is the mean proportional to {AI polygon} and {FK polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
And {MN polygon} is also the mean proportional to the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} [Prop. 10.13 lem.], and {AI polygon} is equal to {LM polygon}, and {FK polygon} to {NO polygon}.
{EK polygon} is thus also equal to {MN polygon}.
But, {DH polygon} is equal to {EK polygon}, and {LO polygon} is equal to {MN polygon} [Prop. 1.43].
Thus, the whole of {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and {NO polygon}.
Therefore, since the whole of {AK polygon} is equal to the (sum of the) squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon}, of which {DK polygon} is equal to the gnomon {UVW given} and the square {NO polygon}, the remainder {AB polygon} is thus equal to {ST polygon}---that is to say, to the square on {LN line}.
Thus, {LN line} is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
I say that {LN line} is the irrational (straight-line which is) called minor.

For since {AK polygon} is rational, and is equal to the (sum of the) squares {LP line} and {PN line}, the sum of the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} is thus rational.
Again, since {DK polygon} is medial, and {DK polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}, thus twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line} is medial.
And since {AI polygon} was shown (to be) incommensurable with {FK polygon}, the square on {LP line} (is) thus also incommensurable with the square on {PN line}.
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them medial.
{LN line} is thus the irrational (straight-line) called minor [Prop. 10.76].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.

Thus, the square-root of area {AB polygon} is a minor (straight-line).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 95
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fifth apotome then the square-root of the area is that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the fifth apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

For let {DG line} be an attachment to {AD line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {DG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73], and the attachment {GD line} is commensurable in length the the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on the whole, {AG line}, is greater than (the square on) the attachment, {DG line}, by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.15].
Thus, if (some area), equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {DG line}, is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) incommensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.18].
Therefore, let {DG line} have been divided in half at point {E point}, and let (some area), equal to the (square) on {EG line}, have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, and let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
Thus, {AF line} is incommensurable in length with {FG line}.
And since {AG line} is incommensurable in length with {CA line}, and both are rational (straight-lines), {AK polygon} is thus a medial (area) [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {DG line} is rational, and commensurable in length with {AC line}, {DK polygon} is a rational (area) [Prop. 10.19].

Therefore, let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, have been constructed.
And let the square {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, (and) about the same angle, {LPM angle}, have been subtracted (from {NO polygon}).
Thus, the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let (the rest of) the figure have been drawn.
So, similarly (to the previous propositions), we can show that {LN line} is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
I say that {LN line} is that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

For since {AK polygon} was shown (to be) a medial (area), and is equal to (the sum of) the squares on {LP line} and {PN line}, the sum of the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} is thus medial.
Again, since {DK polygon} is rational, and is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}, (the latter) is also rational.
And since {AI polygon} is incommensurable with {FK polygon}, the (square) on {LP line} is thus also incommensurable with the (square) on {PN line}.
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them rational.
Thus, the remainder {LN line} is the irrational (straight-line) called that which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.77].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.

Thus, the square-root of area {AB polygon} is that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 96
prose:
If an area is contained by a rational (straight-line) and a sixth apotome then the square-root of the area is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For let the area {AB polygon} have been contained by the rational (straight-line) {AC line} and the sixth apotome {AD line}.
I say that the square-root of area {AB polygon} is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For let {DG line} be an attachment to {AD line}.
Thus, {AG line} and {GD line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73], and neither of them is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {AC line}, and the square on the whole, {AG line}, is greater than (the square on) the attachment, {DG line}, by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({AG line}) [Def. 10.16].
Therefore, since the square on {AG line} is greater than (the square on) {GD line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable in length with ({AG line}), thus if (some area), equal to the fourth part of square on {DG line}, is applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure, then it divides ({AG line}) into (parts which are) incommensurable (in length) [Prop. 10.18].
Therefore, let {DG line} have been cut in half at [point] {E line}.
And let (some area), equal to the (square) on {EG line}, have been applied to {AG line}, falling short by a square figure.
And let it be the (rectangle contained) by {AF line} and {FG line}.
{AF line} is thus incommensurable in length with {FG line}.
And as {AF line} (is) to {FG line}, so {AI polygon} is to {FK polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {AI polygon} is incommensurable with {FK polygon} [Prop. 10.11].
And since {AG line} and {AC line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, {AK polygon} is a medial (area) [Prop. 10.21].
Again, since {AC line} and {DG line} are rational (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in length, {DK polygon} is also a medial (area) [Prop. 10.21].
Therefore, since {AG line} and {GD line} are commensurable in square only, {AG line} is thus incommensurable in length with {GD line}.
And as {AG line} (is) to {GD line}, so {AK polygon} is to {KD polygon} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {AK polygon} is incommensurable with {KD polygon} [Prop. 10.11].

Therefore, let the square {LM polygon}, equal to {AI polygon}, have been constructed.
And let {NO polygon}, equal to {FK polygon}, (and) about the same angle, have been subtracted (from {LM polygon}).
Thus, the squares {LM polygon} and {NO polygon} are about the same diagonal [Prop. 6.26].
Let {PR line} be their (common) diagonal, and let (the rest of) the figure have been drawn.
So, similarly to the above, we can show that {LN line} is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.
I say that {LN line} is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For since {AK polygon} was shown (to be) a medial (area), and is equal to the (sum of the) squares on {LP line} and {PN line}, the sum of the (squares) on {LP line} and {PN line} is medial.
Again, since {DK polygon} was shown (to be) a medial (area), and is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}, twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line} is also medial.
And since {AK polygon} was shown (to be) incommensurable with {DK polygon}, [thus] the (sum of the) squares on {LP line} and {PN line} is also incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {LP line} and {PN line}.
And since {AI polygon} is incommensurable with {FK polygon}, the (square) on {LP line} (is) thus also incommensurable with the (square) on {PN line}.
Thus, {LP line} and {PN line} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by medial, and, furthermore, the (sum of the) squares on them incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by them.
Thus, {LN line} is the irrational (straight-line) called that which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.78].
And it is the square-root of area {AB polygon}.

Thus, the square-root of area ({AB polygon}) is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 97
prose:
The (square) on an apotome, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a first apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be an apotome, and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a first apotome.

For let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
And let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon}, (equal) to the (square) on {BG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}.
Thus, the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which {CE polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}.
The remainder {FL polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Let {FM line} have been cut in half at point {N point}.
And let {NO line} have been drawn through {N point}, parallel to {CD line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {LN polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And since the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is rational, and {DM polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {DM polygon} is thus rational.
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
Thus, {CM line} is rational, and commensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.20].
Again, since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is medial, and {FL polygon} (is) equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {FL polygon} (is) thus a medial (area).
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
{FM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} medial, the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, and {FL polygon} to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
{DM polygon} is thus incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {DM polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} is to {FM line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CM line} is thus incommensurable in length with {FM line} [Prop. 10.11].
And both are rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a first (apotome).

For since the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and {CH polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon} equal to the (square) on {BG magnitude}, and {NL polygon} to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {NL polygon} is thus also the mean proportional to {CH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {CH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}.
But, as {CH polygon} (is) to {NL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {NM line}, and as {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {NM line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line} is equal to the (square) on {NM line}---that is to say, to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line} [Prop. 6.17].
And since the (square) on {AG magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {GB magnitude}, {CH polygon} [is] also commensurable with {KL polygon}.
And as {CH polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {CK line} (is) to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CK line} is thus commensurable (in length) with {KM line} [Prop. 10.11].
Therefore, since {CM line} and {MF line} are two unequal straight-lines, and the (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line}, equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line}, has been applied to {CM line}, falling short by a square figure, and {CK line} is commensurable (in length) with {KM line}, the square on {CM line} is thus greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.17].
And {CM line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
Thus, {CF line} is a first apotome [Def. 10.15].

Thus, the (square) on an apotome, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a first apotome as breadth.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 98
prose:
The (square) on a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a second apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a second apotome.

For let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a rational (area) [Prop. 10.74].
And let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CK line} as breadth, and {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}, producing {KM line} as breadth.
Thus, the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
Thus, {CL polygon} (is) also a medial (area) [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
{CM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which the (square) on {AB magnitude} is equal to {CE polygon}, the remainder, twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, is thus equal to {FL polygon} [Prop. 2.7].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [is] rational.
Thus, {FL polygon} (is) rational.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {FE line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
{FM line} is thus also rational, and commensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.20].
Therefore, since the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}---that is to say, {CL polygon}---is medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}---that is to say, {FL polygon}---(is) rational, {CL polygon} is thus incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {CL polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} is to {FM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {CM line} (is) incommensurable in length with {FM line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a second (apotome).

For let {FM line} have been cut in half at {N point}.
And let {NO line} have been drawn through (point) {N point}, parallel to {CD line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {NL polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the squares on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and the (square) on {AG magnitude} is equal to {CH polygon}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} to {NL polygon}, and the (square) on {BG magnitude} to {KL polygon}, {NL polygon} is thus also the mean proportional to {CH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {CH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon} [Prop. 5.11].
But, as {CH polygon} (is) to {NL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {NM line}, and as {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {NM line} is to {MK line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, as {CK line} (is) to {NM line}, so {NM line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 5.11].
The (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line} is thus equal to the (square) on {NM line} [Prop. 6.17]---that is to say, to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line} [and since the (square) on {AG magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {BG magnitude}, {CH polygon} is also commensurable with {KL polygon}---that is to say, {CK line} with {KM line}].
Therefore, since {CM line} and {MF line} are two unequal straight-lines, and the (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line}, equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {MF line}, has been applied to the greater {CM line}, falling short by a square figure, and divides it into commensurable (parts), the square on {CM line} is thus greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable in length with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.17].
The attachment {FM line} is also commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
{CF line} is thus a second apotome [Def. 10.16].

Thus, the (square) on a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a second apotome as breadth.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 99
prose:
The (square) on a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a third apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be the second apotome of a medial (straight-line), and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a third apotome.

For let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, containing a medial (area) [Prop. 10.75].
And let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CK line} as breadth.
And let {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {BG magnitude}, have been applied to {KH line}, producing {KM line} as breadth.
Thus, the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [and the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is medial].
{CL polygon} (is) thus also medial [Props. 10.15, 10.23 corr.].
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
Thus, {CM line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which {CE polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, the remainder {LF polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Therefore, let {FM line} have been cut in half at point {N point}.
And let {NO line} have been drawn parallel to {CD line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {NL polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} (is) medial.
Thus, {FL polygon} is also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
{FM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are commensurable in square only, {AG magnitude} [is] thus incommensurable in length with {GB magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {AG magnitude} is also incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
But, the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} with the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
The (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is thus incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
But, {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, and {FL polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
Thus, {CL polygon} is incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {CL polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} is to {FM line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CM line} is thus incommensurable in length with {FM line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a third (apotome).

For since the (square) on {AG magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {GB magnitude}, {CH polygon} (is) thus also commensurable with {KL polygon}.
Hence, {CK line} (is) also (commensurable in length) with {KM line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and {CH polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon} equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}, and {NL polygon} equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {NL polygon} is thus also the mean proportional to {CH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {CH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}.
But, as {CH polygon} (is) to {NL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {NM line}, and as {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {NM line} (is) to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, as {CK line} (is) to {MN line}, so {MN line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 5.11].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line} is equal to the [(square) on {MN line}---that is to say, to the] fourth part of the (square) on {FM line} [Prop. 6.17].
Therefore, since {CM line} and {MF line} are two unequal straight-lines, and (some area), equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line}, has been applied to {CM line}, falling short by a square figure, and divides it into commensurable (parts), the square on {CM line} is thus greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.17].
And neither of {CM line} and {MF line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
{CF line} is thus a third apotome [Def. 10.13].

Thus, the (square) on a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a third apotome as breadth.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 100
prose:
The (square) on a minor (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a fourth apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be a minor (straight-line), and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a fourth apotome.

For let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} medial [Prop. 10.76].
And let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CK line} as breadth, and {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {BG magnitude}, producing {KM line} as breadth.
Thus, the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And the sum of the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is rational.
{CL polygon} is thus also rational.
