And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
Thus, {CM line} (is) also rational, and commensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.20].
And since the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which {CE polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, the remainder {FL polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Therefore, let {FM line} have been cut in half at point {N point}.
And let {NO line} have been drawn through {N point}, parallel to either of {CD line} or {ML line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {NL polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is medial, and is equal to {FL polygon}, {FL polygon} is thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {FE line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
Thus, {FM line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the sum of the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is rational, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} medial, the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is [thus] incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And {CL polygon} (is) equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, and {FL polygon} equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
{CL polygon} [is] thus incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {CL polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} is to {MF line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CM line} is thus incommensurable in length with {MF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And both are rational (straight-lines).
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
[So], I say that (it is) also a fourth (apotome).

For since {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, the (square) on {AG magnitude} (is) thus also incommensurable with the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
And {CH polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon} equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
Thus, {CH polygon} is incommensurable with {KL polygon}.
And as {CH polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CK line} is thus incommensurable in length with {KM line} [Prop. 10.11].
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and the (square) on {AG magnitude} is equal to {CH polygon}, and the (square) on {GB magnitude} to {KL polygon}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} to {NL polygon}, {NL polygon} is thus the mean proportional to {CH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {CH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}.
But, as {CH polygon} (is) to {NL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {NM line}, and as {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {NM line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, as {CK line} (is) to {MN line}, so {MN line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 5.11].
The (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line} is thus equal to the (square) on {MN line}---that is to say, to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line} [Prop. 6.17].
Therefore, since {CM line} and {MF line} are two unequal straight-lines, and the (rectangle contained) by {CK line} and {KM line}, equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {MF line}, has been applied to {CM line}, falling short by a square figure, and divides it into incommensurable (parts), the square on {CM line} is thus greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.18].
And the whole of {CM line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
Thus, {CF line} is a fourth apotome [Def. 10.14].

Thus, the (square) on a minor, and so on ...

title: Proposition 101
prose:
The (square) on that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a fifth apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole, and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a fifth apotome.

Let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, the straightlines {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by them rational [Prop. 10.77].
And let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, and {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
The whole of {CL polygon} is thus equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And the sum of the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} together is medial.
Thus, {CL polygon} is medial.
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
{CM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable (in length) with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which {CE polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, the remainder {FL polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
Therefore, let {FM line} have been cut in half at {N point}.
And let {NO line} have been drawn through {N point}, parallel to either of {CD line} or {ML line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {NL polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And since twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is rational, and [is] equal to {FL polygon}, {FL polygon} is thus rational.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {EF line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
Thus, {FM line} is rational, and commensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.20].
And since {CL polygon} is medial, and {FL polygon} rational, {CL polygon} is thus incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {CL polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} (is) to {MF line} [Prop. 6.1].
{CM line} is thus incommensurable in length with {MF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And both are rational.
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a fifth (apotome).

For, similarly (to the previous propositions), we can show that the (rectangle contained) by {CKM line} is equal to the (square) on {NM line}---that is to say, to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line}.
And since the (square) on {AG magnitude} is incommensurable with the (square) on {GB magnitude}, and the (square) on {AG magnitude} (is) equal to {CH polygon}, and the (square) on {GB magnitude} to {KL polygon}, {CH polygon} (is) thus incommensurable with {KL polygon}.
And as {CH polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {CK line} (is) to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {CK line} (is) incommensurable in length with {KM line} [Prop. 10.11].
Therefore, since {CM line} and {MF line} are two unequal straight-lines, and (some area), equal to the fourth part of the (square) on {FM line}, has been applied to {CM line}, falling short by a square figure, and divides it into incommensurable (parts), the square on {CM line} is thus greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.18].
And the attachment {FM line} is commensurable with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
Thus, {CF line} is a fifth apotome [Def. 10.15].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 102
prose:
The (square) on that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a sixth apotome as breadth.

Let {AB magnitude} be that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole, and {CD line} a rational (straight-line).
And let {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CF line} as breadth.
I say that {CF line} is a sixth apotome.

For let {BG magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} medial, and the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.78].
Therefore, let {CH polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {CK line} as breadth, and {KL polygon}, equal to the (square) on {BG magnitude}.
Thus, the whole of {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
{CL polygon} [is] thus also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {CD line}, producing {CM line} as breadth.
Thus, {CM line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
Therefore, since {CL polygon} is equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, of which {CE polygon} (is) equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, the remainder {FL polygon} is thus equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 2.7].
And twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} (is) medial.
Thus, {FL polygon} is also medial.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {FE line}, producing {FM line} as breadth.
{FM line} is thus rational, and incommensurable in length with {CD line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is incommensurable with twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, and {CL polygon} equal to the (sum of the squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, and {FL polygon} equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {CL polygon} [is] thus incommensurable with {FL polygon}.
And as {CL polygon} (is) to {FL polygon}, so {CM line} is to {MF line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus,{CM line} is incommensurable in length with {MF line} [Prop. 10.11].
And they are both rational.
Thus, {CM line} and {MF line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
So, I say that (it is) also a sixth (apotome).

For since {FL polygon} is equal to twice the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, let {FM line} have been cut in half at {N point}, and let {NO line} have been drawn through {N point}, parallel to {CD line}.
Thus, {FO polygon} and {NL polygon} are each equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}.
And since {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} are incommensurable in square, the (square) on {AG magnitude} is thus incommensurable with the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
But, {CH polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon} is equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}.
Thus, {CH polygon} is incommensurable with {KL polygon}.
And as {CH polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}, so {CK line} is to {KM line} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, {CK line} is incommensurable (in length) with {KM line} [Prop. 10.11].
And since the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} is the mean proportional to the (squares) on {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and {CH polygon} is equal to the (square) on {AG magnitude}, and {KL polygon} equal to the (square) on {GB magnitude}, and {NL polygon} equal to the (rectangle contained) by {AG magnitude} and {GB magnitude}, {NL polygon} is thus also the mean proportional to {CH polygon} and {KL polygon}.
Thus, as {CH polygon} is to {NL polygon}, so {NL polygon} (is) to {KL polygon}.
And for the same (reasons as the preceding propositions), the square on {CM line} is greater than (the square on) {MF line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CM line}) [Prop. 10.18].
And neither of them is commensurable with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {CD line}.
Thus, {CF line} is a sixth apotome [Def. 10.16].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 103
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable in length with an apotome is an apotome, and (is) the same in order.

Let {AB magnitude} be an apotome, and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable in length with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is also an apotome, and (is) the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For since {AB magnitude} is an apotome, let {BE magnitude} be an attachment to it.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
And let it have been contrived that the (ratio) of {BE magnitude} to {DF magnitude} is the same as the ratio of {AB magnitude} to {CD magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].
Thus, also, as one is to one, (so) all [are] to all [Prop. 5.12].
And thus as the whole {AE magnitude} is to the whole {CF magnitude}, so {AB magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}.
And {AB magnitude} (is) commensurable in length with {CD magnitude}.
{AE magnitude} (is) thus also commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude}, and {BE magnitude} with {DF magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And {AE magnitude} and {BE magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.13].
[{CD magnitude} is thus an apotome.
So, I say that (it is) also the same in order as {AB magnitude}.]

Therefore, since as {AE magnitude} is to {CF magnitude}, so {BE magnitude} (is) to {DF magnitude}, thus, alternately, as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, so {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
So, the square on {AE magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {EB magnitude} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable, or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable, (in length) with ({AE magnitude}).
Therefore, if the (square) on {AE magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {EB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({AE magnitude}) then the square on {CF magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {FD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({CF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {AE magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) then so (is) {CF magnitude} [Prop. 10.12], and if {BE magnitude} (is commensurable), so (is) {DF magnitude}, and if neither of {AE magnitude} or {EB magnitude} (are commensurable), neither (are) either of {CF magnitude} or {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
And if the (square) on {AE magnitude} is greater [than (the square on) {EB magnitude}] by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({AE magnitude}) then the (square) on {CF magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {FD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {AE magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), so (is) {CF magnitude} [Prop. 10.12], and if {BE magnitude} (is commensurable), so (is) {DF magnitude}, and if neither of {AE magnitude} or {EB magnitude} (are commensurable), neither (are) either of {CF magnitude} or {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].

Thus, {CD magnitude} is an apotome, and (is) the same in order as {AB magnitude} [Defs. 10.11-10.16].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 104
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with an apotome of a medial (straight-line) is an apotome of a medial (straight-line), and (is) the same in order.

Let {AB magnitude} be an apotome of a medial (straight-line), and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable in length with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is also an apotome of a medial (straight-line), and (is) the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

For since {AB magnitude} is an apotome of a medial (straight-line), let {EB magnitude} be an attachment to it.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Props. 10.74, 10.75].
And let it have been contrived that as {AB magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, so {BE magnitude} (is) to {DF magnitude} [Prop. 6.12].
Thus, {AE magnitude} [is] also commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude}, and {BE magnitude} with {DF magnitude} [Props. 5.12, 10.11].
And {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are thus also medial (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Props. 10.23, 10.13].
Thus, {CD magnitude} is an apotome of a medial (straight-line) [Props. 10.74, 10.75].
So, I say that it is also the same in order as {AB magnitude}.

[For] since as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, so {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Props. 5.12, 5.16] [but as {AE magnitude} (is) to {EB magnitude}, so the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude}, and as {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude}, so the (square) on {CF magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}], thus as the (square) on {AE magnitude} is to the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude}, so the (square) on {CF magnitude} also (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.] [and, alternately, as the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {CF magnitude}, so the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}].
And the (square) on {AE magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {CF magnitude}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is also commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Props. 5.16, 10.11].
Therefore, either the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is rational, and the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} will also be rational [Def. 10.4], or the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} [is] medial, and the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [is] also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].

Therefore, {CD magnitude} is the apotome of a medial (straight-line), and is the same in order as {AB magnitude} [Props. 10.74, 10.75].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 105
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with a minor (straight-line) is a minor (straight-line).

For let {AB magnitude} be a minor (straight-line), and (let) {CD magnitude} (be) commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is also a minor (straight-line).

For let the same things have been contrived (as in the former proposition).
And since {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square [Prop. 10.76], {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are thus also (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square [Prop. 10.13].
Therefore, since as {AE magnitude} is to {EB magnitude}, so {CF magnitude} (is) to {FD magnitude} [Props. 5.12, 5.16], thus also as the (square) on {AE magnitude} is to the (square) on {EB magnitude}, so the (square) on {CF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FD magnitude} [Prop. 6.22].
Thus, via composition, as the (sum of the squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is to the (square) on {EB magnitude}, so the (sum of the squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.18], [also alternately].
And the (square) on {BE magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {DF magnitude} [Prop. 10.104].
The sum of the squares on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) thus also commensurable with the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Prop. 5.16, 10.11].
And the sum of the (squares) on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is rational [Prop. 10.76].
Thus, the sum of the (squares) on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} is also rational [Def. 10.4].
Again, since as the (square) on {AE magnitude} is to the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude}, so the (square) on {CF magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} [Prop. 10.21 lem.], and the square on {AE magnitude} (is) commensurable with the square on {CF magnitude}, the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is thus also commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
And the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} (is) medial [Prop. 10.76].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (is) also medial [Prop. 10.23 corr.].
{CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are thus (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them rational, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial.

Thus, {CD magnitude} is a minor (straight-line) [Prop. 10.76].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 106
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole is a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

Let {AB magnitude} be a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole, and (let) {CD magnitude} (be) commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is also a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial (whole).

For let {BE magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational [Prop. 10.77].
And let the same construction have been made (as in the previous propositions).
So, similarly to the previous (propositions), we can show that {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are in the same ratio as {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude}, and the sum of the squares on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} is commensurable with the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
Hence, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them rational.

{CD magnitude} is thus a (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.77].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 107
prose:
A (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole is itself also a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

Let {AB magnitude} be a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole, and let {CD magnitude} be commensurable (in length) with {AB magnitude}.
I say that {CD magnitude} is also a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For let {BE magnitude} be an attachment to {AB magnitude}.
And let the same construction have been made (as in the previous propositions).
Thus, {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, further, the sum of the squares on them incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by them [Prop. 10.78].
And, as was shown (previously), {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} are commensurable (in length) with {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} (respectively), and the sum of the squares on {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} with the sum of the squares on {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}, and the (rectangle contained) by {AE magnitude} and {EB magnitude} with the (rectangle contained) by {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude}.
Thus, {CF magnitude} and {FD magnitude} are also (straight-lines which are) incommensurable in square, making the sum of the squares on them medial, and the (rectangle contained) by them medial, and, further, the sum of the [squares] on them incommensurable with the (rectangle contained) by them.

Thus, {CD magnitude} is a (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.78].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 108
prose:
A medial (area) being subtracted from a rational (area), one of two irrational (straight-lines) arise (as) the square-root of the remaining area---either an apotome, or a minor (straight-line).

For let the medial (area) {BD polygon} have been subtracted from the rational (area) {BC polygon}.
I say that one of two irrational (straight-lines) arise (as) the square-root of the remaining (area), {EC polygon}---either an apotome, or a minor (straight-line).

For let the rational (straight-line) {FG line} have been laid out, and let the right-angled parallelogram {GH polygon}, equal to {BC polygon}, have been applied to {FG line}, and let {GK polygon}, equal to {DB polygon}, have been subtracted (from {GH polygon}).
Thus, the remainder {EC polygon} is equal to {LH polygon}.
Therefore, since {BC polygon} is a rational (area), and {BD polygon} a medial (area), and {BC polygon} (is) equal to {GH polygon}, and {BD polygon} to {GK polygon}, {GH polygon} is thus a rational (area), and {GK polygon} a medial (area).
And they are applied to the rational (straight-line) {FG line}.
Thus, {FH line} (is) rational, and commensurable in length with {FG line} [Prop. 10.20], and {FK line} (is) also rational, and incommensurable in length with {FG line} [Prop. 10.22].
Thus, {FH line} is incommensurable in length with {FK line} [Prop. 10.13].
{FH line} and {FK line} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {KH line} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73], and {KF line} an attachment to it.
So, the square on {HF line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straightline which is) either commensurable, or not (commensurable), (in length with {HF line}).

First, let the square (on it) be (greater) by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) commensurable (in length with {HF line}).
And the whole of {HF line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {FG line}.
Thus, {KH line} is a first apotome [Def. 10.1].
And the square-root of an (area) contained by a rational (straight-line) and a first apotome is an apotome [Prop. 10.91].
Thus, the square-root of {LH polygon}---that is to say, (of) {EC polygon}---is an apotome.

And if the square on {HF line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line which is) incommensurable (in length) with ({HF line}), and (since) the whole of {FH line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {FG line}, {KH line} is a fourth apotome [Prop. 10.14].
And the square-root of an (area) contained by a rational (straight-line) and a fourth apotome is a minor (straight-line) [Prop. 10.94].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 109
prose:
A rational (area) being subtracted from a medial (area), two other irrational (straight-lines) arise (as the square-root of the remaining area)---either a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), or that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

For let the rational (area) {BD polygon} have been subtracted from the medial (area) {BC polygon}.
I say that one of two irrational (straight-lines) arise (as) the square-root of the remaining (area), {EC polygon}---either a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), or that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole.

For let the rational (straight-line) {FG line} be laid down, and let similar areas (to the preceding proposition) have been applied (to it).
So, accordingly, {FH line} is rational, and incommensurable in length with {FG line}, and {KF line} (is) also rational, and commensurable in length with {FG line}.
Thus, {FH line} and {FK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.13].
{KH line} is thus an apotome [Prop. 10.73], and {FK line} an attachment to it.
So, the square on {HF line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({HF line}), or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with {HF line}).

Therefore, if the square on {HF line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({HF line}), and (since) the attachment {FK line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {FG line}, {KH line} is a second apotome [Def. 10.12].
And {FG line} (is) rational.
Hence, the square-root of {LH polygon}---that is to say, (of) {EC polygon}---is a first apotome of a medial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.92].

And if the square on {HF line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length with {HF line}), and (since) the attachment {FK line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {FG line}, {KH line} is a fifth apotome [Def. 10.15].
Hence, the square-root of {EC polygon} is that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.95].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 110
prose:
A medial (area), incommensurable with the whole, being subtracted from a medial (area), the two remaining irrational (straight-lines) arise (as) the (square-root of the area)---either a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), or that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For, as in the previous figures, let the medial (area) {BD polygon}, incommensurable with the whole, have been subtracted from the medial (area) {BC polygon}.
I say that the square-root of {EC polygon} is one of two irrational (straight-lines)---either a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), or that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.

For since {BC polygon} and {BD polygon} are each medial (areas), and {BC polygon} (is) incommensurable with {BD polygon}, accordingly, {FH line} and {FK line} will each be rational (straight-lines), and incommensurable in length with {FG line} [Prop. 10.22].
And since {BC polygon} is incommensurable with {BD polygon}---that is to say, {GH polygon} with {GK polygon}---{HF line} (is) also incommensurable (in length) with {FK line} [Props. 6.1, 10.11].
Thus, {FH line} and {FK line} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{KH line} is thus as apotome [Prop. 10.73], [and {FK line} an attachment (to it).
So, the square on {FH line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable, or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable, (in length) with({FH line}).]

So, if the square on {FH line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({FH line}), and (since) neither of {FH line} and {FK line} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {FG line}, {KH line} is a third apotome [Def. 10.3].
And {KL line} (is) rational.
And the rectangle contained by a rational (straight-line) and a third apotome is irrational, and the square-root of it is that irrational (straight-line) called a second apotome of a medial (straight-line) [Prop. 10.93].
Hence, the square-root of {LH polygon}---that is to say, (of) {EC polygon}---is a second apotome of a medial (straight-line).

And if the square on {FH line} is greater than (the square on) {FK line} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable [in length] with ({FH line}), and (since) neither of {HF line} and {FK line} is commensurable in length with {FG line}, {KH line} is a sixth apotome [Def. 10.16].
And the square-root of the (rectangle contained) by a rational (straight-line) and a sixth apotome is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole [Prop. 10.96].
Thus, the square-root of {LH polygon}---that is to say, (of) {EC polygon}---is that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) makes a medial whole.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 111
prose:
An apotome is not the same as a binomial.

Let {AB magnitude} be an apotome.
I say that {AB magnitude} is not the same as a binomial.

For, if possible, let it be (the same).
And let a rational (straight-line) {DC line} be laid down.
And let the rectangle {CE polygon}, equal to the (square) on {AB magnitude}, have been applied to {CD line}, producing {DE magnitude} as breadth.
Therefore, since {AB magnitude} is an apotome, {DE magnitude} is a first apotome [Prop. 10.97].
Let {EF magnitude} be an attachment to it.
Thus, {DF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {DF magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {FE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({DF magnitude}), and {DF magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {DC line} [Def. 10.10].
Again, since {AB magnitude} is a binomial, {DE magnitude} is thus a first binomial [Prop. 10.60].
Let ({DE magnitude}) have been divided into its (component) terms at {G point}, and let {DG magnitude} be the greater term.
Thus, {DG magnitude} and {GE magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, and the square on {DG magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {GE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({DG magnitude}), and the greater (term) {DG magnitude} is commensurable in length with the (previously) laid down rational (straight-line) {DC line} [Def. 10.5].
Thus, {DF magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {DG magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
The remainder {GF magnitude} is thus commensurable in length with {DF magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
[Therefore, since {DF magnitude} is commensurable with {GF magnitude}, and {DF magnitude} is rational, {GF magnitude} is thus also rational.
Therefore, since {DF magnitude} is commensurable in length with {GF magnitude},] {DF magnitude} (is) incommensurable in length with {EF magnitude}.
Thus, {FG magnitude} is also incommensurable in length with {EF magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].
{GF magnitude} and {FE magnitude} [are] thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EG magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].
But, (it is) also rational.
The very thing is impossible.

Thus, an apotome is not the same as a binomial.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

[Corollary]

The apotome and the irrational (straight-lines) after it are neither the same as a medial (straight-line) nor (the same) as one another.

For the (square) on a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a rational (straight-line which is) incommensurable in length with the (straight-line) to which (the area) is applied [Prop. 10.22].
And the (square) on an apotome, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a first apotome [Prop. 10.97].
And the (square) on a first apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a second apotome [Prop. 10.98].
And the (square) on a second apotome of a medial (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a third apotome [Prop. 10.99].
And (square) on a minor (straight-line), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a fourth apotome [Prop. 10.100].
And (square) on that (straight-line) which with a rational (area) produces a medial whole, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a fifth apotome [Prop. 10.101].
And (square) on that (straight-line) which with a medial (area) produces a medial whole, applied to a rational (straight-line), produces as breadth a sixth apotome [Prop. 10.102].
Therefore, since the aforementioned breadths differ from the first (breadth), and from one another---from the first, because it is rational, and from one another since they are not the same in order---clearly, the irrational (straight-lines) themselves also differ from one another.
And since it has been shown that an apotome is not the same as a binomial [Prop. 10.111], and (that) the (irrational straight-lines) after the apotome, being applied to a rational (straight-line), produce as breadth, each according to its own (order), apotomes, and (that) the (irrational straight-lines) after the binomial themselves also (produce as breadth), according (to their) order, binomials, the (irrational straight-lines) after the apotome are thus different, and the (irrational straight-lines) after the binomial (are also) different, so that there are, in order, 13 irrational (straight-lines) in all:
Medial,
Binomial,
First bimedial,
Second bimedial,
Major,
Square-root of a rational plus a medial (area),
Square-root of (the sum of) two medial (areas),
Apotome,
First apotome of a medial,
Second apotome of a medial,
Minor,
That which with a rational (area) produces a medial whole,
That which with a medial (area) produces a medial whole.

title: Proposition 112
prose:
The (square) on a rational (straight-line), applied to a binomial (straight-line), produces as breadth an apotome whose terms are commensurable (in length) with the terms of the binomial, and, furthermore, in the same ratio.
Moreover, the created apotome will have the same order as the binomial.

Let {A magnitude} be a rational (straight-line), and {BC magnitude} a binomial (straight-line), of which let {DC magnitude} be the greater term.
And let the (rectangle contained) by {BC magnitude} and {EF magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}.
I say that {EF magnitude} is an apotome whose terms are commensurable (in length) with {CD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, and in the same ratio, and, moreover, that {EF magnitude} will have the same order as {BC magnitude}.

For, again, let the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {G magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}.
Therefore, since the (rectangle contained) by {BC magnitude} and {EF magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {G magnitude}, thus as {CB magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so {G magnitude} (is) to {EF magnitude} [Prop. 6.16].
And {CB magnitude} (is) greater than {BD magnitude}.
Thus, {G magnitude} is also greater than {EF magnitude} [Props. 5.16, 5.14].
Let {EH magnitude} be equal to {G magnitude}.
Thus, as {CB magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so {HE magnitude} (is) to {EF magnitude}.
Thus, via separation, as {CD magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so {HF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.17].
Let it have been contrived that as {HF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude}, so {FK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}.
And, thus, the whole {HK magnitude} is to the whole {KF magnitude}, as {FK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}.
For as one of the leading (proportional magnitudes is) to one of the following, so all of the leading (magnitudes) are to all of the following [Prop. 5.12].
And as {FK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}, so {CD magnitude} is to {DB magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
And, thus, as {HK magnitude} (is) to {KF magnitude}, so {CD magnitude} is to {DB magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
And the (square) on {CD magnitude} (is) commensurable with the (square) on {DB magnitude} [Prop. 10.36].
The (square) on {HK magnitude} is thus also commensurable with the (square) on {KF magnitude} [Props. 6.22, 10.11].
And as the (square) on {HK magnitude} is to the (square) on {KF magnitude}, so {HK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}, since the three (straight-lines) {HK magnitude}, {KF magnitude}, and {KE magnitude} are proportional [Def. 5.9].
{HK magnitude} is thus commensurable in length with {KE magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
Hence, {HE magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {EK magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
And since the (square) on {A magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {EH magnitude} and {BD magnitude}, and the (square) on {A magnitude} is rational, the (rectangle contained) by {EH magnitude} and {BD magnitude} is thus also rational.
And it is applied to the rational (straight-line) {BD magnitude}.
Thus, {EH magnitude} is rational, and commensurable in length with {BD magnitude} [Prop. 10.20].
And, hence, the (straight-line) commensurable (in length) with it, {EK magnitude}, is also rational [Def. 10.3], and commensurable in length with {BD magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
Therefore, since as {CD magnitude} is to {DB magnitude}, so {FK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}, and {CD magnitude} and {DB magnitude} are (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only, {FK magnitude} and {KE magnitude} are also commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And {KE magnitude} is rational.
Thus, {FK magnitude} is also rational.
{FK magnitude} and {KE magnitude} are thus rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
Thus, {EF magnitude} is an apotome [Prop. 10.73].

And the square on {CD magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {DB magnitude} either by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable, or by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable, (in length) with ({CD magnitude}).

Therefore, if the square on {CD magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {DB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with [{CD magnitude}] then the square on {FK magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {KE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({FK magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {CD magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), (so) also (is) {FK magnitude} [Props. 10.11, 10.12].
And if {BD magnitude} (is commensurable), (so) also (is) {KE magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if neither of {CD magnitude} or {DB magnitude} (is commensurable), neither also (are) either of {FK magnitude} or {KE magnitude}.

And if the square on {CD magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {DB magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({CD magnitude}) then the square on {FK magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {KE magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({FK magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {CD magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), (so) also (is) {FK magnitude} [Props. 10.11, 10.12].
And if {BD magnitude} (is commensurable), (so) also (is) {KE magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if neither of {CD magnitude} or {DB magnitude} (is commensurable), neither also (are) either of {FK magnitude} or {KE magnitude}.
Hence, {FE magnitude} is an apotome whose terms, {FK magnitude} and {KE magnitude}, are commensurable (in length) with the terms, {CD magnitude} and {DB magnitude}, of the binomial, and in the same ratio.
And ({FE magnitude}) has the same order as {BC magnitude} [Defs. 10.5-10.10].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 113
prose:
The (square) on a rational (straight-line), applied to an apotome, produces as breadth a binomial whose terms are commensurable with the terms of the apotome, and in the same ratio.
Moreover, the created binomial has the same order as the apotome.

Let {A magnitude} be a rational (straight-line), and {BD magnitude} an apotome.
And let the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {KH magnitude} be equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}, such that the square on the rational (straight-line) {A magnitude}, applied to the apotome {BD magnitude}, produces {KH magnitude} as breadth.
I say that {KH magnitude} is a binomial whose terms are commensurable with the terms of {BD magnitude}, and in the same ratio, and, moreover, that {KH magnitude} has the same order as {BD magnitude}.

For let {DC magnitude} be an attachment to {BD magnitude}.
Thus, {BC magnitude} and {CD magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.73].
And let the (rectangle contained) by {BC magnitude} and {G magnitude} also be equal to the (square) on {A magnitude}.
And the (square) on {A magnitude} (is) rational.
The (rectangle contained) by {BC magnitude} and {G magnitude} (is) thus also rational.
And it has been applied to the rational (straight-line) {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {G magnitude} is rational, and commensurable in length with {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.20].
Therefore, since the (rectangle contained) by {BC magnitude} and {G magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {BD magnitude} and {KH magnitude}, thus, proportionally, as {CB magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so {KH magnitude} (is) to {G magnitude} [Prop. 6.16].
And {BC magnitude} (is) greater than {BD magnitude}.
Thus, {KH magnitude} (is) also greater than {G magnitude} [Prop. 5.16, 5.14].
Let {KE magnitude} be made equal to {G magnitude}.
{KE magnitude} is thus commensurable in length with {BC magnitude}.
And since as {CB magnitude} is to {BD magnitude}, so {HK magnitude} (is) to {KE magnitude}, thus, via conversion, as {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude}, so {KH magnitude} (is) to {HE magnitude} [Prop. 5.19 corr.].
Let it have been contrived that as {KH magnitude} (is) to {HE magnitude}, so {HF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude}.
And thus the remainder {KF magnitude} is to {FH magnitude}, as {KH magnitude} (is) to {HE magnitude}---that is to say, [as] {BC magnitude} (is) to {CD magnitude} [Prop. 5.19].
And {BC magnitude} and {CD magnitude} [are] commensurable in square only.

{KF magnitude} and {FH magnitude} are thus also commensurable in square only [Prop. 10.11].
And since as {KH magnitude} is to {HE magnitude}, (so) {KF magnitude} (is) to {FH magnitude}, but as {KH magnitude} (is) to {HE magnitude}, (so) {HF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude}, thus, also as {KF magnitude} (is) to {FH magnitude}, (so) {HF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude} [Prop. 5.11].
And hence as the first (is) to the third, so the (square) on the first (is) to the (square) on the second [Def. 5.9].
And thus as {KF magnitude} (is) to {FE magnitude}, so the (square) on {KF magnitude} (is) to the (square) on {FH magnitude}.
And the (square) on {KF magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {FH magnitude}.
For {KF magnitude} and {FH magnitude} are commensurable in square.
Thus, {KF magnitude} is also commensurable in length with {FE magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
Hence, {KF magnitude} [is] also commensurable in length with {KE magnitude} [Prop. 10.15].
And {KE magnitude} is rational, and commensurable in length with {BC magnitude}.
Thus, {KF magnitude} (is) also rational, and commensurable in length with {BC magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And since as {BC magnitude} is to {CD magnitude}, (so) {KF magnitude} (is) to {FH magnitude}, alternately, as {BC magnitude} (is) to {KF magnitude}, so {DC magnitude} (is) to {FH magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
And {BC magnitude} (is) commensurable (in length) with {KF magnitude}.
Thus, {FH magnitude} (is) also commensurable in length with {CD magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And {BC magnitude} and {CD magnitude} are rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only.
{KF magnitude} and {FH magnitude} are thus also rational (straight-lines which are) commensurable in square only [Def. 10.3, Prop. 10.13].
Thus, {KH magnitude} is a binomial [Prop. 10.36].

Therefore, if the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {CD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}), then the square on {KF magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {FH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) commensurable (in length) with ({KF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {BC magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), (so) also (is) {KF magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if {CD magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), (so) also (is) {FH magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if neither of {BC magnitude} or {CD magnitude} (are commensurable), neither also (are) either of {KF magnitude} or {FH magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].

And if the square on {BC magnitude} is greater than (the square on) {CD magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({BC magnitude}) then the square on {KF magnitude} will also be greater than (the square on) {FH magnitude} by the (square) on (some straight-line) incommensurable (in length) with ({KF magnitude}) [Prop. 10.14].
And if {BC magnitude} is commensurable in length with a (previously) laid down rational (straight-line), (so) also (is) {KF magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if {CD magnitude} is commensurable, (so) also (is) {FH magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
And if neither of {BC magnitude} or {CD magnitude} (are commensurable), neither also (are) either of {KF magnitude} or {FH magnitude} [Prop. 10.13].

{KH magnitude} is thus a binomial whose terms, {KF magnitude} and {FH magnitude}, [are] commensurable (in length) with the terms, {BC magnitude} and {CD magnitude}, of the apotome, and in the same ratio.
Moreover, {KH magnitude} will have the same order as {BC magnitude} [Defs. 10.5-10.10].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 114
prose:
If an area is contained by an apotome, and a binomial whose terms are commensurable with, and in the same ratio as, the terms of the apotome then the square-root of the area is a rational (straight-line).

For let an area, the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude}, have been contained by the apotome {AB magnitude}, and the binomial {CD magnitude}, of which let the greater term be {CE magnitude}.
And let the terms of the binomial, {CE magnitude} and {ED magnitude}, be commensurable with the terms of the apotome, {AF magnitude} and {FB magnitude} (respectively), and in the same ratio.
And let the square-root of the (rectangle contained) by {AB magnitude} and {CD magnitude} be {G magnitude}.
I say that {G magnitude} is a rational (straight-line).

For let the rational (straight-line) {H magnitude} be laid down.
And let (some rectangle), equal to the (square) on {H magnitude}, have been applied to {CD magnitude}, producing {KL magnitude} as breadth.
Thus, {KL magnitude} is an apotome, of which let the terms, {KM magnitude} and {ML magnitude}, be commensurable with the terms of the binomial, {CE magnitude} and {ED magnitude} (respectively), and in the same ratio [Prop. 10.112].
But, {CE magnitude} and {ED magnitude} are also commensurable with {AF magnitude} and {FB magnitude} (respectively), and in the same ratio.
Thus, as {AF magnitude} is to {FB magnitude}, so {KM magnitude} (is) to {ML magnitude}.
Thus, alternately, as {AF magnitude} is to {KM magnitude}, so {BF magnitude} (is) to {LM magnitude} [Prop. 5.16].
Thus, the remainder {AB magnitude} is also to the remainder {KL magnitude} as {AF magnitude} (is) to {KM magnitude} [Prop. 5.19].
And {AF magnitude} (is) commensurable with {KM magnitude} [Prop. 10.12].
{AB magnitude} is thus also commensurable with {KL magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And as {AB magnitude} is to {KL magnitude}, so the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {AB magnitude} (is) to the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {KL magnitude} [Prop. 6.1].
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {AB magnitude} is also commensurable with the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {KL magnitude} [Prop. 10.11].
And the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {KL magnitude} (is) equal to the (square) on {H magnitude}.
Thus, the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {AB magnitude} is commensurable with the (square) on {H magnitude}.
And the (square) on {G magnitude} is equal to the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {AB magnitude}.
The (square) on {G magnitude} is thus commensurable with the (square) on {H magnitude}.
And the (square) on {H magnitude} (is) rational.
Thus, the (square) on {G magnitude} is also rational.
{G magnitude} is thus rational.
And it is the square-root of the (rectangle contained) by {CD magnitude} and {AB magnitude}.

Thus, if an area is contained by an apotome, and a binomial whose terms are commensurable with, and in the same ratio as, the terms of the apotome, then the square-root of the area is a rational (straight-line).

Corollary

And it has also been made clear to us, through this, that it is possible for a rational area to be contained by irrational straight-lines.
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.

title: Proposition 115
prose:
An infinite (series) of irrational (straight-lines) can be created from a medial (straight-line), and none of them is the same as any of the preceding (straight-lines).

Let {A magnitude} be a medial (straight-line).
I say that an infinite (series) of irrational (straight-lines) can be created from {A magnitude}, and that none of them is the same as any of the preceding (straight-lines).

Let the rational (straight-line) {B magnitude} be laid down.
And let the (square) on {C magnitude} be equal to the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {A magnitude}.
Thus, {C magnitude} is irrational [Def. 10.4].
For an (area contained) by an irrational and a rational (straight-line) is irrational [Prop. 10.20].
And ({C magnitude} is) not the same as any of the preceding (straight-lines).
For the (square) on none of the preceding (straight-lines), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces a medial (straight-line) as breadth.
So, again, let the (square) on {D magnitude} be equal to the (rectangle contained) by {B magnitude} and {C magnitude}.
Thus, the (square) on {D magnitude} is irrational [Prop. 10.20].
{D magnitude} is thus irrational [Def. 10.4].
And ({D magnitude} is) not the same as any of the preceding (straight-lines).
For the (square) on none of the preceding (straight-lines), applied to a rational (straight-line), produces {C magnitude} as breadth.
So, similarly, this arrangement being advanced to infinity, it is clear that an infinite (series) of irrational (straight-lines) can be created from a medial (straight-line), and that none of them is the same as any of the preceding (straight-lines).
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.
